content:
# Welcome to Nebula Team’s Homepage!

The Nebula team is a new team at Invent as is responsible for speeding up our customer delivery processes. The Nebula team bridges the gap between product teams and delivery teams and aims to productize the more technical aspects of each of the Invents solutions. In essence, team is responsible for building and delivery a customer delivery platform that can be used by delivery teams to quickly assemble and configure solutions for our customer.

Feel free to browse through the following pages to find out what we have been up to and what’s on our roadmap:

| Team Name: | Nebula |
| --- | --- |
| Slack: | #ask-nebula |
| Email: | nebula@inventanalytics.com |
| Manager: |  |
| Jira Board: | https://invent.atlassian.net/jira/software/c/projects/NEB/boards/326 |

Team VisionCreate a self service and frictionless Invent platform that can be used by delivery teams to quickly implement Invent solutions for the customer.

Team Mission

can be used by delivery teams to quickly implement Invent solutions for the customer.

Team Mission

(Suggestions)
The Nebula team’s mission is to accelerate customer discovery and delivery at Invent by building a unified delivery platform. We streamline collaboration between product and delivery teams, transforming technical solution components into reusable, configurable products that enable faster, more reliable and precise customer deployments.

Team Goals

(Suggestions)

Efficiency & Speed

- Reduce time-to-delivery by simplifying solution assembly and configuration.
- Minimize repetitive technical work through reusable components and automation.

Platform Development & Adoption

- Build a robust, scalable customer delivery platform.
- Drive adoption of the platform across all delivery teams.

Collaboration & Integration

Collaboration & Integration

- Better integration with product and delivery teams for funneling new requirements, developing solution expertise and sharing knowledge.
- Ensure smooth handoffs between product and delivery teams through clear platform interfaces.

KPIs

Time to delivery for each solution i.e. Store Replenishment, Store Transfer etc.

Hits/Misses against definition of ready and definition of done.

Time for customer onboarding

Issues/Misses in each of customer onboarding and solution implementation

Implementations per Quarter

Definition of SOPs, playbooks and standard templates/processes.

content:
This page serves as a guide to import client custom raw tables into invent datastore.

This tutorial outlines the steps (when ran in a *notebook*) from pre-etl to importing into datastore (operation tables).

The examples below are based on the `ct_po_receipts` table provided by the client, which we want to persist as a feed and as an operation table.

1. Define file read config in rocks_extension/opal/config_metadata.yml

```yaml
ct_po_receipts:
  key: "{raw_data_path}/ct_po_receipts.csv"
  storage_type: csv
  options:
    header: ${commons.header}
    sep: "|"
```

1. Define pre_etl task in rocks_extension/opal/config.yml

```yaml
pre_etl_ct_po_receipts:
  feed_table_name: ct_po_receipts_feed
  commons_table_name: ct_po_receipts
  sources:
    raw:
      metadata_provider: local
      table_name: ct_po_receipts
      is_required: True
```

1. Publish the data feed schema into PokedexThis can be done in a notebook using the Pokedex API

metadata.title: Import Custom tables

content:
``

1. Publish the data feed schema into PokedexThis can be done in a notebook using the Pokedex API

```py
customer = "cititrends"
environment = "prod"
cloud_provider = "azure"  # aws or azure
storage_type = "delta"
file_schema =  '/mnt/'
bucket = 'invent-cititrends-datastore'

# schema for feed

metadata = {
      "schema": asn_schema,
    "storage_type": storage_type,
    # "description": <table description>,
    "path": {
        "bucket": bucket,
        "file_schema": file_schema,
        "key": "feed/ct_po_receipts"
    }
}

client.post_metadata(
    customer=customer,
    name="ct_po_receipts_feed",
    environment=environment,
    metadata=metadata,
)

# schema for operation
metadata = {
      "schema": asn_schema,
      "storage_type": storage_type,
    # "description": <table description>,
    "path": {
        "bucket": bucket,
        "file_schema": file_schema,
        "key": "operation/ct_po_receipts"
    }
}

metadata.title: Import Custom tables

content:
cket": bucket,
        "file_schema": file_schema,
        "key": "operation/ct_po_receipts"
    }
}

client.post_metadata(
    customer=customer,
    name="ct_po_receipts",
    environment=environment,
    metadata=metadata,
)
```

1. Define data feed tasks in rocks_extension/opal/config.yml. These configs vary based on the implementation and the client needs. Here’s an example:

```yaml
data_feed_ct_po_receipts:
  operation_table_name: ct_po_receipts
  feed_table_name: ct_po_receipts_feed
  id_conversions:
    - product
  overwrite:
    enabled: True
    partitioned: False
  save_update_interval_flag: True
  raise_exception_if_empty: True
  commons_table_name: ct_po_receipts
  operation_date_column: receipt_date
  eliminated_by_master_control:
    enabled: False
    control_table_name: control_eliminated_by_master_ct_po_receipts
```

metadata.title: Import Custom tables

content:
_control:
    enabled: False
    control_table_name: control_eliminated_by_master_ct_po_receipts
```

Once the schema for feed and operation is published, and the config is update, you can then test by running the pre-etl code, and the `DataFeedNew` to ensure the data is being persisted in the storage, both as a feed (from pre-etl) and as an operation (from update_datastore)

```py
# Example to persist operation data

from rocks.opal.data_feed_new import DataFeedNew

DataFeedNew(customer_config_path="dbfs:/FileStore/src/feature-test/scripts/opal/config.yaml",
            run_id=run_id,
            run_date=run_date,
            config_section="data_feed_ct_po_receipts",
            pipeline_name="update_datastore").run()
```

A full running example can be found [here](https://adb-3365102088809467.7.azuredatabricks.net/editor/notebooks/2697803232791451?o=3365102088809467).

### Workflow DAG Documentation

#### Step 1: Add a Workflow DAG Script

1. Create a DAG script under the dags folder.
2. Ensure the NAME parameter which is DAG name matches the workflow name defined in the fabbrica.yaml file.
3. Define the YAML path for pipelines as all pipelines in Invent are defined in a YAML file.
4. Define correct app for your workflow. If you choose ‘noob’ app, this configurations will be added automatically.If you choose ‘shield’ app, this configurations will be added automatically.If you choose ‘d1_reporting’ app, this configurations will be added automatically.

Example Script:

```
""" Academy Custom Dag """
import os
from airflow.operators.empty import EmptyOperator
from rocks.core.pipeline import Pipeline
from fabbrica.dags.rocks_dag import RocksDAG

class AcademyEtlWorkflow(Pipeline):
    """ Academy Custom Dag """

    NAME = "etl_workflow"
    PIPELINE_CONFIG = os.path.join(
        os.path.dirname(__file__), "pipelines", "etl_workflow.yaml"
    )

metadata.title: How to add  custom workflow?

content:
INE_CONFIG = os.path.join(
        os.path.dirname(__file__), "pipelines", "etl_workflow.yaml"
    )

class AcademyEtlWorkflowDag(RocksDAG):
    """ Academy Custom Dag """

    app = "shield"
    dag_id = "etl_workflow"

    def pipeline(self):
        """Definition of pipeline here"""
        pipeline = AcademyEtlWorkflow(
            pipeline_overrides=self.config.rocks_conf.dict(exclude_unset=True),
            included_tasks=self.config.rocks_conf.included_tasks,
            excluded_tasks=self.config.rocks_conf.excluded_tasks,
        ).to_omegaconf()
        return pipeline

    def before_pipeline_tasks_creation(self, dag):
        EmptyOperator(task_id="etl_workflow_start", dag=dag)
        EmptyOperator(task_id="etl_workflow_end", dag=dag)

with AcademyEtlWorkflowDag(config_path="/etc/airflow/dags/config").dag() as workflow_dag:
    pass
```

#### Step 2: Define Tasks in the YAML File

1. Define tasks for the custom workflow pipeline in the related YAML file.
2. Include start and end tasks.
3. Pass parameters from application_args and reference them in the CustomStep class. You can use application_args parameters directly in your workflow script with a self keyword.

Example YAML Configuration:

content:
n_args parameters directly in your workflow script with a self keyword.

Example YAML Configuration:

```
etl_workflow:
  start_node: etl_workflow_start
  end_node: etl_workflow_end
  tasks:
    etl_workflow_start:
      desc: Dummy start task
      is_external: True
    etl_workflow_end:
      desc: Dummy end task
      is_external: True
    import_seasonality_coefficients:
      application: ${application}
      module: rocks_extension.custom.import_seasonality_coefficients
      class: CustomStep
      application_args:
        run_date: ${jinja.run_date_daily}
        foo: bar
      upstream_task_ids:
        - ${start_node}
      downstream_task_ids:
        - ${end_node}

```

---

#### Step 3: Define the Workflow in fabbrica.yaml

1. Define the workflow and fill the Tags section correctly.
2. Set Team, Project, and pipeline details to align with the workflow purpose.

Example fabbrica.yaml Configuration:

          resources:

                - invent-warp

1. Place the module in the related folder under rocks_extension.
2. Inherit the appropriate class for the step:ETL Steps: from rocks.core.pipeline_step import BaseSparkPipelineStepForecast Steps: from rocks.noob.noob_base import NoobPipelineStepReplenishment Steps: ??No Relation: from rocks.core.pipeline_step import BaseSparkPipelineStepConfigurable

1. option_code is missing from the CSV
2. SeasonCodeActive is extra in the CSV. Not sure if it needs to be include
3. ProductGroup1,2,3 are missing descriptions
4. BudgetCat is extra in the CSV
5. CasePackQuantity - Not sure if it maps to PackType in our mapping.
6. price_with_tax and price_without_tax are missing from the CVS
7. There are several stockXXX_XXX columns - not sure if they need to be used.
8. For  ´is_active´ there are three values in the CSV - Active(A), Passive and End of Life. We are only using Active. Not sure what passive means in this context.
9. last_original_period and last_original_cost - not sure if they are to be used.
10. In summary, the following required fields are missing:product_group_1_description

content:
Pokedex is an internal service that keeps metadata (schema, path, etc.) of your data. It allows you to get or update these metadata using HTTP methods.

## Overview of Pokedex Functionality

Pokedex acts as the central repository for storing the default schemas of all tables within a project. Each project has its own isolated schema, ensuring no overlap or interference between different projects.

The metadata of the Spider project, which is an internal customer project, contains the most up-to-date default schemas. You can view the default schemas by retrieving the metadata associated with a table. This document will guide you through the steps to get and update the metadata of your project.

## Pokedex Check During Build

metadata.title: How to Update Pokedex for custom/extended Feeds

content:
you through the steps to get and update the metadata of your project.

## Pokedex Check During Build

Pokedex is integrated into the Jenkins build pipeline. During build time, Pokedex metadata is checked as part of the Pokedex Metadata Check step. If an error occurs during this step, you will be able to see the problem in the Jenkins logs. Typically, errors indicate missing or unnecessary columns in your schema. To resolve these issues, you can adjust the metadata by using the appropriate GET or POST actions, which will be explained in the next sections.

## Editing Schemas in Pokedex

In general, you can modify the schemas of a project as needed, but with one major exception: Master Tables. These tables have strict controls over changes to their schema. If you wish to add custom columns to master tables, you cannot modify them directly. Instead, you’ll need to write extensions to add the necessary columns.

metadata.title: How to Update Pokedex for custom/extended Feeds

content:
cannot modify them directly. Instead, you’ll need to write extensions to add the necessary columns.

To ensure the changes are reflected in Pokedex, you must also add the schema of any extensions to Pokedex, which is crucial for proper metadata management.

## Managing Metadata for Different Environments

You can retrieve or post metadata to either the prod or dev environments, depending on your requirements.

- Prod (Production): This is the environment used when working with the main branch. Any changes made here will apply to the live system.
- Dev (Development): This environment is used when working with non-main branches. Changes in this environment allow you to test updates before they are deployed to production.

> Note: When interacting with Pokedex, ensure you are targeting the correct environment based on whether you’re working with the main branch or a development branch.

---

# How To Use

metadata.title: How to Update Pokedex for custom/extended Feeds

content:
ent based on whether you’re working with the main branch or a development branch.

---

# How To Use

The GET and POST actions in Pokedex are essential for interacting with the metadata:

- GET: This action is used to retrieve the current schema metadata for a project or environment (e.g., prod or dev).
- POST: This action is used to update or add new metadata to a project’s schema.

To use these actions, you must specify the appropriate endpoint, the project you’re working with, and the environment (prod or dev).

1. GET Action:Send a request to retrieve the metadata for a table in a specific project and environment.from warp.core.pokedex import Pokedex
from pprint import pp

customer = "spider"
environment = "prod"
cloud_provider = "aws"  # aws or azure

client = Pokedex(customer=customer,
                 environment=environment,

content:
## Overview

In Airflow pipelines that interact with cloud storage (such as Azure Blob Storage or Amazon S3), a single bucket or blob store is configured as the default storage target. This is typically assigned to the pipeline’s `self.storage_driver` instance and corresponds to the bucket name defined in the environment variable `INPUT_BUCKET_NAME` (set via `.cicd/build/Jenkinsfile`).

However, certain pipeline tasks may require interaction with additional buckets. This guide explains how to instantiate and use a secondary storage driver for such cases.

## Default Storage Driver Behavior

Each task or pipeline component generally uses the default storage driver:

```
self.storage_driver
```

This driver is configured to interact with a single bucket. It does not have access to other buckets by default.

## Accessing Additional Buckets

metadata.title: How to Access Additional Buckets/Blob Stores from Airflow DAGs

content:
single bucket. It does not have access to other buckets by default.

## Accessing Additional Buckets

To operate on a second bucket, you must explicitly instantiate a new storage driver that points to the desired target. This driver uses the same underlying driver logic but is initialized with the new bucket's name and configuration.

### Usage Guide

Use the following pattern to create a new storage driver for a different bucket:

```
# Step 1: Get the driver constructor
self.new_storage_driver = get_driver(
    cloud_provider=self.provider.name.value,
    service="storage",
    driver_type=self.config.main_conf.global_settings.data_transfer_provider
)

# Step 2: Instantiate the driver with a different bucket
self.new_storage_driver: BaseStorageDriver = self.new_storage_driver(
    bucket_name="<target-bucket-name>",
    driver_args=self.global_settings.driver_args
        .get(self.provider.name.value)
        .dict(),
)
```

## Operations Between Buckets

metadata.title: How to Access Additional Buckets/Blob Stores from Airflow DAGs

content:
er_args
        .get(self.provider.name.value)
        .dict(),
)
```

## Operations Between Buckets

In some scenarios — particularly with Amazon S3 — it's possible to copy files directly between buckets using native cloud APIs. This operation does not require the storage driver to be bound to a specific bucket, so any storage driver instance with access to the S3 resource can be used to perform the copy.

Here’s an example pattern that uses the S3 resource to copy a file from one bucket to another:

```
source_bucket = "<source-bucket-name>"
destination_bucket = "<destination-bucket-name>"

source_path = "<source/path>"
destination_path = "<destination/path>"

# Use the underlying S3 resource to perform a direct copy between buckets
(self.any_storage_driver.s3_resource
    .Object(destination_bucket, destination_path)
    .copy({
        "Bucket": source_bucket,
        "Key": source_path
    })
)
```

metadata.title: How to Access Additional Buckets/Blob Stores from Airflow DAGs

1. Ways of working: Most of what we learn and encounter depends on what comes before it. For instance, solving omega issues requires an understanding of what Omega is and how it works. If we are working together, we can lean on support from other team members. This speeds up the learning process and helps share knowledge. Also, waiting for the Shield or Omega team takes time. Wayne agrees as well.None of us should work on a project entirely on our own. We could learn from each other faster and don’t have to toil on figuring out what the team collectively might know already.
2. Project PMs: There are multiple project/delivery team members, and we feel we are left alone when there are challenges. If we have more support, we can better reason with the delivery team.

content: 4. Team: We don’t feel like we belong to the team, but I feel like I am in the Tecovas of the OTCF team. Working together as a Nebula team will help. It's great to work with the delivery team, but it feels like a short-term assignment. We can split it between two team members —we can decide on the split. We should be able to manage it for now, as we are already managing those projects on our own.Splitting will help with the workload as a whole because at the initial stage, we are just waiting for the customer to provide data in the right format. In the following couple of weeks, we are under pressure to deliver 3DD, and then it eases again with advanced configuration. That 3DD is on a critical path—100% load for 2 weeks and then drops again.Most of the time, we try to understand what the customer is sending us, and low-level/skillful work takes a lot of time. If we can automate that as a team, it will improve significantly. Its only in cases where the tool is not up to the job (i.e

metadata.title: Team Meeting - 15th May, 2025

as a team, it will improve significantly. Its only in cases where the tool is not up to the job (i.e. exceptions) that we can engage with the customer.Lack of product team support: If there was a more experienced team to help us at least initially until we learn, would help immensely. We only learn about our solution when we run into errors.
5. Lack of internal organisation: We did not have an internal backlog, and we were just working on customer deliverables, which meant that between customer deliveries, we didn’t know what to do.

Documentation gaps/mismatch: Documentation is not good enough for new team membersIts hard to know if what you are reading is indeed the most recent and updated version.There is a lot of documentation but it's either outdated or missing some critical information. In some cases its too detailed without being helpful for implementation projects. Very narrow in some cases - if you can find an example relevant to you great. i.e. Join examples for Noob describing configuration for joins. Our knowledge is “Spotty”. I was trying to do x for a customer, but how does it match to what I am trying to do.We need to document our issues better as well - we can mitigate the learning curve within the team.

content:
Main PrincipleBootstrap DAGis used when onboarding new noob pipelines, i.e. new dag stages.

---

Overview: DAG Stage Mechanism

Noob DAGs operate under a staged system, ranging from stage 1 to stage 20. This staged approach enables incremental introduction of forecasting features, ensuring controlled rollout and validation.

Each stage, represented as `dag_stage`, introduces new components to the pipeline. This modularity allows development teams to safely manage complexity and ensure stability as tasks are added.

For a comprehensive list of noob DAG stages and their definitions, refer to the document: [Noob DAG Stages].

---

Triggering Noob Bootstrap

The `noob_bootstrap` process is initiated when a new stage is being onboarded into the pipeline. While stage 1 can be onboarded with no manual intervention, subsequent stages require manual setup and validation.

It is strongly advised to:

metadata.title: Noob Bootstrap Guide

content:
ual intervention, subsequent stages require manual setup and validation.

It is strongly advised to:

- Trigger each task manually via notebooks to validate execution and data integrity.
- Avoid triggering via Airflow, as this may result in long-running executions with unintended outputs due to downstream dependencies.

---

Triggering Bootstrap Notebooks: Step-by-Step Guide

1. Access the YAML ConfigurationOpen the noob_bootstrap.yaml file.Locate the task to be onboarded.
2. Check for config_sectionIf config_section is defined within the task, you can skip visiting the class.If not, open the class module listed in the task to retrieve the config_section manually.
3. Review the config.yaml FileLocate the relevant config_section.Parameters within this section can be overridden at runtime as needed.
4. Import and Execute the Class in NotebookUse the module and class from the YAML configuration.Execute the task with the correct parameters and run_date.

---

metadata.title: Noob Bootstrap Guide

content:
nd class from the YAML configuration.Execute the task with the correct parameters and run_date.

---

Example 1: Task Without`application_args`

Task: `daily_data_create`

YAML snippet:

```
daily_data_create:
  desc: >
    Generate daily data
  module: rocks.noob.daily_data
  class: DailyData
  application: ${application}
  upstream_task_ids:
    - create_holiday_table
    - cl_product_agg_level_generator
    - cl_store_agg_level_generator
  downstream_task_ids:
    - create_ignore_tables
  activation_stage: ${oc.select:initial_dag_activation_stage, 0}
```

Steps:

- Since no config_section is listed, visit the class definition:

```
def __init__(
    self,
    update_range: Optional[int] = None,
    config_section: str = "daily_data",
    kwargs):
```

- From the class, retrieve config_section = "daily_data".
- Refer to the config.yaml for parameters under this section:

metadata.title: Noob Bootstrap Guide

content:
etrieve config_section = "daily_data".
- Refer to the config.yaml for parameters under this section:

```
daily_data:
  groupby_columns:
    - product_id
    - store_id
    - date
    ...
  io_control_mode: RAISE
```

- Parameters can be overridden as needed.
- Run the class in a notebook:

```
from rocks.noob.daily_data import DailyData
daily = DailyData(run_date="2024-01-01")
daily.run()
```

---

Example 2: Task With`application_args`

Task: `cl_weekly_lag_features_create`

YAML snippet:

metadata.title: Noob Bootstrap Guide

content:
`

---

Example 2: Task With`application_args`

Task: `cl_weekly_lag_features_create`

YAML snippet:

```
cl_weekly_lag_features_create:
  desc: >
    Generates lag features for the requested configuration.
  module: rocks.noob.enrich
  class: LagFeatures
  application: ${application}
  application_args:
    config_section: cl_weekly_lag_features
    period: week
    aggregation_cols:
      - store_agg_level
      - product_agg_level
  upstream_task_ids:
    - cl_weekly_enrich_create
  downstream_task_ids:
    - cl_weekly_forecast_data_prep_create
  activation_stage: ${oc.select:initial_dag_activation_stage, 0}
```

Steps:

- Since application_args are defined, parameters are available directly.
- Refer to config.yaml under cl_weekly_lag_features:

```
cl_weekly_lag_features:
  forecast_horizon: ${commons.chain_long_term_forecast_horizon}
  period: week
  output_table_name: cl_weekly_lag_features
  ...
```

- Parameters can be overridden if required.
- Run the class in a notebook:

metadata.title: Noob Bootstrap Guide

content:
y_lag_features
  ...
```

- Parameters can be overridden if required.
- Run the class in a notebook:

```
from rocks.noob.enrich import LagFeatures
lag_features = LagFeatures(
    run_date="2024-01-01",
    config_section="cl_weekly_lag_features",
    period="week",
    aggregation_cols=["store_agg_level", "product_agg_level"])

lag_features.run()
```

---

Excluding Bootstrap Tasks

Certain stages require the exclusion of specific tasks from pipelines. To exclude tasks:

1. Navigate to the fabbrica.yaml file in the customer repository.
2. Add the task under the excluded_tasks section of the corresponding DAG.

Example:

```
noob_daily:
  plugin: fabbrica-plugin-invent::noob_daily
  rocks_pipeline:
    excluded_tasks:
      - asp_calculation
      - share_calculation
      - smartlag_features
      - forecast_vectorization
      ...
```

These tasks will be skipped during the DAG execution, ensuring a tailored and accurate bootstrap process.

---

Final Notes

metadata.title: Noob Bootstrap Guide

content:
pped during the DAG execution, ensuring a tailored and accurate bootstrap process.

---

Final Notes

- The Bootstrap DAG is the only interface that project teams should use when onboarding stages.
- Manual execution through notebooks is recommended over Airflow, especially during validation.
- The dag_stage mechanism allows safe, incremental rollouts.
- All configuration should be reviewed in config.yaml, and defaults may be overridden as needed.

metadata.title: Noob Bootstrap Guide

content:
> Note: This document is currently a work in progress and is not yet complete or ready to serve as a reliable guide. It contains only limited personal experience and should not be treated as a comprehensive reference.If you have relevant knowledge or insights, please consider contributing—your input can help improve and expand this resource for everyone.

This guide explains how to securely connect to and interact with the MAPS SQL database using DBeaver for manual access, and Databricks for automated processes. It includes authentication practices, example queries, and helper classes provided internally via the `DatabaseAccess` module.

---

## 1. Requesting Access

Before anything:

- Contact Alpha Team to request database access credentials.

Upon approval, you will receive username and password.

---

## 2. Accessing the Database with DBeaver

You can connect to the SQL Server using DBeaver:

metadata.title: How to Access SQL/MAPS Database

content:
d.

---

## 2. Accessing the Database with DBeaver

You can connect to the SQL Server using DBeaver:

1. Launch DBeaver and click "New Connection".
2. Select SQL Server.
3. Fill in the following (example):Host: 10.244.2.13Port: 1433Database: TeknosaUsername/Password: (from Alpha Team)
4. Click Test Connection and then Finish.

---

## 3. Accessing the Database in Databricks (Basic)

For one-time queries, use the helper function from `warp.spark.database`:

```py
from warp.spark import database as warp_db

db_credentials = {
    "system": "mssql",
    "host": "10.244.2.13",
    "username": "your.username",
    "password": "your.password",
    "engine": "sqlserver",
    "database": "Teknosa",
    "port": "1433",
}

sql_query = "SELECT * FROM Teknosa.[data].InventoryPosition"

df = warp_db.read_from_db(db_credentials, sql_query)
df.show()
```

Replace placeholder credentials before running.

---

## 4. Using DatabaseAccess Class

### Overview

metadata.title: How to Access SQL/MAPS Database

content:
Replace placeholder credentials before running.

---

## 4. Using DatabaseAccess Class

### Overview

For robust pipelines, use the `DatabaseAccess` class which:

- Reads secrets securely from AWS Key Vault
- Provides pre-defined methods for chunked reads/writes
- Supports delta checks, calendar creation, and metadata tracking

### Example Initialization

```py
from rocks.maps.database_access import DatabaseAccess

db = DatabaseAccess(db_name="Teknosa")
```

### Example Queries

Read table:

```py
df = db.read_table("markdown.ItemCostHistory")
```

Read with custom query:

```py
query = "SELECT * FROM markdown.StoreClusterParameters"
df = db.read_query(query)
```

Save data to table:

```py
db.save_table(df, table_name="etl.ProcessedInventory", save_mode="overwrite")
```

Chunked save with transformation:

metadata.title: How to Access SQL/MAPS Database

content:
, table_name="etl.ProcessedInventory", save_mode="overwrite")
```

Chunked save with transformation:

```py
query = "INSERT INTO markdown.FinalInventory SELECT * FROM markdown.FinalInventory_Temp"
db.save_table_in_chunks(df, "markdown.FinalInventory", query=query, chunk_count=3)
```

---

## 5. Advanced Utilities

The `DatabaseAccess` class also includes utilities such as:

- get_latest_data_from_db(): Retrieve the latest rows by partition columns.
- delete_data_within_date_interval(): Delete old data by date range.
- get_calendar(): Generate a custom calendar DataFrame with week/year columns.
- get_delta_rows(): Efficiently detect changes (delta) between two data snapshots.
- is_table_empty(): Check if a table has any rows.
- save_data_transfer_update_ranges(): Log ETL activity with run_id and data dates.

---

## 6. Helper Repository

metadata.title: How to Access SQL/MAPS Database

content:
transfer_update_ranges(): Log ETL activity with run_id and data dates.

---

## 6. Helper Repository

For additional scripts and configurations, refer to the internal helper [repo](https://github.com/inventanalytics/rocks-acme/blob/main/rocks/acme/data_access/database_access.py):

This includes:

- Parameter templates
- Secure credential fetching
- Common SQL snippets

---

## 7. Security Best Practices

- Always use secret drivers for credentials instead of hardcoding.
- Avoid running SELECT * in production.
- Log your ETL updates via save_data_transfer_update_ranges.

metadata.title: How to Access SQL/MAPS Database

content:
## 1. Branch Naming Convention

Create a new branch with a name starting with feature-.

Example:
feature-customername-new-reporting-pipeline

## 2. Update Slack Channel Configuration for CICD Notifications

- Update the Slack notification channel in the following files:

- .cicd/build/Jenkinsfile
- .cicd/airflow/Jenkinsfile
- .cicd/integration/Jenkinsfile

Replace the Slack channel name with your customer-specific channel:

```
slackSend(
    channel: "#customername-cicd",
    color: COLOR_MAP[currentBuild.currentResult],
    message: message
)
```

- In dags/config/main.config, update the Slack channel:

```
global_settings:
  ...
  slack_channel: "#customername-cicd"
```

## 3. Update Email Configuration

Comment out the email: fields in dags/fabbrica.yaml or redirect to your personal or team mail address. ([example](https://github.com/inventanalytics/customer-pipeline-aloyoga/blob/03ca93b584880032e63c57a224ec53201cd88883/dags/fabbrica.yaml#L19))

## 4. Add Workflow Name Suffix

metadata.title: Feature Environment Setup and Best Practices

content:
ob/03ca93b584880032e63c57a224ec53201cd88883/dags/fabbrica.yaml#L19))

## 4. Add Workflow Name Suffix

Ensure the following is present in dags/config/main.yaml:

```
workflow_name_suffix: ${oc.env:ROCKS_ENV,"prod"}
```

This helps isolate environments by creating unique workflow identifiers and prevents cross-environment interference. ([example](https://github.com/inventanalytics/customer-pipeline-aloyoga/blob/03ca93b584880032e63c57a224ec53201cd88883/dags/config/main.yaml#L356))

## 5. Deploy Your New Branch

Once your branch is ready and Jenkins build completes, a dedicated Airflow environment will be deployed.

Accessing the environment:
- New clients: customername-your-branch-name.customertest.airflow.inventanalytics.com
- Old clients: customername-your-branch-name.prod.airflow.inventanalytics.com

## 6. Run Airflow Connection Sync

Run the Airflow-Connection-Sync Jenkins pipeline with appropriate parameters.

metadata.title: Feature Environment Setup and Best Practices

content:
rflow Connection Sync

Run the Airflow-Connection-Sync Jenkins pipeline with appropriate parameters.

[https://jenkins.euwest1.prod.inventanalytics.com/job/pipelines/job/Airflow-Connection-Sync/job/main/](https://jenkins.euwest1.prod.inventanalytics.com/job/pipelines/job/Airflow-Connection-Sync/job/main/)

- Configurations for customers using Azure Storage:

- Configurations for customers using AWS:

## 7. DAG Activation

- Do not activate DAGs unless required for testing.

## 8. Update Secrets and Paths

- Secret Names:
- - Search for cheetah-shu-customername and replace with cheetah-shu-customername-test or -uat

- Storage Paths:
- - Update any hard coded bucket paths to point to the dev/uat bucket.

## 9. Generate ID Tasks

Avoid using generate_id tasks during development and testing in the update_. These tasks create random IDs. If new records are added in both production and test, IDs will diverge.

Instead, prefer using shallow cloning for master data tables.

metadata.title: Feature Environment Setup and Best Practices

content:
roduction and test, IDs will diverge.

Instead, prefer using shallow cloning for master data tables.

Add the shallow_clone task for master tables instead of generate id tasks. ([example extension](https://adb-156147526466559.19.azuredatabricks.net/editor/notebooks/2964296299268390?o=156147526466559#command/8546949836545967))

## 10. Shallow Clone for Preparing Test Storage Environment

Use shallow clone script to prepare the test environment by replicating required data from the production storage environment. ([example shallow clone script](https://adb-156147526466559.19.azuredatabricks.net/editor/notebooks/2964296299268390?o=156147526466559#command/8144179631598489))

## 11. Copy Pokedex

## 11. Copy Pokedex

Some Pokedex values might be missing in the development Pokedex environment. To ensure consistency, these values should be copied from the production Pokedex to the development environment as well. ([example copy pokedex script](https://adb-156147526466559.19.azuredatabricks.net/editor/notebooks/3050256903331814?o=156147526466559#command/4829186572748163))

content:
- Airflow-Connection-Sync pipeline fails due to missing pod access or GitHub token issues:
- When defining connection variables using the Airflow-Connection-Sync pipeline in Jenkins, a hudson.AbortException can occur with a message like No pod found matching 'airflow-scheduler' in namespace.Make sure the correct Kubernetes cluster name is provided (e.g., prod-eu-eks for AWS).Confirm the namespace is correctly set.A common cause of failure is missing GitHub access permissions, which results in errors such as:"Resource not accessible by personal access token".As a temporary workaround, connections can be manually defined until the issue is fixed.Until resolved, the same issue is expected when setting up future feature environments for the academyv2. (related chat)
- Databricks connection error – conn_id 'databricks' isn't defined:

metadata.title: Feature Environment Setup and Best Practices

content:
or the academyv2. (related chat)
- Databricks connection error – conn_id 'databricks' isn't defined:
- This error occurs if the Databricks connection is not properly configured in Airflow.Check whether Step 6 (Run Airflow-Connection-Sync Pipeline) was completed successfully and that the connection was created in the target environment.If the issue persists even after running the sync pipeline, report the problem to the Alpha team for further investigation.
- Aws connection error – conn_id 'aws-euwest1' isn't defined:
- This error occurs if the aws connection is not properly configured in Airflow.Check whether Step 6 (Run Airflow-Connection-Sync Pipeline) was completed successfully and that the connection was created in the target environment.If the issue persists even after running the sync pipeline, report the problem to the Alpha team for further investigation.
- Create Cluster Issue:

metadata.title: Feature Environment Setup and Best Practices

content:
nc pipeline, report the problem to the Alpha team for further investigation.
- Create Cluster Issue:
- When dags needed to create new cluster like rocket_internal_data_update it might get error without any log. This error due to there is no connection between airflow to data-bricks clusters.You need to run Airflow-Connection-Sync job from Jenkins in Step 6.

content:
# Store Rpl Orders Controller Dag

## Purpose

This DAG is used to manage released store replenishment orders based on the released orders by users through the UI. After the user clicks the “Release Order” button, and the system performs the following actions:

1. The Cheetah application writes a csv file to the customer’s Azure or AWS storage under the path: ui-data/released_store_rpl_orders/date=xxxx-xx-xx.

The execution of the DAG starts with the store_rpl_orders_controller, which is triggered by the get_run_input sensor task that monitors the current date folder written by Cheetah:

- The get_run_input sensor task remains in a running state until the current date folder is created.
- Once the folder is written, the sensor is triggered, and the store_rpl_orders_process DAG runs based on the csv files received from the Cheetah.

After the store_rpl_orders_process DAG is triggered:

metadata.title: Released Orders Design Documentation (WIP)

content:
ed on the csv files received from the Cheetah.

After the store_rpl_orders_process DAG is triggered:

- The csv file is moved to the path: ui-data/released_store_rpl_orders/date=xxxx-xx-xx/xxxx.csv.
- The original ui-date/interim_released_store_rpl_orders/date=xxxx-xx-xx/xxxx.csv path is then deleted.

Dag structure might be like in the screenshot:

## Store Replenishment Orders Controller DAG - Task Descriptions

This document provides a detailed explanation of each task within the Store Replenishment Orders Controller DAG, as shown in the diagram.

### 1. run_input_sensor

- Purpose: This sensor task monitors the existence of the necessary input data. It will continue to wait until the required input files are available to trigger the next steps.

### 2. get_first_release

- Purpose: This task retrieves the path to the csv that is released first from the UI. It identifies which csv file will be processed next by getting the folder path from the storage.

metadata.title: Released Orders Design Documentation (WIP)

content:
UI. It identifies which csv file will be processed next by getting the folder path from the storage.

### 3. create_trigger_dag_conf

- Purpose: This task generates the configuration for the DAG that will be triggered next. It prepares the necessary parameters to start the store_rpl_orders_process DAG, ensuring that the correct settings are passed.

### 4. trigger

- Purpose: The trigger task is responsible for launching the store_rpl_orders_process DAG. Once all the required parameters are collected and conditions are met, this task initiates the execution of the send output dag and waits until it success.

### 5. trigger_store_rpl_orders_run_end

- Purpose: This task signifies the end of the store_rpl_orders_process DAG. It ensures the successful completion of the run or marks the termination if any issues arise.

### 6. copy_run_input_to_processed

metadata.title: Released Orders Design Documentation (WIP)

content:
pletion of the run or marks the termination if any issues arise.

### 6. copy_run_input_to_processed

- Purpose: After the run is completed, this task moves the related input data to the “processed” folder, marking the run as successfully processed.

### 8. delete_run_from_queue

- Purpose: This task deletes the folder/file path from the queue (ui-data/released_store_rpl_orders/date=xxxx-xx-xx/xxx.csv) once the run is completed, ensuring that the queue is cleared of processed runs.

### 11. self_trigger

- Purpose: This task is responsible for re-triggering the DAG under certain conditions. It ensures that the DAG can restart or rerun if required by the workflow logic.

# Store Replenishment Orders Process Dag

## Purpose

This dag is getting necessary parameters from controller dag, process related input and write to customer bucket.

## Understand your DAGs

The table above lists all the Airflow DAGs that need to be implemented for each solution. However, for most customers, the implementation will be a combination of the above DAGs. Except for some PoCs and custom implementations, you will almost always implement Core ETL DAGs that validate, enrich, and prepare the data for other DAGs—the tables below list DAGs, their purpose, and how they relate to each of the solutions above.

### 1. Core Data Process and Pre/ETL

These are the first set of DAGs that you should configure for your customer implementation. These DAGs read the data from the customers' buckets/data stores, enforce schemas, and write the partitioned data to the customers’ data. Refer to the page [🏗️ Core Data Processing & ETL Solutions]  for step by step guide on configuring these DAGs for the customer.

### 2. Demand Planning and Forecasting

The Demand Planning DAGs are sometimes also referred to as the Noob DAGs, forecasting, or demand planning DAGs. Please don’t get confused by the names; they are used interchangeably at Invent and with our customers. For these DAGs to function, the [Core Data Process and PRE/ETL](https://invent.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/NE/pages/5244977294/Onboarding+Guide+for+Invent+Solutions+For+Nebula+Team#1.-Core-Data-Process-and-Pre%2FETL) processing DAGs must be implemented first.

## 🚀 Quick Start Implementation Guide

### Phase 1: Preparation (1-2 weeks)

1. Solution Selection - Choose solutions based on customer needs
2. Data Assessment - Verify CSV file availability and quality
3. Environment Setup - Prepare development/staging environments
4. Team Alignment - Assign roles and responsibilities

### Phase 2: Configuration (2-4 weeks)

1. YML Configuration - Update fabbrica.yaml and config files
2. UI Setup - Configure Omega UI screens
3. Pre-ETL Development - Create custom data transformation logic
4. DAG Activation - Enable required DAGs, disable unused ones

metadata.title: Onboarding Guide for Invent Solutions For Nebula Team

content:
reate custom data transformation logic
4. DAG Activation - Enable required DAGs, disable unused ones

### Phase 3: Testing & Validation (1-2 weeks)

1. Integration Testing - Verify end-to-end data flow
2. User Acceptance Testing - Validate UI functionality
3. Performance Testing - Ensure scalability requirements
4. Go-Live Preparation - Final checks and deployment

## 📋 Common Resources

### Standard Configuration Files

- fabbrica.yaml - Main DAG configuration
- config.yaml - OPAL data mapping configuration
- config_metadata.yml - Data validation rules
- omega_ui/config.yml - UI screen definitions

### Core CSV Files (Required for All Solutions)

- product.csv - Master product data
- store.csv - Store master data
- warehouse.csv - Warehouse/DC data
- supplier.csv - Supplier information
- inventory.csv - Current inventory levels

### Common Troubleshooting

metadata.title: Onboarding Guide for Invent Solutions For Nebula Team

content:
er.csv - Supplier information
- inventory.csv - Current inventory levels

### Common Troubleshooting

- DAG Not Appearing: Check is_skipped_dag: false in fabbrica.yaml
- CSV Import Errors: Verify file encoding (UTF-8) and delimiter (comma)
- UI Screens Missing: Confirm omega_ui configuration and deployment
- Data Quality Issues: Check pre_etl validations and data_quality_checks

## 🔗 Technical Resources

### Key Repositories

- Main Pipeline: airflow-fabbrica-plugin-invent/
- UI Components: rocks-rocket/rocks/rocket/omega_ui/
- Customer Configs: customer-pipeline-{customer}/

### Development Standards

- Naming Convention: Follow existing customer-pipeline-{name} pattern
- Code Review: All YML changes require peer review
- Testing: Mandatory integration testing before production
- Documentation: Update the solution guide with customer-specific details

ividual Solution Documentation

2. ✅ Definition of Ready - Prerequisites and readiness criteria
3. ☑️ Definition of Done - Completion and validation checklist

5. ⚙️ Configuration Requirements - YML, UI, and system setup
6. 🔄 Technical Details - Data flow diagrams and ERDs
7. 🛠️ Debugging Tips - Common issues and solutions
8. 🔗 Code References - Links to relevant repositories

> 📞 Need Help?Contact the Nebula Team for technical assistance or the Delivery team for implementation guidance.

metadata.title: Onboarding Guide for Invent Solutions For Nebula Team

content:
*This customer onboarding template is owned and maintained by the Nebula team.*

---

📝 1. SummaryMerchandise Financial Planning (MFP) is a strategic process used primarily in retail to plan and control the investment in merchandise (products) to maximize profitability, align with business goals, and meet customer demand. It answers *what to buy*, *how much to invest*, *when to buy*, and *how much revenue/profit to expect*—before specific products are even selected.

### ✅ Key Components of MFP:

1. Sales Plan – How much do we plan to sell overall?
2. Margin Plan – What profit margins are targeted?
3. Inventory Plan – How much inventory investment is needed?
4. Open-to-Buy (OTB) – How much can we still spend on buying stock?
5. Markdown/Discount Plan – Planned reductions to clear stock.

### 🧵 Example: Apparel Retailer

Let’s take a chain of women’s clothing stores planning for Fall-Winter 2025.

#### Merchandise Financial Planning

metadata.title: Merchandise Financial Planning

content:
chain of women’s clothing stores planning for Fall-Winter 2025.

#### Merchandise Financial Planning

At the *season start*, the planners make a top-down plan:

- Sales goal: €10 million
- Margin goal: 55%
- Inventory budget: €4 million
- Markdown target: €1 million
- Top categories: Outerwear (40%), Dresses (30%), Knitwear (30%)

They *allocate budgets* to categories and channels (e.g. online vs physical store) months before orders are placed.

#### Forecasting and Replenishment

Once the season begins and actual sales data flows in:

- Forecasting predicts future demand based on recent sales, weather, promotions, etc.For example, if puffers are selling faster than expected, forecasted demand may rise.
- Replenishment is the tactical response:Automatically reordering sizes or styles if inventory falls below threshold.E.g., Reordering more size M black puffers if it’s a bestseller.

---

### 🔍 MFP vs Forecasting & Replenishment

metadata.title: Merchandise Financial Planning

content:
ering more size M black puffers if it’s a bestseller.

---

### 🔍 MFP vs Forecasting & Replenishment

| Aspect | Merchandise Financial Planning (MFP) | Forecasting & Replenishment |
| --- | --- | --- |
| Focus | Strategic, pre-season financial planning | In-season operational execution |
| Timeframe | Pre-season (months ahead) | In-season (real-time or near-term) |
| Objective | Align investment with financial goals | Meet real-time demand and avoid stockouts |
| Granularity | High-level (category, region, channel) | SKU-level or store-level |
| Inputs | Historic data, growth targets, financial KPIs | POS data, weather, events, trends |
| Output | Category budgets, profit targets | SKU replenishment orders, updated forecasts |
| Tooling | Planning systems (e.g., Oracle RPAS, Anaplan, Invent MFP) | Demand forecasting engines, auto-replenishment tools NOOB + Rocket |

---

### 👥 How They Work Together

metadata.title: Merchandise Financial Planning

content:
and forecasting engines, auto-replenishment tools NOOB + Rocket |

---

### 👥 How They Work Together

MFP sets the boundaries and goals. Forecasting & replenishment helps execute within those boundaries.

For instance, if MFP allocates €1.2M for dresses, and red midi dresses are overperforming, forecasting can suggest more replenishment—but the buyer must stay within the MFP budget unless re-forecasting is approved.

---

## 📋 Quick Configuration & Implementation Summary

### ⚡ Implementation Steps Overview

Step 1: Data Preparation

1. Set up Database Schema - Create initial allocation tables and procedures
2. Prepare Allocation Data - Season buy, store clustering, product-store pairs
3. Configure R/Python Environment - Allocation algorithm processing setup
4. Validate Business Rules - Season planning and allocation constraints

Step 2: Allocation Configuration

1. Configure Season Management - Set up active seasons and product arrivals
2. Set up Store Clustering - Configure store segmentation and targeting
3. Generate Allocation Pairs - Create initial allocation store-product combinations
4. Configure Business Rules - Allocation constraints, budgets, size curves

Step 3: Testing & Validation

onfigure Business Rules - Allocation constraints, budgets, size curves

1. Execute allocation runs - Verify allocation calculations and season buy distribution
2. Validate allocation logic - Check store targets, quantities, and constraints
3. Test UI functionality - Ensure allocation review and approval workflows work
4. Performance testing - Ensure allocation processing times meet requirements

Step 4: Go-Live

1. Production deployment - Enable initial allocation processes for active seasons
2. Monitor allocation performance - Set up tracking for allocation effectiveness
3. Documentation handover - Initial allocation procedures and season planning
4. User training - Train merchandising and planning teams on allocation workflows

## 📋 Complete Solution Documentation

### Solution Overview

Initial Allocation Solution optimizes the initial distribution of new products from warehouses to stores based on demand forecasts, store attributes, and business constraints to maximize sales potential. The solution uses advanced store clustering algorithms and demand modeling to determine the optimal stores for new product placement and calculate appropriate quantities for each location. This ensures new products reach the right customers at launch while minimizing initial allocation adjustments.

Business Value:

- 40-50% improvement in new product sell-through rates
- 35-45% reduction in initial allocation adjustments needed
- 20-30% increase in full-price sales for new products
- 25-35% improvement in overall inventory efficiency for new launches

## ⚙️ Configuration Requirements

### 1. Database Schema Setup

#### Initial Allocation Tables:

```
-- Active Seasons
CREATE TABLE [initialallocation].[ActiveSeasons] (
    [SeasonId] SMALLINT NOT NULL,
    CONSTRAINT [PK_IAActiveSeasons] PRIMARY KEY CLUSTERED ([SeasonId] ASC),
    CONSTRAINT [FK_IAActiveSeasons_Seasons]
        FOREIGN KEY ([SeasonId]) REFERENCES [model].[Seasons] ([SeasonId])
);

metadata.title: 📦 Solution 24: Initial Allocation - Configuration Guide

content:
ActiveSeasons_Seasons]
        FOREIGN KEY ([SeasonId]) REFERENCES [model].[Seasons] ([SeasonId])
);

-- Season Product Groups
CREATE TABLE [initialallocation].[GenericRunSeasonProductGroups] (
    [RunId] INT NOT NULL,
    [SeasonId] TINYINT NOT NULL,
    [ProductGroup] [sys].[hierarchyid] NOT NULL,
    CONSTRAINT [PK_GenericRunSeasonProductGroups]
        PRIMARY KEY ([ProductGroup], [RunId], [SeasonId])
);

-- Allocation Pairs
CREATE TABLE [initialallocation].[AllocationPairs] (
    [ProductId] NVARCHAR(50) NOT NULL,
    [StoreId] NVARCHAR(50) NOT NULL,
    [SeasonId] SMALLINT NOT NULL,
    [TargetQuantity] INT,
    [AllocatedQuantity] INT,
    [Status] NVARCHAR(20),
    [CreatedDate] DATETIME2 DEFAULT GETDATE()
);

```

))

                              ReleaseDate,

#### Allocation-Specific Files:

- ia_pairs.csv - Initial allocation store-product pairs
- ia_target_dates.csv - Target dates for product delivery
- season_buy.csv - Season buy quantities by warehouse
- season_dates_ia.csv - Season start/end dates per store
- size_family.csv - Product size groupings
- seasoncode.csv - Product-season mappings
- store_clusters.csv - Store clustering definitions
- allocation_constraints.csv - Business rules and limits

## 🐛 Debugging & Troubleshooting

### Common Issues & Solutions

#### 1. Missing Store-Product Pairs

```
# Debug pair generation
ia_pairs_debug <- sqlQuery(
  rds_connection,
  "SELECT ProductId, StoreId, COUNT(*) as pair_count
   FROM InitialAllocationCustomerPairs
   GROUP BY ProductId, StoreId
   HAVING COUNT(*) > 1"
)

```

#### 2. Season Buy Allocation Issues

metadata.title: 📦 Solution 24: Initial Allocation - Configuration Guide

content:
GROUP BY ProductId, StoreId
   HAVING COUNT(*) > 1"
)

```

#### 2. Season Buy Allocation Issues

```
# Validate season buy totals
def validate_season_buy(season_buy_data, allocations):
    buy_total = season_buy_data.groupby('product_id')['quantity'].sum()
    alloc_total = allocations.groupby('product_id')['quantity'].sum()
    discrepancies = buy_total.compare(alloc_total)
    return discrepancies

```

#### 3. Store Clustering Problems

```
# Validate store clustering
check_cluster_balance <- function(store_data) {
  cluster_summary <- store_data[, .(
    store_count = .N,
    avg_sales = mean(sales),
    avg_size = mean(store_size)
  ), by = cluster]
  return(cluster_summary)
}

```

#### 4. UI Data Sync Issues

```
-- Check allocation data freshness
SELECT
    season_id,
    COUNT(*) as allocation_count,
    MAX(created_date) as last_update
FROM initialallocation.AllocationPairs
GROUP BY season_id
ORDER BY season_id DESC;

```

### 🔧 Essential Configuration Checklist

#### Required DAGs to Enable:

```
noob_bootstrap: {is_skipped_dag: false}      # One-time setup
noob_etl: {is_skipped_dag: false}           # Daily processing
noob_daily: {is_skipped_dag: false}         # Daily forecasts
noob_weekly: {is_skipped_dag: false}        # Weekly aggregation

```

#### Required CSV Files:

- ✅ transactional_sales.csv - Historical sales (104+ weeks)
- ✅ inventory.csv - Current/historical inventory levels
- ✅ product.csv - Product master with hierarchies
- ✅ store.csv - Store master data
- ✅ scope.csv - Solution scope (solution_id=11)

#### UI Screens to Configure:

- forecast_edit - Interactive forecast editing
- forecast_review - Historical vs. predicted analysis

metadata.title: 🔮 Solution 11: Demand Planning - Configuration Guide

content:
recast editing
- forecast_review - Historical vs. predicted analysis

### 🚨 Critical Success Factors

- Data Quality: Minimum 104 weeks of continuous sales history
- User Adoption: Train business users on UI functionality

---

## 📋Solution Overview

Demand Planning provides AI-powered forecasting capabilities to predict future product demand across different time horizons and granularities. This solution utilizes advanced machine learning models (NOOB - Neural Optimization of Business) to generate accurate demand forecasts that consider seasonality, trends, promotions, and other business factors. The solution supports both short-term (daily and weekly) and long-term (monthly and quarterly) forecasting, enabling better inventory planning, informed procurement decisions, and effective business strategy.

Business Value: Reduces stockouts by 15-25%, improves inventory turnover by 10-20%, and increases forecast accuracy by 20-35% compared to traditional statistical methods.

metadata.title: 🔮 Solution 11: Demand Planning - Configuration Guide

content:
er by 10-20%, and increases forecast accuracy by 20-35% compared to traditional statistical methods.

## ✅ Definition of Ready

Prerequisites before configuration can begin:

☑️ Data Requirements:

- Historical Sales Data: Minimum 104 weeks (2 years) of transactional sales history
- Product Master Data: Complete product catalog with hierarchies
- Store Master Data: Store information with operational status
- Inventory Data: Current and historical inventory levels
- Promotion Data: Historical promotional activities (if applicable)

☑️ Infrastructure Requirements:

- EMR Clusters: Development and production environments configured
- S3 Buckets: Datastore buckets with appropriate permissions
- Airflow Environment: DAG deployment capabilities
- Database Access: Read/write permissions for forecast tables

☑️ Business Requirements:

metadata.title: 🔮 Solution 11: Demand Planning - Configuration Guide

content:
apabilities
- Database Access: Read/write permissions for forecast tables

☑️ Business Requirements:

- Forecast Granularity: Store-Product level granularity confirmed
- Forecast Horizon: Business requirements for forecast periods (4-26 weeks)
- Update Frequency: Agreement on daily, weekly, or monthly refreshes
- Business Calendar: Holiday calendar and seasonal patterns identified

## ☑️ Definition of Done

Completion checklist for successful deployment:

✅ Technical Validation:

- [ ] All NOOB DAGs running successfully without errors
- [ ] Forecast data populating in target tables
- [ ] Data quality checks passing (>95% success rate)
- [ ] EMR clusters auto-scaling properly
- [ ] Forecast accuracy metrics meeting baseline requirements (>70% MAPE)

✅ Functional Validation:

metadata.title: 🔮 Solution 11: Demand Planning - Configuration Guide

content:
- [ ] Forecast accuracy metrics meeting baseline requirements (>70% MAPE)

✅ Functional Validation:

- [ ] Forecast Edit UI screens functional and accessible
- [ ] Forecast Review UI showing historical vs. predicted comparisons
- [ ] User permissions configured correctly
- [ ] Forecast export functionality working
- [ ] Business users trained on UI navigation

✅ Performance Validation:

- [ ] DAG execution times within SLA (<4 hours for weekly runs)

### Data Flow Architecture

```

    ├── Feature Engineering

    ↓
📊 Forecast Selection & Optimization
    ↓

    ├── Forecast Review
    └── Accuracy Reports

```

### Machine Learning Models

1. XGBoost Regressors: Short-term demand patterns
2. Prophet Models: Seasonality and trend analysis
3. LLTD Models: Linear long-term demand forecasting
4. Ensemble Selection: Automatic model selection based on accuracy

## 🛠️ Debugging Tips

### Common Issues & Solutions

❌ NOOB DAGs Failing:

- Check EMR cluster capacity and auto-scaling settings
- Verify NOOB_CONFIG_PATH environment variable
- Review feature engineering logs for data quality issues
- Ensure sufficient historical data (104+ weeks minimum)

❌ Poor Forecast Accuracy:

- Review promotional data quality and encoding
- Check for data gaps or outliers in sales history
- Verify product hierarchy consistency
- Consider adjusting model hyperparameters

❌ UI Screens Not Loading:

metadata.title: 🔮 Solution 11: Demand Planning - Configuration Guide

content:
product hierarchy consistency
- Consider adjusting model hyperparameters

❌ UI Screens Not Loading:

- Confirm forecast tables are populated
- Check user permissions for forecast_edit/review tables
- Verify omega_ui configuration deployment
- Review BigQuery dataset access permissions

❌ Performance Issues:

- Monitor EMR cluster utilization
- Check for data skew in product-store combinations
- Optimize partition strategies for large datasets
- Review model training frequencies

### Monitoring & Alerting

- Forecast Accuracy: Monitor MAPE, RMSE metrics
- Data Freshness: Alert on stale input data
- DAG Runtime: Monitor execution times and failures
- UI Usage: Track user adoption and screen performance

## 📋 Complete Solution Documentation

### Solution Overview

Store & DC Replenishment Solutions automate the optimization of inventory replenishment orders to maintain optimal stock levels while minimizing costs and stockouts. Solution 21 (Store Replenishment) optimizes orders from warehouses/DCs to stores, while Solution 22 (DC Replenishment) optimizes orders from suppliers to distribution centers. Both solutions use advanced mathematical optimization algorithms to balance service levels, inventory costs, and operational constraints.

Business Value:

algorithms to balance service levels, inventory costs, and operational constraints.

Business Value:

- 15-25% reduction in inventory holding costs
- 95%+ service level achievement with optimized safety stocks
- 80% reduction in manual order planning effort
- Real-time optimization with constraint-based business rules

## 🔄 Technical Details

### Replenishment Data Flow Architecture

```
📁 Core ETL Data
    ↓
🔄 Data Partitioning
    ├── Product-Store Combinations
    ├── Inventory Calculations
    └── Lead Time Validations
    ↓
🧮 Optimization Engine
    ├── Demand Forecasting
    ├── Safety Stock Calculation
    ├── Order Quantity Optimization
    └── Constraint Application
    ↓
📊 Order Generation
    ├── Store Replenishment Orders
    ├── DC Replenishment Orders
    └── Exception Alerts
    ↓
🖥️ UI Data Preparation
    ├── Order Review Screens
    ├── Inventory Dashboards
    └── KPI Monitoring

```

### Optimization Algorithm Steps

metadata.title: 🏪🏭 Solutions 21 & 22: Store & DC Replenishment

content:
w Screens
    ├── Inventory Dashboards
    └── KPI Monitoring

```

### Optimization Algorithm Steps

1. Demand Calculation: Historical sales + forecast + trend analysis
2. Safety Stock Calculation: Service level-based safety stock requirements
3. Target Inventory: Demand + safety stock + lead time coverage
4. Need Calculation: Target inventory - current inventory - in-transit
5. Constraint Application: Lead times, case packs, capacity, business rules
6. Order Optimization: Minimize costs while meeting service levels
7. Output Generation: Executable orders with alerts for exceptions

### Key Database Tables & Relationships

Optimization Input Tables:

- inventory / inventory_warehouse ← Current stock levels
- transactional_sales ← Historical demand patterns
- lead_time ← Supplier and warehouse lead times

## 🛠️ Debugging Tips

### Common Issues & Solutions

❌ Optimization Performance Issues:

- Check EMR cluster sizing (increase to r5.8xlarge for large scope)
- Verify data partitioning is working correctly
- Monitor partition count (target 100-500 partitions)
- Check for data skew in large product/store combinations

❌ Order Generation Problems:

- Verify lead time data is complete and accurate
- Check case pack quantity configurations
- Validate service level settings are reasonable (85-99%)
- Review constraint configurations for conflicts

❌ Service Level Achievement Issues:

metadata.title: 🏪🏭 Solutions 21 & 22: Store & DC Replenishment

content:
nable (85-99%)
- Review constraint configurations for conflicts

❌ Service Level Achievement Issues:

- Check safety stock calculation parameters
- Verify demand forecast accuracy
- Review lead time variability settings
- Validate inventory data accuracy and freshness

❌ UI Data Issues:

- Ensure omega_ui_daily DAG is running successfully
- Check UI table partitioning and storage formats
- Verify API endpoint configurations
- Monitor UI data refresh frequency

❌ Business Rule Violations:

- Review constraint configurations in prep config
- Check for conflicting business rules
- Validate order schedule and frequency settings
- Monitor alert generation for business rule exceptions

### Performance Monitoring & Optimization

metadata.title: 🏪🏭 Solutions 21 & 22: Store & DC Replenishment

content:
s
- Monitor alert generation for business rule exceptions

### Performance Monitoring & Optimization

- Optimization Runtime: Target <4 hours for large scope, <1 hour for typical scope
- Service Level Achievement: Monitor actual vs target service levels
- Order Accuracy: Track order execution rates and adjustments
- Data Quality: Monitor inventory accuracy and lead time compliance

#### Data Quality Requirements:

- File Format: UTF-8 encoding, comma-delimited, header row required
- Data Completeness: >98% for inventory and sales data, >95% for constraint data
- Data Accuracy: Valid lead times (1-365 days), reasonable service levels (85-99%)
- Data Consistency: Referential integrity between products, stores, warehouses
- Historical Depth: Minimum 52 weeks of sales and inventory history

### ⚡ Implementation Steps Overview

Step 1: Infrastructure Setup

1. Configure EMR Clusters - Transfer optimization clusters (r5.2xlarge, 2-6 nodes)
2. Set up Transfer ETL - Validate transfer-specific CSV files and data feeds
3. Configure Transfer Maps Database - Set up transfer schema and tables
4. Prepare Transfer Data - Store distances, transfer constraints, historical data

Step 2: Transfer Configuration

1. Update fabbrica.yaml - Enable transfer_etl and transfer_daily DAGs
2. Configure Transfer Rules - Set up business constraints and optimization parameters
3. Set up Transfer UI Screens - Configure transfer decision review and monitoring
4. Deploy transfer configurations to Airflow and test optimization

3. Test UI functionality - Ensure transfer decision workflows and approvals work
4. Performance testing - Ensure transfer optimization times meet SLA (<3 hours)

Step 4: Go-Live

1. Production deployment - Enable scheduled transfer optimization runs
2. Monitor transfer decisions - Set up alerts for optimization failures
3. Documentation handover - Transfer procedures and troubleshooting guides

## 📋 Complete Solution Documentation

### Solution Overview

Store-to-Store Transfer Solution optimizes inventory distribution between stores by calculating optimal transfer quantities and timing to minimize stockouts and maximize sales performance. The solution identifies inventory imbalances across the store network and recommends transfers from stores with excess inventory to stores with higher demand potential. Advanced algorithms consider store distances, transfer costs, lead times, seasonality patterns, and business constraints to generate cost-effective transfer recommendations.

Business Value:

- 30-40% reduction in stockouts across store network
- 25-35% improvement in inventory turns through better distribution
- 15-20% increase in sales through improved product availability
- 10-15% reduction in markdown losses from overstocked locations

Prerequisites before configuration can begin:

☑️ Data Requirements:

- Complete CSV File Set: All universal files + transfer-specific files validated
- Store Distance Matrix: Accurate distances between all store pairs
- Historical Transfer Data: Past transfer decisions and performance metrics
- Inventory Positions: Real-time store inventory levels and accuracy
- Business Constraints: Transfer cost structures, distance limits, seasonal restrictions

☑️ Infrastructure Requirements:

- EMR Clusters: Development and production environments ready (r5.2xlarge+)
- Maps Database: Transfer schema created with proper permissions
- Core ETL Completed: All universal data tables processed and validated
- UI Environment: Transfer decision screens configured

#### Transfer fabbrica.yaml:

```
transfer_etl:
  plugin: fabbrica-plugin-invent::transfer_etl
  rocks_pipeline:
    tasks:
      inventory_position:
        module: rocks.acme.transfer.inventory_position
        class: InventoryPosition
      store_distances:
        module: rocks.acme.transfer.store_distances
        class: StoreDistances
      store_transfer_decisions:
        module: rocks.acme.transfer.store_transfer_decisions
        class: StoreTransferDecisions
      product_agg_level:
        module: rocks.acme.transfer.product_agg_level
        class: ProductAggLevel
      store_agg_level:
        module: rocks.acme.transfer.store_agg_level
        class: StoreAggLevel
      price_history:
        module: rocks.acme.transfer.price_history
        class: PriceHistory
      cost_history:
        module: rocks.acme.transfer.cost_history
        class: CostHistory
      season_history:
        module: rocks.acme.transfer.season_history
        class: SeasonHistory

metadata.title: 🔄 Solution 23: Store-to-Store Transfer - Configuration Guide

content:
season_history:
        module: rocks.acme.transfer.season_history
        class: SeasonHistory

transfer_daily:
  plugin: fabbrica-plugin-invent::transfer_daily
  rocks_pipeline:
    default:
      application_args:
        run_date: ${jinja.run_date_daily}
        run_id: ${jinja.maps_etl_run_id}
    tasks:
      forecast_to_db:
        module: rocks.acme.transfer.forecasts
        class: SaveForecasts

```

    enabled: True
    partitioned: False

  id_conversions:
    - product
  overwrite:
    enabled: True
    partitioned: False

#### Omega UI Screens:

```

  trigger_args:
    conf:
      screens:
        - transfer_decisions
        - transfer_monitoring
        - transfer_performance
      transfer_run_id: ${jinja.transfer_run_id}
  upstream_task_ids:
    - wait_transfer_daily

```

#### Transfer-Specific Files:

content:

### 4. CSV File Requirements

#### Transfer-Specific Files:

- store_transfer_decisions.csv - Historical transfer decisions and performance
- store_distances.csv - Distance matrix between all store pairs
- transfer_lead_time.csv - Lead times for store-to-store transfers
- transfer_costs.csv - Cost structures for transfers by distance/region

#### Business Constraints Configuration:

```
transfer_constraints:
  min_transfer_quantity: 1
  max_transfer_distance_km: 500
  transfer_cost_threshold: 0.10  # 10% of product cost
  seasonal_restrictions:
    enabled: True
    blocked_periods:
      - start: "2024-11-15"
        end: "2024-12-31"
        reason: "Holiday season restrictions"

```

## 🐛 Debugging & Troubleshooting

### Common Issues & Solutions

#### 1. Transfer ETL Failures

```
# Check transfer ETL logs
grep "TRANSFER_ETL_ERROR" /var/log/airflow/dags/transfer_etl/*.log

metadata.title: 🔄 Solution 23: Store-to-Store Transfer - Configuration Guide

content:
es

```
# Check transfer ETL logs
grep "TRANSFER_ETL_ERROR" /var/log/airflow/dags/transfer_etl/*.log

# Validate transfer CSV files
python validate_transfer_csvs.py --date 2024-01-15

```

#### 2. Store Distance Issues

```
-- Verify store distance data
SELECT COUNT(*) as total_pairs,
       AVG(distance_km) as avg_distance,
       MAX(distance_km) as max_distance
FROM maps.store_distances
WHERE distance_km > 0;

```

#### 3. Transfer Optimization Timeouts

```
# Monitor EMR cluster performance for transfer optimization
aws emr describe-cluster --cluster-id j-XXXXXXXXXXXXX
aws cloudwatch get-metric-statistics --namespace AWS/EMR

```

#### 4. UI Transfer Data Issues

```
-- Check transfer decisions data freshness
SELECT run_id, COUNT(*) as decision_count,
       MAX(created_date) as last_update
FROM transfer.StoreTransferDecisions
WHERE run_date >= DATEADD(day, -7, GETDATE())
GROUP BY run_id ORDER BY last_update DESC;

```

## 📋 Quick Configuration & Implementation Summary

### ⚡ Implementation Steps Overview

Step 1: ETL Configuration

1. Update fabbrica.yaml - Enable core ETL DAGs
2. Configure OPAL config.yaml - CSV file paths and transformations
3. Set up data validation rules - Data quality checks and constraints
4. Deploy ETL configurations to Airflow

Step 2: Testing & Validation

1. Execute pre_etl validation - Verify all CSV files load correctly
2. Run data migration - Initial data processing
3. Validate data quality - Check completeness and accuracy
4. Performance testing - Ensure processing times meet SLA

### 🔧 Essential Configuration Checklist

#### Required DAGs to Enable:

#### Required CSV Files (22 Universal Files):

- ✅ Master Data (5 files): product.csv, store.csv, warehouse.csv, supplier.csv, season.csv
- ✅ Operational Data (8 files): inventory.csv, inventory_warehouse.csv, transactional_sales.csv, purchase_order.csv, goods_in_transit.csv, open_orders.csv, goods_on_hold.csv, lead_time.csv
- ✅ Pricing & Promotion (4 files): price.csv, cost.csv, currency.csv, promotion.csv
- ✅ Configuration & Rules (5 files): uda.csv, scope.csv, product_uda.csv, store_activity_calendar.csv, order_schedule.csv

### 🚨 Critical Success Factors

- Data Quality: >95% completeness for all required fields
- File Formats: UTF-8 encoding, pipe-delimited, proper headers
- Data Freshness: Regular refresh cycles (daily/weekly)
- Performance: ETL processing within 2-hour SLA

## 📋 Solution Documentation

### Solution Overview

Core Data Processing & ETL forms the foundation of all Invent solutions by ingesting, validating, and transforming raw business data into standardized formats. This solution handles data preprocessing, quality validation, migration, and synchronization across all customer systems. It ensures data consistency, integrity, and availability for downstream analytics and optimization solutions.

Business Value: Ensures 99.9% data accuracy, reduces data preparation time by 80%, and provides a reliable foundation for all advanced analytics and optimization solutions.

## ✅ Definition of Ready

Prerequisites before configuration can begin:

☑️ Data Requirements:

ons.

## ✅ Definition of Ready

Prerequisites before configuration can begin:

☑️ Data Requirements:

- Complete CSV File Set: All 22 universal files with proper schemas
- Data Quality Standards: Defined validation rules and acceptance criteria
- Historical Data: Minimum data history requirements for each file type
- Data Sources: Identified and accessible source systems

☑️ Infrastructure Requirements:

- S3 Buckets: Configured with appropriate permissions and lifecycle policies
- EMR Clusters: Development and production environments ready
- Airflow Environment: DAG deployment capabilities configured
- Database Access: Read/write permissions for target tables

☑️ Business Requirements:

- Data Refresh Frequency: Agreement on update schedules (daily/weekly)
- Data Retention Policies: Historical data storage and archival rules
- Quality Thresholds: Acceptable data quality metrics and SLAs
- Business Rules: Custom validation and transformation requirements

## ☑️ Definition of Done

d SLAs
- Business Rules: Custom validation and transformation requirements

## ☑️ Definition of Done

Completion checklist for successful deployment:

✅ Technical Validation:

- [ ] All core ETL DAGs are running successfully without errors
- [ ] Data quality checks passing (>95% success rate)
- [ ] All 22 CSV files are loading and validating correctly
- [ ] Database tables populated with clean, standardized data
- [ ] EMR clusters are auto-scaling properly for data volumes

✅ Functional Validation:

- [ ] Data freshness monitoring is working correctly
- [ ] Error alerts and notifications are configured
- [ ] Data lineage tracking operational
- [ ] Incremental data processing working
- [ ] Data validation reports are generating correctly

✅ Performance Validation:

- [ ] ETL processing times within SLA (<2 hours for full refresh)
- [ ] Data validation performance acceptable
- [ ] Storage costs within budget
- [ ] Query performance on processed tables optimized

metadata.title: 🏗️ Core Data Processing & ETL Solutions
