e acceptable
- [ ] Storage costs within budget
- [ ] Query performance on processed tables optimized

✅ Documentation & Handover:

- [ ] ETL configuration documentation updated
- [ ] Data dictionary and schema documentation complete
- [ ] Support procedures documented
- [ ] Monitoring and alerting procedures established

## 🔧 Components Involved

### Primary DAGs & Dependencies

| DAG Name | Purpose | Frequency | Dependencies |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| pre_etl | Data preprocessing and validation | Daily | Raw CSV files availability |
| migrate_data_req | Data migration requirements | Weekly | Pre-ETL completion |
| update_datastore | Datastore updates and sync | Daily | New data availability |
| maps_etl | Maps system ETL processing | Daily (If needed) | Maps data sources |
| transfer_etl | Transfer data processing | Daily (If needed) | Transfer configuration files |

### Database Tables

metadata.title: 🏗️ Core Data Processing & ETL Solutions

content:
| Transfer data processing | Daily (If needed) | Transfer configuration files |

### Database Tables

- Raw Tables: Direct CSV ingestion tables with minimal transformation
- Staging Tables: Intermediate tables for data validation and cleaning
- Clean Tables: Fully validated and standardized tables for downstream use
- Audit Tables: Data lineage, quality metrics, and processing logs

## ⚙️ Configuration Requirements

### 1. YML Configuration Files

#### fabbrica.yaml Updates:

```
# Enable Core ETL DAGs
pre_etl:
  plugin: fabbrica-plugin-invent::pre_etl
  is_skipped_dag: false

migrate_data_req:
  plugin: fabbrica-plugin-invent::migrate_data_req
  is_skipped_dag: false

update_datastore:
  plugin: fabbrica-plugin-invent::update_datastore
  is_skipped_dag: false

# Optional ETL DAGs (enable as needed)
maps_etl:
  plugin: fabbrica-plugin-invent::maps_etl
  is_skipped_dag: true  # Enable only if Maps solution is used

metadata.title: 🏗️ Core Data Processing & ETL Solutions

content:
gin: fabbrica-plugin-invent::maps_etl
  is_skipped_dag: true  # Enable only if Maps solution is used

transfer_etl:
  plugin: fabbrica-plugin-invent::transfer_etl
  is_skipped_dag: true  # Enable only if Transfer solution is used

```

#### OPAL Configuration (config.yaml):

```
# Core configuration for CSV file processing
customer_name: {customer_name}
file_schema: s3://
bucket_name: ${oc.env:DATASTORE_BUCKET_NAME}
week_start_day: 7

commons:
  product:
    raw: ${raw_data_path}product.csv
    is_required: True

  store:
    raw: ${raw_data_path}store.csv
    is_required: True

  warehouse:
    raw: ${raw_data_path}warehouse.csv
    is_required: True

  # ... additional file configurations

```

### 2. Data Validation Configuration

#### Data Quality Rules (customer-pipeline-{customer}/scripts/opal/config.yaml):

metadata.title: 🏗️ Core Data Processing & ETL Solutions

content:
tion Configuration

#### Data Quality Rules (customer-pipeline-{customer}/scripts/opal/config.yaml):

```
# Data quality validation rules
data_quality_checks:
  completeness_threshold: 0.95
  accuracy_threshold: 0.99
  consistency_checks: true
  duplicate_detection: true
  outlier_detection: true

```

### 3. Data Loading Strategy Configuration

#### Overwrite vs Append Mode Settings (customer-pipeline-{customer}/scripts/opal/config.yaml):

Configure how operational data should be loaded - either overwrite existing data completely or append new records to existing data.

```
# Data loading strategy configuration
data_loading_strategy:
  # Default strategy (can be overridden per table)
  default_mode: "append"  # Options: "append" | "overwrite" | "upsert"

  # Table-specific overrides
  table_overrides:
    transactional_sales:
      mode: "overwrite"
      partition_strategy: "by_date"
      retention_days: 1095  # Keep 3 years of data

metadata.title: 🏗️ Core Data Processing & ETL Solutions

content:
: "overwrite"
      partition_strategy: "by_date"
      retention_days: 1095  # Keep 3 years of data

    inventory:
      mode: "overwrite"
      backup_before_overwrite: true
      validation_required: true

    inventory_warehouse:
      mode: "overwrite"
      partition_strategy: "by_warehouse_date"

    purchase_order:
      mode: "upsert"  # Update existing, insert new
      key_columns: ["po_id", "supplier_id"]

    goods_in_transit:
      mode: "overwrite"
      archive_previous: true

    open_orders:
      mode: "overwrite"  # Orders change frequently

    goods_on_hold:
      mode: "overwrite"
      cleanup_released_holds: true

# Backup and safety configurations
backup_config:
  enable_pre_overwrite_backup: true
  backup_retention_days: 30
  backup_location: "${backup_bucket}/pre_overwrite_backups/"

ackup: true
  backup_retention_days: 30
  backup_location: "${backup_bucket}/pre_overwrite_backups/"

# Validation settings for overwrite operations
overwrite_validation:
  require_confirmation: true
  min_record_count_threshold: 1000  # Fail if less than expected
  max_variance_percent: 20  # Fail if >20% change in record count
  enable_data_quality_checks: true

```

commons:

    partition_column: "date"
    retention_policy: "3_years"

sting: True   # Backup before overwrite
    partition_column: "date"

#### Safety Mechanisms for Overwrite Operations (customer-pipeline-{customer}/scripts/opal/config.yaml):

```
# Safety configurations to prevent data loss
safety_mechanisms:
  # Automatic backup before overwrite
  auto_backup:
    enabled: true
    backup_tables: ["transactional_sales", "inventory", "inventory_warehouse"]
    retention_days: 30

content:
backup_tables: ["transactional_sales", "inventory", "inventory_warehouse"]
    retention_days: 30

  # Validation before overwrite
  pre_overwrite_validation:
    min_records_check: true
    schema_validation: true
    business_rules_check: true
    referential_integrity: true

  # Rollback capability
  rollback_config:
    enable_rollback: true
    rollback_window_hours: 24
    rollback_notification: true

```

## 🔄 Technical Details

### Data Flow Architecture

```
📁 Raw CSV Files (S3)
    ↓
🔍 Pre-ETL Validation
    ├── Schema Validation
    ├── Data Type Checks
    └── Completeness Validation
    ↓
🏭 Data Processing Pipeline
    ├── Data Cleansing
    ├── Standardization
    ├── Deduplication
    └── Enrichment
    ↓
📊 Clean Data Tables
    ├── Master Data Tables
    ├── Transactional Tables
    └── Configuration Tables
    ↓
🔄 Datastore Sync
    ├── Incremental Updates
    ├── Full Refresh
    └── Data Archival

```

### Data Processing Steps

metadata.title: 🏗️ Core Data Processing & ETL Solutions

content:
├── Incremental Updates
    ├── Full Refresh
    └── Data Archival

```

### Data Processing Steps

1. Ingestion: CSV files loaded from S3 to staging tables
2. Validation: Schema, data type, and business rule validation
3. Cleansing: Remove duplicates, handle missing values, standardize formats
4. Transformation: Apply business rules and data enrichment
5. Loading: Move clean data to production tables
6. Audit: Log processing metrics and data lineage

### Key Database Tables & Relationships

Master Data Tables:

- product ← Core product information and hierarchies
- store ← Store master with locations and attributes
- warehouse ← Distribution center and warehouse data
- supplier ← Supplier information and relationships

Transactional Tables:

- transactional_sales ← Sales transaction history
- inventory ← Current and historical inventory levels
- purchase_order ← Purchase order information
- goods_in_transit ← In-transit inventory tracking

Purchase order information

## 🛠️ Debugging Tips

### Common Issues & Solutions

❌ CSV File Loading Errors:

- Check file encoding (must be UTF-8)
- Verify delimiter is comma (not semicolon or tab)
- Ensure proper header row with correct column names
- Check for special characters or null bytes

❌ Data Validation Failures:

- Review data quality reports for specific validation failures
- Check for missing required fields
- Verify data types match expected schemas
- Look for business rule violations

❌ Performance Issues:

- Monitor EMR cluster utilization and scale if needed
- Check for data skew in large files
- Optimize file sizes (target 100-500MB per file)
- Consider partitioning strategies for very large datasets

❌ EMR Cluster Failures:

- Check cluster logs for out-of-memory errors
- Verify IAM permissions for S3 access
- Review network connectivity and security groups
- Monitor cluster capacity and auto-scaling settings

metadata.title: 🏗️ Core Data Processing & ETL Solutions

content:
Review network connectivity and security groups
- Monitor cluster capacity and auto-scaling settings

❌ Data Overwrite Issues:

- Verify backup was created before overwrite operation
- Check data validation results before proceeding with overwrite
- Monitor record count variance (should be within configured thresholds)
- Ensure partition columns are correctly configured for overwrite mode
- Validate that retention policies are applied correctly
- Review rollback procedures if data integrity issues occur

❌ Backup and Recovery Problems:

- Confirm backup location permissions and accessibility
- Check backup retention policies and cleanup procedures
- Test rollback procedures in development environment
- Monitor backup storage costs and optimize retention settings
- Verify backup completeness before overwrite operations

### Monitoring & Alerting

metadata.title: 🏗️ Core Data Processing & ETL Solutions

content:
tention settings
- Verify backup completeness before overwrite operations

### Monitoring & Alerting

- Data Freshness: Alert when files are not updated within expected timeframes
- Data Quality: Monitor validation failure rates and data completeness
- Processing Performance: Track ETL execution times and resource usage
- Error Rates: Alert on DAG failures and data processing errors
- Overwrite Operations: Monitor backup completion, record count variance, and overwrite success rates
- Data Loss Prevention: Alert on failed backups, large data variance, or rollback triggers
- Storage Monitoring: Track backup storage usage and retention compliance

#### Data Quality Requirements:

- File Format: UTF-8 encoding, comma-delimited, header row required
- Data Completeness: >95% for required fields, >90% for optional fields

- Data Consistency: Cross-file referential integrity, consistent naming conventions

# Pre-ETL Developement

## 1. Purpose

The Pre-ETL stage is the initial processing layer within our data pipeline.
Its purpose is to convert, standardize, and prepare client-provided data into a format compatible with our internal data model before it enters the main system.

Clients often deliver raw data in a variety of formats, schemas, and naming conventions. The Pre-ETL stage ensures that, before any complex transformations or load operations occur, this data:

- Conforms to our schema and data quality standards.
- Is structured consistently across clients and sources.
- Has accurate and reliable metadata.
- Is validated, cleansed, and dependency-ready.

Essentially, Pre-ETL acts as the translation and quality-assurance layer between the external client data and our internal data infrastructure.

---

## 2. Definition of Ready

metadata.title: 🏗️ Core Data Processing & ETL Solutions

content:
tween the external client data and our internal data infrastructure.

---

## 2. Definition of Ready

Before starting Pre-ETL development for any client or dataset, certain prerequisites must be met. These ensure that development time is used efficiently and the resulting scripts are stable and maintainable.

- The client must deliver all required source data daily.
- Delivery format and method, file naming patterns, and drop times must be stable and verified.
- Some Pre-ETLs may require the output of other Pre-ETLs as input.
- A clear definition of transformations required (column renames, merges, derived columns, etc.).
- The expected output schema.
- Metadata definitions (source name, schema, file paths).

---

## 3. Overview of Pre-ETL Development Workflow

Each table or data entity received from the client must have its own Pre-ETL script. Scripts should be modular and independent, except when explicit dependencies exist.

metadata.title: 🏗️ Core Data Processing & ETL Solutions

content:
Pre-ETL script. Scripts should be modular and independent, except when explicit dependencies exist.

The Pre-ETL development process consists of the following major steps:

1. Understand input data: Analyze the raw data structure, column names, datatypes, and potential issues.
2. Define transformation logic: Identify the renames, derived columns, drops, and data fixes needed.
3. Develop the script in Databricks: Prototype and test logic interactively.
4. Update configuration files (config.yml and config_metadata.yml).
5. Integrate with the Pre-ETL pipeline by updating the fabbrica.yaml file.
6. Push changes to the repository under the correct directory.
7. Trigger and monitor the Pre-ETL DAG in Airflow.
8. Validate final outputs in the datastore/feed path.
9. Mark Pre-ETL as complete once all checks pass.

---

## 4. Script Development

### 4.1. Environment

metadata.title: 🏗️ Core Data Processing & ETL Solutions

content:
Mark Pre-ETL as complete once all checks pass.

---

## 4. Script Development

### 4.1. Environment

All Pre-ETL development should be performed in the Databricks environment, which provides an interactive notebook interface and access to the required data sources and libraries.

Once the script logic is verified, it must be exported and added to the source control repository under:

`rocks-extension/opal/pre-tl/<name_of_the_table>.py`

### 4.2. Script Structure

Pre-ETL script format:

```
"""
    <customer-name><table-name> (e.g., MattressFirmOpenOrders)
"""
from pyspark.sql import functions as F
from rocks.opal.pre_etl import PreETL

metadata.title: 🏗️ Core Data Processing & ETL Solutions

content:
ressFirmOpenOrders)
"""
from pyspark.sql import functions as F
from rocks.opal.pre_etl import PreETL

# pylint: disable=too-many-ancestors
class <customer-name><table-name>(PreETL):
    """
        <customer-name><table-name>
    """
    def main(self, input_data):
        # input tables
        <input_table_name> = input_data["raw"]
        <input_table_name_1> = input_data["<input_table_name_1>"]
        <input_table_name_2> = input_data["<input_table_name_2>"]

        # pre-etl logic goes here

        self.log.info("main logic completed")
        return <output_table>
```

Example:

```
"""
    MattressFirmProduct
"""
from pyspark.sql import functions as F
from rocks.opal.pre_etl import PreETL

# pylint: disable=too-many-ancestors
class MattressFirmProduct(PreETL):
    """
        MattressFirmProduct
    """
    def main(self, input_data):
        product = input_data["raw"]
        product_uda = input_data["product_uda"]

metadata.title: 🏗️ Core Data Processing & ETL Solutions

content:
lf, input_data):
        product = input_data["raw"]
        product_uda = input_data["product_uda"]

        self.log.info("main logic completed")
        return product
```

### 4.3. Databricks Run

When developing on Databricks, you can use the following snippet to run the script. Additionally, if you call `instance.run()`, it will write to the feed using the specified `run_id`.

```
run_date = "2025-11-07"
run_id = "2025-11-07"
instance = MattressFirmProduct(
  config_section="pre_etl_product",
  raw_data_path="/mnt/invent-mattressfirm-input/<input_folder_name>/",
  run_date=run_date,
  run_id=run_id,
)
input_data = instance.read()
result = instance.main(input_data)
display(result)
```

## 5. Configuration Management

### 5.1. Config Files Location

Each Pre-ETL job requires their configurations in two configuration files located under:

rocks-extension/opal/

metadata.title: 🏗️ Core Data Processing & ETL Solutions

content:
L job requires their configurations in two configuration files located under:

rocks-extension/opal/

1. config.yml – defines inputs and execution parameters.
2. config_metadata.yml – defines metadata for the tables such as data paths and schema details.

---

### 5.2. Example: config.yml

- The tables listed under "sources" can be found in the input_data in the script. For example, the 'raw' table is referenced as input_data["raw"]. You can add as many tables as needed, and their metadata will be extracted based on the table_name specified in config_metadata.yml.
- If you need to use a feed table (the output of another pre-ETL process) as input, replace metadata_provider with read_with_run_id: True, and set the table_name to the name of the feed (e.g., product_feed).

metadata.title: 🏗️ Core Data Processing & ETL Solutions

content:
er with read_with_run_id: True, and set the table_name to the name of the feed (e.g., product_feed).

```
pre_etl_product:
  feed_table_name: product_feed
  migrate_data_req: true
  migrator_section: migrate_product
  commons_table_name: product
  sources:
    raw:
      metadata_provider: local
      table_name: product
```

---

### 5.3. Example: config_metadata.yml

```
store:
  key: "{raw_data_path}/store.csv"
  options:
    header: ${commons.header}
    sep: ${commons.csv_delimiter}
  storage_type: csv
```

---

## 6. Pipeline Integration (fabbrica.yaml)

Once the script and configurations are ready, the Pre-ETL must be registered in the pipeline.
This is done by updating the fabbrica.yaml file located under the DAGs path.

metadata.title: 🏗️ Core Data Processing & ETL Solutions

content:
stered in the pipeline.
This is done by updating the fabbrica.yaml file located under the DAGs path.

- The config_section must match the name used in config.yml, as this is where the configuration settings are read from.
- The module specifies the location of the Pre-ETL script, while the class refers to the class name within that script.
- If the Pre-ETL depends on the output of another Pre-ETL, it must complete that process before starting. To ensure this, list the names of the dependent Pre-ETLs in upstream_task_ids.
- Additionally, don’t forget to add the Pre-ETL to the included_tasks list.

Example Entry:

metadata.title: 🏗️ Core Data Processing & ETL Solutions

content:
ask_ids.
- Additionally, don’t forget to add the Pre-ETL to the included_tasks list.

Example Entry:

```
pre_etl:
  rocks_pipeline:
    tasks:
      pre_etl_product:
        application: dbfs:/FileStore/src/${oc.env:ROCKS_ENV, "prod"}/module_runner.py
        application_args:
          config_section: pre_etl_product
        module: rocks_extension.opal.pre_etl.product
        class: MattressFirmProduct
        upstream_task_ids:
          - pre_etl_start
        downstream_task_ids:
          - pre_etl_end
    included_tasks:
    - pre_etl_product
```

This ensures Airflow will automatically handle dependency ordering and execution flow.

noteIf you need to ingest data through a Pre-ETL process but do not require a custom Pre-ETL script (extension), you can use the default base `PreETL` class by specifying the `module: rocks.opal.pre_etl` and the `class: PreETL`."

metadata.title: 🏗️ Core Data Processing & ETL Solutions

content:
default base `PreETL` class by specifying the `module: rocks.opal.pre_etl` and the `class: PreETL`."

If you need to ingest data through a Pre-ETL process but do not require a custom Pre-ETL script (extension), you can use the default base `PreETL` class by specifying the `module: rocks.opal.pre_etl` and the `class: PreETL`."

## 7. Deployment and Execution

### 7.1. Repository Commit

After all changes (script + config + fabbrica updates) are complete:

1. Commit and push the updates to the central repository.
2. Ensure your branch passes code review and CI checks.

### 7.2. Airflow DAG Execution

Once deployed, trigger the Pre-ETL DAG in Airflow.
You can:

- Trigger manually from the Airflow UI, or
- Wait for the scheduled daily execution.

### 7.3. Monitoring the Run

Monitor DAG logs to confirm:

- Each task successfully completes.
- Dependencies are respected.
- No data validation or path errors occur.

---

## 8. Validation and Completion Criteria

metadata.title: 🏗️ Core Data Processing & ETL Solutions

content:
respected.
- No data validation or path errors occur.

---

## 8. Validation and Completion Criteria

A Pre-ETL job is considered successfully completed when all the following conditions are met:

1. Airflow DAG Status: The Pre-ETL DAG shows 100% success.
2. Output Verification:Output data appears under the correct path:invent-<customername>-datastore/feed/<table_name>_feed/run_id=<run_id>File format and schema match expected metadata.Row counts and sample records are verified for correctness.
3. Schema Validation: Column types, names, and constraints align with the pokedex.
4. Data Quality Checks: No missing required fields, invalid datatypes, or mismatched encodings.
5. Dependency Verification: If other Pre-ETLs depend on this job, they can read its output successfully.

Once all checks pass, the Pre-ETL job is done.

# UpdateDatastore Development

## 1. Overview

The UpdateDatastore stage is a critical component of Opal’s orchestration pipeline, positioned immediately after the Pre-ETL step.
Its role is to transform and consolidate the pre-processed (“silver”) data into fully governed, consistent, and curated datasets (“gold”) that downstream systems can reliably consume.

While the internal logic of the pipeline is abstracted within the framework, this section focuses on enabling, registering, and configuring the UpdateDatastore step for new or modified pipelines, followed by an overview of how the component functions conceptually.

---

## 2. Enabling the UpdateDatastore Task

After completing the Pre-ETL stage, you must explicitly enable the UpdateDatastore pipeline in the `fabbrica.yaml` configuration file.

metadata.title: 🏗️ Core Data Processing & ETL Solutions

content:
, you must explicitly enable the UpdateDatastore pipeline in the `fabbrica.yaml` configuration file.

1. Navigate to the update_datastore section.
2. Include the UpdateDatastore task by adding it to the update_datastore.rocks_pipeline.included_tasks list.

If the task is not already registered in the fabbrica configuration, you must register it manually by adding it to the `update_datastore.rocks_pipeline.tasks` as shown below.

```
      data_feed_transactional_sales:
        module: rocks.opal.data_feed_new
        class: DataFeedNew
        application: ${application}
        application_args:
          config_section: data_feed_transactional_sales
        upstream_task_ids:
          - master_data_ready
        downstream_task_ids:
          - ${end_node}
```

---

## 3. Configuring the UpdateDatastore

metadata.title: 🏗️ Core Data Processing & ETL Solutions

content:
downstream_task_ids:
          - ${end_node}
```

---

## 3. Configuring the UpdateDatastore

Once the task is registered, define its configuration in the `rocks_extension/opal/config.yml` file.
The configuration block should specify task parameters, data sources, dependencies, and behavioral flags according to the project’s metadata model. It is read by the pipeline through config name provided to the config_section in the fabbrica.yaml file `update_datastore.rocks_pipeline.tasks.data_feed_<table_name>.application_args.config_section`

metadata.title: 🏗️ Core Data Processing & ETL Solutions

content:
file `update_datastore.rocks_pipeline.tasks.data_feed_<table_name>.application_args.config_section`

```
data_feed_transactional_sales:
  operation_table_name: transactional_sales
  feed_table_name: transactional_sales_feed
  id_conversions:
    - product
    - store
  overwrite:
    enabled: True
    partitioned: True
  save_update_interval_flag: True
  raise_exception_if_empty: True
  calendar_join_date_column: sales_date
  add_year_week_columns: True
  commons_table_name: transactional_sales
  is_required: null
  eliminated_by_master_control:
    enabled: True
    control_table_name: control_eliminated_by_master_transactional_sales
```

---

## 4. Manual Execution of a Task

There are scenarios (e.g., historical data load, new table creation, or re-running tasks) where you may want to execute the `update_datastore` task individually in a notebook, rather than running the entire pipeline or workflow. In such cases, use the following snippet:

metadata.title: 🏗️ Core Data Processing & ETL Solutions

content:
book, rather than running the entire pipeline or workflow. In such cases, use the following snippet:

```
from rocks.opal.data_feed_new import DataFeedNew

DataFeedNew(
    customer_config_path="dbfs:/FileStore/src/prod/rocks_extension/opal/config.yml",
    run_id="<run_id>",
    run_date="<run_date>",
    config_section="data_feed_transactional_sales",
    pipeline_name="update_datastore",
).run()

```

Note: Ensure that the `run_id` matches the `run_id` of the feed data that you want to use as the input for `DataFeedNew`.

---

noteWhile this option is available, it must be used with caution. Per an internal discussion with the Shield team, the schema and semantics of the tables must not be changed. Expanding table dates will inevitably result in large tables, which will take a very long time to process. The proposed alternative is to expand for the specific dates in the task that need them. Instead of date_expansion config for `data_feed_new`, [warp](https://github.com/inventanalytics/data-transfer-warp) has `backward_fill` and `forward_fill` functions for this purpose. In the function, partition column would be pair combinations, and order_col would be the date. You can find the details here [https://github.com/inventanalytics/data-transfer-warp/blob/617bc2b9ddf8147f44883f1ad7a74e0063bfc9d1/warp/spark/transformation.py#L665-L782](https://github.com/inventanalytics/data-transfer-warp/blob/617bc2b9ddf8147f44883f1ad7a74e0063bfc9d1/warp/spark/transformation.py#L665-L782)

While this option is available, it must be used with caution. Per an internal discussion with the Shield team, the schema and semantics of the tables must not be changed. Expanding table dates will inevitably result in large tables, which will take a very long time to process. The proposed alternative is to expand for the specific dates in the task that need them. Slack Thread: [https://invent-ai.slack.com/archives/C02TRP5G6TF/p1762867623847689](https://invent-ai.slack.com/archives/C02TRP5G6TF/p1762867623847689)

Overview
When working with historical data in price and cost tables, users may need to expand dates without relying on the run date, which can result in pruning of data. The goal is to expand dates for historical records while ensuring that performance isn’t compromised, especially when dealing with large datasets.

Problem
The default date expansion configuration works well with daily data feeds but may not be ideal for historical data. Specifically, it prunes data based on the run date, which can lead to incomplete datasets. Additionally, when working with billions of rows in a PRE-ETL process, operations such as code-to-ID conversion and date expansion can become performance bottlenecks, taking hours to complete on large clusters.

metadata.title: 🏗️ Core Data Processing & ETL Solutions

content:
n and date expansion can become performance bottlenecks, taking hours to complete on large clusters.

Solution & Recommendations
To effectively handle historical data loads for price and cost tables, consider the following configuration options and best practices:

1. Set input_data_format to delta:For historical data, set the input_data_format to delta in the data feed configuration. This ensures that historical data is processed efficiently without being pruned by the run_date.

Example snippet:

```
data_feed_new:
  price:
    input_data_format: delta
    date_expansion:
      enabled: true
      start_date_column_name: price_date
      window_partition_column_names:
        - product_id
        - store_id
      expansion_start_date: 2016-01-01
      output_date_column_name: date
      eliminate_duplicates: true

```

metadata.title: 🏗️ Core Data Processing & ETL Solutions

content:
ion_start_date: 2016-01-01
      output_date_column_name: date
      eliminate_duplicates: true

```

1. Use expansion_start_date:Instead of using past_day_count for date expansion, specify the expansion_start_date to control the lower bound of date expansion. This avoids the pruning behavior based on the run_date and allows for more control over the date range.

Example snippet:

```
date_expansion:
  enabled: true
  start_date_column_name: price_date
  expansion_start_date: 2016-01-01  # Set the start date for historical data expansion
  future_day_count: 90  # Expanding future dates
  window_partition_column_names:
    - product_id
    - store_id
  output_date_column_name: date
  eliminate_duplicates: true

```

1. Handle Date Expansion with delta Format:When using delta format, you can ensure that the maximum date present in the dataset is used as the expansion_end_date, instead of relying on the run_date.

Example snippet (from Opal 3.6.0):

metadata.title: 🏗️ Core Data Processing & ETL Solutions

content:
d as the expansion_end_date, instead of relying on the run_date.

Example snippet (from Opal 3.6.0):

```
if self.input_data_format == "delta":
    # Get the maximum date in the data and use it as expansion_end_date
    expansion_end_date = df.agg(
        {self.date_expansion["start_date_column_name"]: "max"}).collect()[0][0]
else:
    future_day_count = self.date_expansion.get("future_day_count", 27)
    expansion_end_date = self.run_date_dt + timedelta(days=future_day_count)

past_day_count = self.date_expansion.get("past_day_count", 7)
expansion_start_date = self.run_date_dt - timedelta(days=past_day_count)

```

1. Forward and Backward Fill for Price/Cost Tables:To handle price and cost data across historical dates, use forward-fill and backward-fill strategies to propagate price values based on primary key pairs, ordered by date. This method avoids the need for complex date expansion and can be much more performant.

Example process:

metadata.title: 🏗️ Core Data Processing & ETL Solutions

content:
method avoids the need for complex date expansion and can be much more performant.

Example process:

- Use forward_fill followed by backward_fill to fill in missing price data for each product-store pair across historical dates.

Example snippet:

```
# Apply forward-fill and backward-fill
expanded_df = df.withColumn("price", forward_fill(df["price"], partition_by=["product_id", "store_id"], order_by="date"))
expanded_df = expanded_df.withColumn("price", backward_fill(expanded_df["price"], partition_by=["product_id", "store_id"], order_by="date"))

```

1. Schema Integrity and Product Consistency:Shield tables should remain unchanged unless explicitly approved by the Shield team. If additional fields are needed, it is recommended to create new tables rather than altering existing ones, to maintain product consistency across the pipeline. This approach prevents unintended schema changes that could disrupt the operation of the system.

Best Practice:

metadata.title: 🏗️ Core Data Processing & ETL Solutions

content:
h prevents unintended schema changes that could disrupt the operation of the system.

Best Practice:

- If a customer requires additional fields or modifications, generate a new table instead of modifying existing Shield tables. This ensures schema consistency and avoids issues in downstream processes.

1. New Product Development:For new product development (e.g., MFP), always coordinate with the Shield team to define data requirements and ensure that any new tables are properly integrated into the Shield schema. New tables should be added as extended tables to ensure product consistency.

---

## 🧩 Extension Usage

This section explains when and how to use Pre-ETL extensions.

### 📊 Quick Decision Table

metadata.title: 🏗️ Core Data Processing & ETL Solutions

content:
ion Usage

This section explains when and how to use Pre-ETL extensions.

### 📊 Quick Decision Table

| Scenario | What to Use | Notes |
| --- | --- | --- |
| Raw table schema is identical to Pokedex schema | Default Pre-ETL | No extension needed |
| Raw table schema differs from Pokedex schema | Pre-ETL Extension | Use an extension under rocks_extension/opal/pre_etl |
| You need extra columns or logic not in default config | Pre-ETL Extension | Update config.yml and register in fabbrica.yaml |
| You need new tables or completely different schema | New Pre-ETL task | Add new config section + data feed definitions |

---

### 🧠 What Are Pre-ETL Extensions?

If a raw table does not match the feed Pokedex schema, you must align it before the ETL process.
This transformation is handled through Pre-ETL extensions.

Extensions allow you to:

metadata.title: 🏗️ Core Data Processing & ETL Solutions

content:
he ETL process.
This transformation is handled through Pre-ETL extensions.

Extensions allow you to:

- Reshape or normalize raw tables before Pokedex ingestion.
- Add or modify columns without changing default modules.
- Plug into the existing Pre-ETL workflow seamlessly.

---

🧩 Adding an Extension to fabbrica.yaml

Once your extension is created under:

```
rocks_extension/opal/pre_etl

```

Add it to `fabbrica.yaml` like this:

```
pre_etl:
  rocks_pipeline:
    tasks:
      pre_etl_product:
        application: dbfs:/FileStore/src/${oc.env:ROCKS_ENV, "prod"}/module_runner.py
        application_args:
          config_section: pre_etl_product
        module: rocks_extension.opal.pre_etl.product
        class: MattressFirmProduct
        upstream_task_ids:
          - pre_etl_start
        downstream_task_ids:
          - pre_etl_end
    included_tasks:
      - pre_etl_product

```

> 📘 See Section 4.2 for a complete working extension example.

---

metadata.title: 🏗️ Core Data Processing & ETL Solutions

content:
ks:
      - pre_etl_product

```

> 📘 See Section 4.2 for a complete working extension example.

---

⚙️ Using Default Pre-ETL (No Extension)

If no extension is required, use the default Pre-ETL class:

```
pre_etl:
  rocks_pipeline:
    tasks:
      pre_etl_product:
        application: dbfs:/FileStore/src/${oc.env:ROCKS_ENV, "prod"}/module_runner.py
        application_args:
          config_section: pre_etl_product
        module: rocks.opal.pre_etl
        class: PreETL
    included_tasks:
      - pre_etl_product

```

---

🧾 Updating config.yml When Using Extra Tables

If your extension requires additional tables beyond the default Pre-ETL sources, update the related section in `config.yml`.
You don’t need to redefine defaults — just add or override what’s needed.

Example:

metadata.title: 🏗️ Core Data Processing & ETL Solutions

content:
in `config.yml`.
You don’t need to redefine defaults — just add or override what’s needed.

Example:

```
pre_etl_product:
  sources:
    raw:
      metadata_provider: local
      table_name: product
    test:
      metadata_provider: local  # Reads from config_metadata.yml
      table_name: test
    test_2:
      table_name: test2         # Defaults to Pokedex if no metadata_provider is given
    test_3:
      read_with_run_id: True
      table_name: test_feed     # Uses Pokedex metadata and reads with related feed run_id

```

---

📦 When Schemas Still Don’t Match — Add a New Table

If schemas cannot align or you need additional columns for predefined tables, create a new Pre-ETL task.

### 🪜 Steps to Add a New Table

#### 1. Add Pokedex Entries

Add new entries for both feed and operation paths in Pokedex.

#### 2. Add New Pre-ETL Config Section

Add a new section in `config.yml`:

metadata.title: 🏗️ Core Data Processing & ETL Solutions

content:
ration paths in Pokedex.

#### 2. Add New Pre-ETL Config Section

Add a new section in `config.yml`:

```
pre_etl_order_schedule_container:
  feed_table_name: order_schedule_container_feed
  commons_table_name: order_schedule_container
  sources:
    raw:
      metadata_provider: local
      table_name: order_schedule_container
      is_required: True

```

#### 3. Add Data Feed Configuration

```
data_feed_order_schedule_container:
  operation_table_name: order_schedule_container
  feed_table_name: order_schedule_container_feed
  id_conversions:
    - product
    - source
    - destination
  overwrite:
    enabled: True
    partitioned: False
  commons_table_name: order_schedule_container
  is_required: True
  eliminated_by_master_control:
    enabled: False
    control_table_name: control_eliminated_by_master_order_container_schedule

```

### ✅ Summary

| Action | File | Purpose |
| --- | --- | --- |
| Create or edit extension | rocks_extension/opal/pre_etl | Add logic for schema alignment |
| Define sources | config.yml | Add or override tables and metadata |
| Register task | fabbrica.yaml | Connect the module to Airflow/DAG pipeline |

Use Pre-ETL extensions when:

- You need to align or modify schema definitions,
- Add preprocessing logic before feed generation, or
- Handle new or nonstandard raw tables.

### ⚠️ Removing Columns in Pre-ETL Extensions When Tables Are Used in Other Modules

When modifying schemas in Pre-ETL extensions, special care is needed if the same table is also used by Rocket Pandas, Rocket Data Partition, or other Rocks modules.

#### 🚨 Problem

metadata.title: 🏗️ Core Data Processing & ETL Solutions

content:
table is also used by Rocket Pandas, Rocket Data Partition, or other Rocks modules.

#### 🚨 Problem

If you remove a column (for example `stock_cost`) from inventory table’s schema that is also referenced in another module (like `rocket_pandas`), you may still encounter errors such as:

```
DataAccessException: Data access operation failed.
called_method: try_read
caused_by: KeyError
exception: 'stock_cost is in the schema but not in the dataframe.'

```

This happens because the default schema from Pokedex and the module schema (e.g. Rocket Data Partition schema) are automatically merged at runtime.
Simply deleting the column from your extension’s schema is not enough — the column persists through the merged default schema.

---

#### ✅ Correct Approach — Use user_schema.remove

To properly remove a column that exists in shared or merged schemas, define a `user_schema` override in your metadata configuration.

Example:

metadata.title: 🏗️ Core Data Processing & ETL Solutions

content:
shared or merged schemas, define a `user_schema` override in your metadata configuration.

Example:

```
metadata_provider:
  metadata:
    inventory:
      user_schema:
        remove:
          - stock_cost
    inventory_partitioned:
      user_schema:
        remove:
          - stock_cost

```

#### ✅ Why This Works

- The user_schema layer explicitly tells the Rocks framework to remove the column after merging schemas.
- This applies globally across all Rocks modules — including Rocket, Noob.
- It ensures consistent schema alignment across all DAGs that depend on the same table.

### 9. 🔧 Debugging and Troubleshooting

Common Configuration Issues:Financial Calculation Problems:

```
-- Check financial calculation accuracy
SELECT PlanType, Season, SUM(WrittenSales) as TotalWrittenSales,
       SUM(ActualSales) as TotalActualSales,
       (SUM(ActualSales) - SUM(WrittenSales)) / SUM(WrittenSales) * 100 as VariancePercent
FROM financial_planning.SeasonalPlan
WHERE FinancialYear = 2025
GROUP BY PlanType, Season

-- Verify OTB calculations
SELECT CategoryId, CurrentInventory, PlannedSales, CalculatedOTB,
       (CalculatedOTB / (CurrentInventory + PlannedSales)) * 100 as OTBPercentage
FROM financial_planning.OTBCalculation
WHERE CalculationDate >= DATEADD(day, -7, GETDATE())

```

## 📋 Complete Solution Documentation

### 1. 🎯 Solution Overview and Purpose

Solution 32: Markdown Optimization uses advanced mathematical optimization to determine optimal markdown pricing strategies that maximize revenue while clearing inventory effectively. The solution employs sophisticated algorithms including CLIBE (Category-Level with Inventory Balance Equations) optimization and benchmark approaches to recommend optimal discount rates, timing, and progression.

Key Capabilities:

- Price Optimization: Determines optimal markdown percentages based on demand elasticity
- Revenue Maximization: Balances markdown depth with sales velocity to optimize revenue
- Inventory Clearance: Ensures appropriate sell-through rates to minimize end-of-season stock
- Seasonal Planning: Considers promotional calendars and seasonal restrictions
- Store Segmentation: Applies different markdown strategies by store performance cluster

Business Impact:

metadata.title: 💰 Solution 32: Markdown Optimization - Configuration Guide

content:
e Segmentation: Applies different markdown strategies by store performance cluster

Business Impact:

- 15-25% improvement in markdown revenue optimization
- 20-30% reduction in end-of-season inventory
- 10-15% increase in gross margin through better pricing
- Enhanced agility in responding to market conditions

### 6. 🔄 Technical Details

#### 🎯 Optimization Algorithms:

- CLIBE Optimization: Category-Level with Inventory Balance Equations for complex scenarios
- Benchmark Optimization: Rule-based approach for simpler markdown decisions
- Hybrid Approach: Combination of CLIBE and benchmark for balanced performance
- Solver Integration: Gurobi or Google OR-Tools for mathematical optimization

#### 📊 Price Sensitivity Modeling:

- Demand Elasticity: Price sensitivity calculations based on historical data
- Price Factor Curves: Non-linear demand response to markdown percentages
- Promotion Effects: Seasonal and event-based demand uplift modeling
- Store Clustering: Different price sensitivity by store performance groups

#### 🔄 Data Flow Architecture:

```
Sales Data → Price Analysis → Demand Modeling → Optimization Engine → Recommendations → Performance Tracking

```

#### 📈 Performance Optimization:

metadata.title: 💰 Solution 32: Markdown Optimization - Configuration Guide

content:
Optimization Engine → Recommendations → Performance Tracking

```

#### 📈 Performance Optimization:

- Parallel Processing: Multi-threaded optimization for large product sets
- Caching Strategy: Pre-calculated demand curves and store clusters
- Incremental Updates: Delta processing for daily price updates
- Solver Tuning: Optimized parameters for balance of speed and accuracy

### 7. 🐛 Debugging and Troubleshooting

#### ⚠️ Common Issues:

Solver Performance Issues:

```
# Check solver status
SELECT RunId, Status, StartTime, EndTime
FROM markdown.AlgorithmRuns
WHERE Status IN ('Failed', 'InProgress', 'Timeout')
ORDER BY StartTime DESC;

# Monitor optimization time
SELECT RunId, OptimizationDuration, ItemCount, TargetGroupCount
FROM markdown.OptimizationStats
WHERE OptimizationDuration > 30  -- minutes
ORDER BY OptimizationDuration DESC;

```

Data Quality Issues:

content:
OptimizationDuration > 30  -- minutes
ORDER BY OptimizationDuration DESC;

```

Data Quality Issues:

```
-- Check price data quality
SELECT ProductCode, COUNT(*) as PriceChanges,
       MIN(DiscountRate) as MinDiscount,
       MAX(DiscountRate) as MaxDiscount
FROM markdown.PriceHistory
WHERE Date >= DATEADD(month, -12, GETDATE())
GROUP BY ProductCode
HAVING COUNT(*) < 5;  -- Too few price changes

-- Validate inventory positions
SELECT ItemCode, SUM(StoreStock) as TotalStock,
       COUNT(DISTINCT StoreCode) as StoreCount
FROM markdown.InventoryPosition
WHERE Date = (SELECT MAX(Date) FROM markdown.InventoryPosition)
GROUP BY ItemCode
HAVING SUM(StoreStock) = 0;  -- No stock items

```

Optimization Results Issues:

```
-- Check infeasible models
SELECT ItemCode, TargetGroup, ErrorMessage
FROM markdown.InfeasibleModels
WHERE RunId = (SELECT MAX(RunId) FROM markdown.AlgorithmRuns);

## 2. 📋 Solution Documentation

### Solution Overview

In-Season Allocation Solution dynamically reallocates inventory during active selling seasons to optimize sales performance, minimize stockouts, and respond to changing demand patterns across the store network. The solution continuously monitors store and product performance to identify reallocation opportunities and automatically generates transfer recommendations to move inventory from underperforming to high-performing locations. Advanced optimization algorithms consider sales velocity, seasonality, transfer costs, and business constraints to maximize revenue during active seasons.

Business Value:

- 20-30% improvement in in-season sales performance
- 15-25% reduction in end-of-season markdown requirements
- 25-35% improvement in inventory velocity across stores
- 30-40% reduction in stockouts during peak selling periods

### Common Issues & Solutions

#### 1. Allocation Optimization Failures

```
# Check rocket pandas allocation logs
grep "ALLOCATION_ERROR" /var/log/airflow/dags/rocket_pandas/*.log

# Validate allocation constraints
python validate_allocation_constraints.py --date 2024-01-15

```

#### 2. Performance Monitoring Issues

```
-- Verify store performance data
SELECT store_id,
       AVG(sales_velocity) as avg_velocity,
       COUNT(*) as data_points
FROM allocation.StorePerformance
WHERE measurement_date >= DATEADD(week, -4, GETDATE())
GROUP BY store_id
HAVING COUNT(*) < 20;  -- Identify stores with missing data

```

### 6. 🔍 Technical Details

Product Clustering Algorithm:

- Performance Metrics: Sales quantity, gross margin, inventory turnover, sales trend
- Clustering Method: K-means with percentile-based classification (A, B, C, D)
- Segmentation Criteria:A Products: Top 25% performers (high sales, high margin)B Products: 25-50% performers (good sales, moderate margin)C Products: 50-75% performers (moderate sales, acceptable margin)D Products: Bottom 25% performers (low sales, low margin)

Store Clustering Algorithm:

- Store Attributes: Sales performance, store size, customer demographics, location type
- Hierarchy Integration: Product hierarchy-specific store performance
- Targeting Logic: Automated assortment recommendations based on store cluster and product cluster combinations

Category Optimization Engine:

metadata.title: 🎯 Solution 41: Merchandise Assortment Planning - Configuration Guide

content:
commendations based on store cluster and product cluster combinations

Category Optimization Engine:

- Optimization Objective: Maximize category performance (sales × margin × turnover)
- Constraints: Minimum/maximum products per category, inventory limits, financial targets
- Algorithm: Mixed-integer programming with heuristic optimization

Performance Analytics:

- KPI Calculation: Real-time calculation of category and product performance metrics
- Trend Analysis: Statistical analysis of performance trends and seasonality
- Alerting: Automated alerts for performance exceptions and opportunities

## 📋 Complete Solution Documentation

### Solution Overview

Reallocation Solution optimizes the redistribution of existing inventory and purchase orders between stores after initial allocation to improve performance and minimize stockouts. The solution continuously monitors store performance and inventory positions to identify reallocation opportunities, automatically generating recommendations to move inventory or reassign purchase orders from underperforming to high-performing locations. Advanced algorithms consider sales velocity, store capacity, transfer costs, and business constraints to maximize return on investment during active seasons.

Business Value:

- 15-25% improvement in inventory utilization across store network
- 20-30% reduction in stockouts through optimized redistribution
- 10-15% increase in sales through better inventory placement
- 25-35% reduction in markdown risk from overstocked locations

## 🐛 Debugging & Troubleshooting

### Common Issues & Solutions

#### 1. Reallocation Algorithm Failures

```
# Check Maps reallocation algorithm logs
grep "REALLOCATION_ERROR" /var/log/maps/reallocation/*.log

# Validate prerequisite runs
SELECT TOP 10 RunId, AlgorithmCode, Status, StartDate
FROM engine.AlgoRuns
WHERE AlgorithmCode IN ('FCT', 'RPL')
ORDER BY StartDate DESC;

```

#### 2. PO Reallocation Script Issues

```
# Debug PO reallocation data
check_po_data <- function(po_data) {
  issues <- list()

  if (nrow(po_data[is.na(QTY_ORDERED)]) > 0) {
    issues <- append(issues, "Missing PO quantities")
  }

  if (nrow(po_data[QTY_ORDERED <= 0]) > 0) {
    issues <- append(issues, "Invalid PO quantities")
  }

  return(issues)
}

```

## 📋 Complete Solution Documentation

### 1. 🎯 Solution Overview and Purpose

Solution 33: Promotion Optimization uses advanced optimization algorithms to determine optimal promotional strategies that maximize revenue, profit, or sell-through rates while maintaining business constraints. The solution employs both heuristic decision-making and mathematical optimization to recommend promotional pricing, timing, and targeting strategies.

metadata.title: 🎯 Solution 33: Promotion Optimization - Configuration Guide

content:
ng and mathematical optimization to recommend promotional pricing, timing, and targeting strategies.

Key Capabilities:

- Promotional Planning: Determines optimal promotion discount rates and timing
- Revenue Optimization: Balances promotional depth with sales velocity to optimize revenue
- Sell-Through Management: Ensures appropriate inventory clearance through targeted promotions
- Store Segmentation: Applies different promotional strategies by store performance cluster
- Performance Tracking: Monitors promotional effectiveness and ROI

Business Impact:

- 20-30% improvement in promotional ROI and effectiveness
- 15-25% increase in sell-through rates during promotional periods
- 10-20% improvement in promotional margin optimization
- Enhanced agility in responding to competitive promotional pressure

### 7. 🐛 Debugging and Troubleshooting

#### ⚠️ Common Issues:

Optimization Performance Issues:

```
-- Check promotion optimization status
SELECT RunId, Status, StartTime, EndTime, ScenarioId
FROM promotion.AlgorithmRuns
WHERE Status IN ('Failed', 'InProgress', 'Timeout')
ORDER BY StartTime DESC;

-- Monitor optimization duration
SELECT RunId, OptimizationDuration, ItemCount, CategoryCount
FROM promotion.OptimizationStats
WHERE OptimizationDuration > 60  -- minutes
ORDER BY OptimizationDuration DESC;

```

Data Quality Issues:

```
-- Check promotional data quality
SELECT ItemCode, COUNT(*) as PromotionCount,
       MIN(DiscountRate) as MinDiscount,
       MAX(DiscountRate) as MaxDiscount,
       AVG(SalesUplift) as AvgUplift
FROM promotion.HistoricalPromotions
WHERE StartDate >= DATEADD(month, -12, GETDATE())
GROUP BY ItemCode
HAVING COUNT(*) < 3;  -- Too few promotions

metadata.title: 🎯 Solution 33: Promotion Optimization - Configuration Guide

content:
Date >= DATEADD(month, -12, GETDATE())
GROUP BY ItemCode
HAVING COUNT(*) < 3;  -- Too few promotions

-- Validate store cluster performance
SELECT StoreCluster, COUNT(DISTINCT ItemCode) as ItemCount,
       AVG(PromotionalLift) as AvgLift,
       AVG(ROI) as AvgROI
FROM promotion.StoreClusterPerformance
WHERE PromotionDate >= DATEADD(month, -6, GETDATE())
GROUP BY StoreCluster
HAVING AVG(ROI) < 1.0;  -- Poor performing clusters

```

Optimization Results Issues:

```
-- Check infeasible promotional models
SELECT ItemCode, StoreCluster, ErrorMessage, ConstraintViolation
FROM promotion.InfeasibleModels
WHERE RunId = (SELECT MAX(RunId) FROM promotion.AlgorithmRuns);

-- Validate promotional recommendations
SELECT ItemCode, PromotionDiscountRate, ProjectedLift, ProjectedROI
FROM promotion.OptimizationResults
WHERE RunId = (SELECT MAX(RunId) FROM promotion.AlgorithmRuns)
  AND (PromotionDiscountRate > 0.8 OR ProjectedROI < 1.0);

```

thmRuns)

```

#### 📊 Monitoring Queries:

```
-- Daily promotional optimization performance
SELECT Date, COUNT(*) as ItemsProcessed,
       AVG(OptimizationTime) as AvgTime,
       AVG(ProjectedLift) as AvgLift,
       SUM(CASE WHEN Status = 'Success' THEN 1 ELSE 0 END) as SuccessCount
FROM promotion.OptimizationLog
WHERE Date >= DATEADD(day, -7, GETDATE())
GROUP BY Date
ORDER BY Date DESC;

-- Promotional ROI tracking
SELECT PromotionWeek,
       SUM(ProjectedRevenue) as ProjectedRevenue,
       SUM(ActualRevenue) as ActualRevenue,
       SUM(PromotionalCost) as PromotionalCost,
       (SUM(ActualRevenue) - SUM(PromotionalCost)) / SUM(PromotionalCost) as ActualROI
FROM promotion.PerformanceTracking
WHERE PromotionWeek >= DATEADD(week, -12, GETDATE())
GROUP BY PromotionWeek
ORDER BY PromotionWeek DESC;

```

content:
This RFC proposes an environment and Git branching strategy, motivated by the critical need for robust tenant management and streamlined feature deployment as outlined in the "Product Tenant Management and Feature Deployment Requirements" document. The current challenges, including difficulties in cloning environments, promoting individual features, and ensuring consistent behavior between UAT and Production, highlight a pressing need for a structured approach to development, testing, and deployment. This proposal aims to address these issues, enabling the efficient, reliable, and compliant delivery of software.

> Info: The primary objective of this RFC and subject implementation is to make it ridiculously easy for delivery teams to create environments and copy data across environments for testing purposes. When combined with a new branching strategy described below, our teams can develop and test with complete confidence, meeting compliance requirements across all projects.

metadata.title: (DRAFT) RFC-NEB-01: Environment Branching, Provisioning, and Data Sync Strategy for customer implementations

content:
can develop and test with complete confidence, meeting compliance requirements across all projects.

> Tip: Vision: In the long run, we would like to reach a point where we can pinpoint to the customer the differences in output (i.e., orders or forecast) in the production and UAT UI and trace it down to a code change or PR commit id.

## Overview

This RFC proposes a [GitFlow](https://www.atlassian.com/git/tutorials/comparing-workflows/gitflow-workflow)-inspired branching model and environment management strategy for test, UAT, and production environments. It lists alternatives available for provisioning, i.e., GitHub Forms, automated data/file syncing, DAGs, CLI, Slackbot and considerations for parallel feature testing. Code, Data, and UI aspects are covered as part of this proposal. Key points include:

metadata.title: (DRAFT) RFC-NEB-01: Environment Branching, Provisioning, and Data Sync Strategy for customer implementations

content:
- Environments: We propose having at least three environments - production, UAT, and Test. UAT and Testing can be ephemeral, depending on the project's lifecycle and timing.
- Branching model: Long-lived branches for prod → uat → test, with short-lived feature branches off test. Each long-lived branch corresponds to an environment.
- Provisioning: Developers can provision ephemeral development and UAT environments using GitHub Forms, the CLI, and other methods, with manual or automatic teardown options (e.g., after 7 days).
- Data sync: Production data can be synced to test or UAT environments via DAGs, CLI, or GitHub Action Forms. We could theoretically do hourly syncs or full CTAS clones. Alternatively, we could replicate buckets between the environments, allowing each environment to run its DAGs.
- File sync: Files between buckets can be synced on-demand or on schedule via DAGs or automation tools.

metadata.title: (DRAFT) RFC-NEB-01: Environment Branching, Provisioning, and Data Sync Strategy for customer implementations

content:
ile sync: Files between buckets can be synced on-demand or on schedule via DAGs or automation tools.
- Parallel feature testing: Multiple features can be tested in parallel, using either shared or isolated data environments.
- UI constraints: Investigations are ongoing into how GitHub Forms or a custom UI can support these flows.

## Git Branch Strategy

We adopt a GitFlow-like model with long-running branches, one for each environment:

```
         +-------------+
         |  production | ← main
         +-------------+
                ↑
         +-------------+
         |     uat     | ← release
         +-------------+
                ↑
         +-------------+
         |     test    | ← test
         +-------------+
           ↑    ↑   ↑
       feat/x feat/y feat/z ← feature/*
```

metadata.title: (DRAFT) RFC-NEB-01: Environment Branching, Provisioning, and Data Sync Strategy for customer implementations

content:
| ← test
         +-------------+
           ↑    ↑   ↑
       feat/x feat/y feat/z ← feature/*
```

- main: Only stable, production-ready code.
- release: Code ready for UAT validation.
- test: Integrates ongoing work, connected to a shared test environment.
- feature/*: Isolated branches for new features.

## Environment Provisioning

Provisioning environments is a straightforward task, as we already have some automation through the template project. This project can be extended to create test and release branches, as well as the corresponding environment, upon provisioning. However, there are some differences between the environments that need to be taken into account:

metadata.title: (DRAFT) RFC-NEB-01: Environment Branching, Provisioning, and Data Sync Strategy for customer implementations

content:
ng. However, there are some differences between the environments that need to be taken into account:

1. Environment-specific configuration: We must ensure that the following configuration is enabled only in the Production environment and disabled otherwise. This is easily achieved using a combination of environment variables and branch variables:Slack Channels for build failures etc.Page Duty configurationIOControl Emails if anySecrets for Databricks etc.
2. Application-specific configuration:Input and Output locations ReportsPurchase order approvals Configuration parameters

## Daily Feeds

Daily feeds should mirror the development lifecycle, both on the customer side and on our side. The customer should first aim to provide data feeds in the test environment and then graduate to UAT and finally to prod. This will ensure our feeds are aligned with customers’ UAT and test systems.

## Data Cloning

metadata.title: (DRAFT) RFC-NEB-01: Environment Branching, Provisioning, and Data Sync Strategy for customer implementations

content:
prod. This will ensure our feeds are aligned with customers’ UAT and test systems.

## Data Cloning

While daily feeds will help test some scenarios, we don’t want to run three environments all the time. Additionally, there might be scenarios where existing production data is needed to simulate the production environment in the UAT or test accounts. However, there are several considerations when cloning data across environments:

metadata.title: (DRAFT) RFC-NEB-01: Environment Branching, Provisioning, and Data Sync Strategy for customer implementations

content:
T or test accounts. However, there are several considerations when cloning data across environments:

1. UUIDs: When we receive new products, stores, etc., in the daily data feeds, the UUIDs generated are specific to the environment the code runs in. When production data is copied from one environment to another, these UUIDs for products, stores, and other entities may not match, causing issues. This case requires either a full copy of data from production or the UUIDs of new stores and products.
2. Data Dependencies: There may be processes that either have dependencies on upstream or downstream DAGs. However, with a complete clone of data from production, there is a risk that some of these dependencies might not be thoroughly tested; thus, a daily feed and a full run may still be required to test these processes effectively.

## UI Provisioning

content:
the tools and processes needed to achieve this.

1. Process documentation: Document recommended GitFlow processes sufficiently and provide recommendations, guidelines, and best practices.
2. Pipeline template updates to provisioning additional environments and branches
3. Tooling:Environments:Ad-hoc feature environment creation:Cleanup of stale environmentsData:Tool to do a full copy of data from production to UAT or test on demandNot sure if additional tooling is required to schedule synchronization or update UUIDs or delta. If scheduling, this might overwrite the data in the testing environment
4. CLI tool: We could consider a CLI tool that could do this on demand, i.e., something like iai copy, which provides a thin wrapper around the AZ command to copy blob storage/S3.
5. Slackbot: A slackbot can also be used to provision environments or copy data between environments on demand.
6. Alerts, Production Notifications, Purchase Order Approvals, Emails, Output Results, Inputs, Reports

content:
Alerts, Production Notifications, Purchase Order Approvals, Emails, Output Results, Inputs, Reports

## Parallel Feature Testing

This setup theoretically supports multiple testers testing in parallel:

- Feature branches are deployed to dedicated ephemeral environments.
- Each is triggered from GitHub with optional test data injection.
- Shared test environment to ensure all features work together without issues.

## Cost considerations

TBC: What will be the costs of having multiple copies of customer data? Databricks clusters for testing will be needed irrespective of branching or environment strategy, and they are ephemeral anyway. Airflow costs should be minimal.

content:
## Background & Purpose

Our team is planning to integrate Okta SSO into our newly developed UI to align with the company's existing authentication infrastructure. This will ensure consistency, security, and reduce friction for internal users.
However, before moving forward, we need to define the scope, ownership, and requirements clearly to avoid misunderstandings during implementation.

---

## Questions We Need to Answer

### 1. Scope of the System

- What is the purpose of this UI? Internal tool, customer-facing platform, or both?
- Who are the users? Internal employees only? External clients?
- Is this authentication required for all environments (dev, staging, prod) or just production?

### 2. Authentication Goals

metadata.title: Proposal for Okta Authentication Integration into Customer Provisioning Portal

content:
required for all environments (dev, staging, prod) or just production?

### 2. Authentication Goals

- Do we want to use Okta only for SSO login? Or also for authorization / user permissions management?
- Will there be role-based access control (RBAC) integrated with Okta groups, or is that managed separately?
- Do we plan to integrate MFA (Multi-Factor Authentication) through Okta?

---

## 3. Coupled Systems / Dependencies

- Will this authentication layer integrate with:Backend APIsOther internal tools (data platforms, dashboards)Third-party services
- Is there a need for token sharing between this UI and other existing services (e.g., APIs authenticated through Okta)?

---

## 4. Customer Impact / Scope

metadata.title: Proposal for Okta Authentication Integration into Customer Provisioning Portal

content:
other existing services (e.g., APIs authenticated through Okta)?

---

## 4. Customer Impact / Scope

- Is this only for internal users or also for customers accessing our solutions?
- Customers are going to register with their own work e-mail through onboarding form. How to handle sign in?Onboarding users to Okta?Managing tenant-specific auth domains?
- Is this scope similar to how we handle auth in existing Next UI’s?

---

## 5. Deployment Considerations

- Should we deploy this under a subdomain (e.g., ui.company.com) with a clear namespace?
- Should we follow the same deployment approach as Cheetah's existing Okta-integrated systems?

---

## 6. Alignment with Other Teams

- Examples exist in Cheetah's current implementation.
- It might be a good idea to have a discussion between Nebula, Alpha, and Cheetah to map out a roadmap.

metadata.title: Proposal for Okta Authentication Integration into Customer Provisioning Portal

and the explanation of changes on Data Format UI.

Summary of Results:

This feature introduces solution-based filtering across the UI and Excel export functionality. With these changes:

> Tip: Users can filter CSV files by Solution ID directly in the UI.

> Tip: The Excel file format is enhanced with a defined display order for improved readability.

> Tip: All relevant metadata (e.g., solution name, ID, description, display order) is maintained in the invent_data_format.yml.

Important Warning:

> Note: Filtering uses intersection of all filtering options (Solution, sector, section filters).

These improvements:

- Make it significantly easier to access and manage CSV files for specific solutions.
- Help users track, organize, and export solution-related data more efficiently.

### UI & Output Examples

#### 1. Filtered CSVs in UI

The UI now displays only the CSV files associated with the selected solution.

metadata.title: Solution Filter Feature Documentation

content:
. Filtered CSVs in UI

The UI now displays only the CSV files associated with the selected solution.

📌 Example: After selecting `Solution 11-Demand Planning`, only the relevant data tables appear.

🖼️ Screenshot:

> Example Data Format UI

---

#### 2. Generated Excel File

The exported Excel file now:

- Includes only filtered tables for the selected solution.
- Lists tables in the order defined by display_order.
- Is formatted for improved readability.

📌 Example: After selecting `Solution 11-Demand Planning`

>

> Info: Solution filtering also works with multiple selections of solutions for both Excel and UI display

content:
Welcome to the `warp.spark.date` module! This library gives you easy-to-use PySpark functions to work with dates and calendars. It helps you get your time-series data ready and filter it easily.

---

## 📅 Filling in Dates with expand_dates

The `expand_dates` function is a helpful tool for creating a full timeline from data that has missing dates. It makes sure every date in a chosen time range has a record for each group, and it copies the last known value to fill in the empty spots. This is very important for looking at data over time.

### 1. Filling in Gaps in Event Data

This is for when your data has rows for specific days, but not for every day. The function adds the missing days and copies the last available information to those new rows.

What the Function Does

metadata.title: Warp Spark Date Module: A Developer's Guide

content:
he missing days and copies the last available information to those new rows.

What the Function Does

- df: Your starting PySpark data table.
- expansion_start_date: The first date to use for filling.
- expansion_end_date: The last date to use for filling.
- window_partition_column_names: A list of columns (like ['product_code']) that group your data. The values are copied forward inside each group.
- start_date_column_name: The name of the column that has your dates.
- output_date_column_name (Optional): A new name for the date column. It is 'date' by default.
- interval (Optional): The number of days between each new date. It is 1 by default.

Starting Table (Example)

Here is a table with some missing dates for `P1` and `P2`.

| stock_date | product_code | stock |
| --- | --- | --- |
| 2020-01-01 | P1 | 100 |
| 2020-01-04 | P1 | 110 |
| 2020-01-02 | P2 | 250 |
| 2020-01-05 | P2 | 280 |
| 2020-01-01 | P3 | 300 |

Code Example

metadata.title: Warp Spark Date Module: A Developer's Guide

content:
| 110 |
| 2020-01-02 | P2 | 250 |
| 2020-01-05 | P2 | 280 |
| 2020-01-01 | P3 | 300 |

Code Example

```
from pyspark.sql import SparkSession
from warp.spark.date import expand_dates

spark = SparkSession.builder.appName("DateExpansionExample").getOrCreate()

input_df_delta = spark.createDataFrame(
    [
        ("2020-01-01", "P1", 100),
        ("2020-01-04", "P1", 110),
        ("2020-01-02", "P2", 250),
        ("2020-01-05", "P2", 280),
        ("2020-01-01", "P3", 300)
    ],
    ["stock_date", "product_code", "stock"]
)

expanded_df = expand_dates(
    df=input_df_delta,
    expansion_start_date="2020-01-01",
    expansion_end_date="2020-01-06",
    window_partition_column_names=["product_code"],
    start_date_column_name="stock_date",
    output_date_column_name="date_new"
)

expanded_df.orderBy("product_code", "date_new").show()

```

Final Table

The function correctly fills in the missing dates and carries the `stock` value forward.

metadata.title: Warp Spark Date Module: A Developer's Guide

content:
inal Table

The function correctly fills in the missing dates and carries the `stock` value forward.

| product_code | stock | date_new |
| --- | --- | --- |
| P1 | 100 | 2020-01-01 |
| P1 | 100 | 2020-01-02 |
| P1 | 100 | 2020-01-03 |
| P1 | 110 | 2020-01-04 |
| P1 | 110 | 2020-01-05 |
| P1 | 110 | 2020-01-06 |
| P2 | 250 | 2020-01-02 |
| P2 | 250 | 2020-01-03 |
| P2 | 250 | 2020-01-04 |
| P2 | 280 | 2020-01-05 |
| P2 | 280 | 2020-01-06 |
| P3 | 300 | 2020-01-01 |
| P3 | 300 | 2020-01-02 |
| P3 | 300 | 2020-01-03 |
| P3 | 300 | 2020-01-04 |
| P3 | 300 | 2020-01-05 |
| P3 | 300 | 2020-01-06 |

---

### 2. Filling in a Date Range

This is for when your starting data already has a date range with a `start_date` and an `end_date`. The function will make a new row for every single day inside that range.

What the Function Does (Main Difference)

- end_date_column_name: The name of the column with the end date.

Starting Table (Example)

metadata.title: Warp Spark Date Module: A Developer's Guide

content:
erence)

- end_date_column_name: The name of the column with the end date.

Starting Table (Example)

This table has rows that show periods of activity. A `NULL` end date means the period goes until the `expansion_end_date`.

| start_date | end_date | product_code | stock |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| 2020-01-01 | 2020-01-04 | P1 | 100 |
| 2020-01-06 | null | P1 | 130 |
| 2020-01-02 | 2020-01-05 | P2 | 200 |
| 2020-01-07 | null | P2 | 220 |

Code Example

```
input_df_interval = spark.createDataFrame(
    [
        ("2020-01-01", "2020-01-04", "P1", 100),
        ("2020-01-06", None, "P1", 130),
        ("2020-01-02", "2020-01-05", "P2", 200),
        ("2020-01-07", None, "P2", 220)
    ],
    ["start_date", "end_date", "product_code", "stock"]
)

metadata.title: Warp Spark Date Module: A Developer's Guide

content:
("2020-01-07", None, "P2", 220)
    ],
    ["start_date", "end_date", "product_code", "stock"]
)

expanded_df_interval = expand_dates(
    df=input_df_interval,
    expansion_start_date="2020-01-01",
    expansion_end_date="2020-01-08",
    window_partition_column_names=["product_code"],
    start_date_column_name="start_date",
    end_date_column_name="end_date",
    output_date_column_name="date_new"
)

expanded_df_interval.orderBy("product_code", "date_new").show()

```

Final Table

The function correctly makes a new row for each day in the date ranges. For rows with no `end_date`, it uses `2020-01-08` as the end date.

## 🗓️ Building a Calendar Table with create_calendar_table

The `create_calendar_table` function makes a complete calendar table in Spark. This table is a basic building block for adding date-related information to your data.

How to Use It

You only need to give it a start and end date. You can also say if your weeks start on Sunday.

```
from warp.spark.date import create_calendar_table

metadata.title: Warp Spark Date Module: A Developer's Guide

content:
u can also say if your weeks start on Sunday.

```
from warp.spark.date import create_calendar_table

calendar_df = create_calendar_table(
    start_date="2023-01-01",
    end_date="2023-01-07",
    is_first_day_sunday=False
)

calendar_df.select(
    "date", "year", "month", "day_of_week", "is_weekend", "iso_8601_year", "iso_8601_week"
).show()

```

What You Get

A table with a row for each day and lots of details about that day.

| date | year | month | day_of_week | is_weekend | iso_8601_year | iso_8601_week |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| 2023-01-01 | 2023 | 1 | 7 | true | 2022 | 52 |
| 2023-01-02 | 2023 | 1 | 1 | false | 2023 | 1 |
| 2023-01-03 | 2023 | 1 | 2 | false | 2023 | 1 |
| 2023-01-04 | 2023 | 1 | 3 | false | 2023 | 1 |
| 2023-01-05 | 2023 | 1 | 4 | false | 2023 | 1 |
| 2023-01-06 | 2023 | 1 | 5 | false | 2023 | 1 |
| 2023-01-07 | 2023 | 1 | 6 | true | 2023 | 1 |

---

content:
At the start of 2025, we set the vision to reduce our customer onboarding time to less than 3 days. The vision required us to essentially remove the 3 in the 3 Day DAG and make it almost instantaneous. During the course of the year, we expanded our scope to examine end-to-end customer onboarding processes. We identified significant room for efficiency gains by centralizing and automating the entire customer onboarding process. We called this vision - The Customer Onboarding Portal, a.k.a “Nebula”.

The Customer Provisioning Portal represents a transformative approach to customer onboarding and infrastructure management, designed to reduce time-to-value while ensuring data quality and operational excellence are dramatically improved. By automating complex provisioning workflows and providing intuitive self-service capabilities, this portal transforms what traditionally takes weeks into a matter of hours.

## Vision Statement

metadata.title: Nebula - Customer Provisioning Portal

content:
, this portal transforms what traditionally takes weeks into a matter of hours.

## Vision Statement

"Operational readiness for each new customer in minutes, not weeks, through intelligent automation and seamless integration."

Our portal envisions a future where customer onboarding is not a bottleneck but an accelerator for business growth – where sales teams can confidently promise rapid deployment, delivery teams can focus on value creation rather than repetitive setup tasks, and customers experience immediate value from day one.

## 💡 Why Now?

The convergence of cloud maturity, customer expectations, and competitive pressure makes this the optimal time for investment:

metadata.title: Nebula - Customer Provisioning Portal

content:
aturity, customer expectations, and competitive pressure makes this the optimal time for investment:

1. Customer Expectations: B2B buyers expect B2C-level experiences
2. Market Differentiation: Fast onboarding is becoming a key selection criterion
3. Technical Readiness: Cloud APIs and modern frameworks enable rapid development
4. Competitive Pressure: Early movers will capture market share from slower competitors

## 🚀 Productivity Gains

### Self-service Onboarding

- Traditional Process: 2-3 weeks of back-and-forth emails, manual provisioning, and data validation
- With Portal: Almost instantaneous from signup to operational readiness
- Impact: Faster revenue recognition and improved customer satisfaction scores

### 90% Fewer Support Requirements

metadata.title: Nebula - Customer Provisioning Portal

content:
er revenue recognition and improved customer satisfaction scores

### 90% Fewer Support Requirements

- Self-Service Data Validation: Customers identify and fix issues before they become problems
- Interactive Schema Documentation: Real-time Q&A reduces confusion and misconfiguration
- Automated Error Detection: Proactive issue identification with clear resolution guidance

### Faster Issue Resolution

- Visual Error Highlighting: Instantly identify problematic data cells and relationships
- Contextual Error Messages: Specific guidance on how to fix each issue
- Referential Integrity Visualization: Clear understanding of data dependencies

## 🎯 Measurable Outcomes

### Year 1 Projections

metadata.title: Nebula - Customer Provisioning Portal

content:
lization: Clear understanding of data dependencies

## 🎯 Measurable Outcomes

### Year 1 Projections

| Metric | Current State | With Portal | Improvement |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Average Onboarding Time | 15 days | 1 day | 93% faster |
| Customer Onboardings/Month | Limited. Scales linearly with the team capacity | Unlimited |  |
| Data Quality Issues |  |  | 100 % reduction |
| Support Tickets |  |  |  |
| Customer Satisfaction (NPS) |  |  | +20 points |

---

## 🔮 Future Vision

### Phase 1 (Months 1-3): Foundation

✅ Core provisioning automation
✅ Basic data validation
✅ Customer self-service portal

### Phase 2 (Months 4-6): Intelligence

🔄 AI-powered data mapping suggestions
🔄 Predictive error detection
🔄 Automated remediation workflows

### Phase 3 (Months 7-12): Scale

📈 Multi-tenant architecture
📈 API-first platform
📈 Partner ecosystem integration

## 📊 Strategic Benefits

### Competitive Advantage

metadata.title: Nebula - Customer Provisioning Portal

content:
I-first platform
📈 Partner ecosystem integration

## 📊 Strategic Benefits

### Competitive Advantage

- Industry-Leading Onboarding: Deploy in minutes while competitors take weeks
- Premium Customer Experience: Modern, intuitive interface that reflects innovation
- Scalability: Handle 10x customer growth without proportional team expansion

### Data Quality Assurance

- 99.9% Data Accuracy: Validation before ingestion prevents downstream issues
- Compliance Ready: Audit trails and validation reports for regulatory requirements
- Reduced Data Incidents: 95% ?? fewer production data quality issues

### Team Empowerment

- Sales Confidence: Demo actual provisioning during sales calls
- Delivery Excellence: Focus on customer success, not repetitive tasks
- Customer Self-Sufficiency: Empower customers to manage their own data quality, incidents and alerts

---

## 🎯 Call to Action

metadata.title: Nebula - Customer Provisioning Portal

content:
: Empower customers to manage their own data quality, incidents and alerts

---

## 🎯 Call to Action

The Customer Provisioning Portal is not just a tool – it's a strategic investment in customer success, operational excellence, and competitive advantage. By transforming the onboarding experience, we're not only reducing costs and improving efficiency; we're fundamentally changing how customers perceive and interact with our platform from their very first touchpoint.
