content:
TanStack Query (a.k.a React Query) is a powerful data-fetching and server state management library for React. Instead of manually managing `fetch`, loading states, and invalidation, TanStack Query provides a declarative way to handle server-side data efficiently and consistently.

---

## 🚀 Why TanStack Query over fetch?

### Problems with base fetch:

- ❌ You must manually manage loading, error, and success states.
- ❌ No caching — data is re-fetched every time.
- ❌ No deduplication — two components calling the same endpoint each trigger requests.
- ❌ No invalidation — if data changes, you must manually re-fetch everywhere.
- ❌ Hard to sync server and client state.

### Benefits of TanStack Query:

metadata.title: TanStack Query (React Query) — Request Orchestration

content:
ally re-fetch everywhere.
- ❌ Hard to sync server and client state.

### Benefits of TanStack Query:

- ✅ Built-in caching — avoids unnecessary requests.
- ✅ Query keys — organize and manage requests easily.
- ✅ Automatic refetching when data becomes stale or when the user refocuses the app.
- ✅ Background updates — keep UI responsive while new data is fetched.
- ✅ Mutations with invalidation — keeps UI in sync after writes.
- ✅ Retries & error recovery — auto retry failed requests.

---

## 🔑 Core Concepts

### 1. Query Keys (the heart of React Query)

Query keys are unique identifiers that React Query uses to cache, track, and manage queries. Think of them as the primary key for your query data.

#### 🧩 What makes a query key?

- A string or an array (arrays are recommended).
- Can include variables to make the key unique per request.

Examples:

metadata.title: TanStack Query (React Query) — Request Orchestration

content:
ray (arrays are recommended).
- Can include variables to make the key unique per request.

Examples:

```
['todos'] // basic list of todos
['todos', { status: 'completed' }] // todos filtered by status
['user', userId] // a single user by id
['posts', { userId, sort: 'desc' }] // posts per user with sort
```

#### 🔍 Why query keys matter?

- React Query caches data based on the query key.
- Two queries with the same key share the same cached data.
- If you want different data, you must use different keys.
- When you invalidate a key, React Query knows which queries to refresh.

#### ⚡ Best practices for query keys:

- Always use an array → ['todos'] not 'todos'.
- Be consistent in structure.
- Include filters/params in the key so the cache doesn’t mix results.
- For complex keys, always use objects inside arrays, not strings:// Bad ❌ (hard to maintain, inconsistent string building)
['todos?status=completed']

// Good ✅ (structured and typed)
['todos', { status: 'completed' }]

metadata.title: TanStack Query (React Query) — Request Orchestration
TanStack Query (React Query) — Request Orchestration
TanStack Query (React Query) — Request Orchestration

content:
sPending}
    >
      {mutation.isPending ? 'Adding...' : 'Add Todo'}
    </button>
  );
}

```

---

### 4. Invalidating Queries

Invalidation tells React Query:
“This data is outdated, go fetch it again.”

```
const queryClient = useQueryClient();
queryClient.invalidateQueries({ queryKey: ['todos'] });

```

✅ Example

Registered queries:

```
['todos']                       // all todos
['todos', { status: 'completed' }] // completed todos
['todos', { status: 'pending' }]   // pending todos
['user', 1]                        // unrelated

```

When you call:

```
queryClient.invalidateQueries({ queryKey: ['todos'] });

```

👉 The following queries will be invalidated:

- ['todos']
- ['todos', { status: 'completed' }]
- ['todos', { status: 'pending' }]

❌ `['user', 1]` is not affected.

### 🎯 Exact Matching

If you want to only invalidate one specific query key, use the `exact` option:

```
queryClient.invalidateQueries({ queryKey: ['todos'], exact: true });

```

metadata.title: TanStack Query (React Query) — Request Orchestration

content:
e the `exact` option:

```
queryClient.invalidateQueries({ queryKey: ['todos'], exact: true });

```

👉 This will invalidate only`['todos']`, but not the variations like `['todos', { status: 'completed' }]`.

---

### 5. Caching & Garbage Collection

- Cache time: how long unused data stays in memory.
- Stale time: how long data is considered fresh before refetch.

Defaults:

- staleTime: 0 → data is stale immediately.
- cacheTime: 5 minutes → after that, unused cache is removed.

Example:

```
useQuery({
  queryKey: ['todos'],
  queryFn: fetchTodos,
  staleTime: 60 * 1000, // 1 min
  cacheTime: 10 * 60 * 1000, // 10 min
});

```

---

### 6. Refetching

React Query automatically refetches:

- On window focus.
- On network reconnect.
- When you manually refetch:const { refetch } = useQuery({
  queryKey: ['todos'],
  queryFn: fetchTodos,
});

// trigger on button click
<button onClick={() => refetch()}>Refresh</button>

---

### 7. Parallel & Dependent Queries

Parallel queries:

metadata.title: TanStack Query (React Query) — Request Orchestration

content:
lick={() => refetch()}>Refresh</button>

---

### 7. Parallel & Dependent Queries

Parallel queries:

```
const users = useQuery({ queryKey: ['users'], queryFn: fetchUsers });
const posts = useQuery({ queryKey: ['posts'], queryFn: fetchPosts });

```

Dependent queries (posts fetched only after user exists):

```
const user = useQuery({ queryKey: ['user'], queryFn: fetchUser });
const posts = useQuery({
  queryKey: ['posts', user.data?.id],
  queryFn: () => fetchPosts(user.data.id),
  enabled: !!user.data, // only runs if user exists
});

```

---

## ✅ Summary

- Queries = GET, Mutations = POST.
- Query keys are the backbone — they control caching, invalidation, and refetching.
- Stale time and cache time fine-tune UX and performance.

---

## Resources

For further details, visit the [TanStack Query documentation](https://tanstack.com/query/latest/docs/framework/react/overview).

metadata.title: TanStack Query (React Query) — Request Orchestration

> Info: This is a Nebula-maintained page for publishing MAPS database. Original page: How to publish Maps Database with sqlpackage

> Note: Before proceeding with the steps below, ensure you have sufficient permissions on the corresponding SQL Server databases and have the necessary credentials to log in. In most cases this requres DBO/Owner permissions.

The repository for MAPS DACPAC: [https://github.com/inventanalytics/maps-database/tree/master/MAPS%20Database](https://github.com/inventanalytics/maps-database/tree/master/MAPS%20Database)

As a customer onboarding step, we need to publish a model of the database to the customer database server. For this we use files with `.dacpac` extension.

> DACPAC – Data-Tier Application Package is a zip file that contains a data model (database objects).

metadata.title: How to publish Maps Database with SqlPackage

content:
DACPAC – Data-Tier Application Package is a zip file that contains a data model (database objects).

When the master/main branch of the maps-database project is built by CI/CD pipeline, we also create these DACPAC files for each customer project and the default Maps Database project. These models are then sent to cloud storage (s3) and the files can be viewed with:

```
aws s3 ls s3://pypi.inventanalytics.com/mapsdatabase/dacpacs/
master.dacpac
Maps Database.dacpac
CustomerName.Maps.Database.dacpac
```

If the customer project has not been created yet and we need a database publish, then the default project’s DACPAC file can be used. Otherwise, customer specific DACPAC file should be used. In any case, `master.dacpac` file should be present in the same directory, so download it too.

```
aws cp s3://pypi.inventanalytics.com/mapsdatabase/dacpacs/CustomerName.Maps.Database.dacpac .
aws cp s3://pypi.inventanalytics.com/mapsdatabase/dacpacs/master.dacpac .
```

metadata.title: How to publish Maps Database with SqlPackage

content:
Maps.Database.dacpac .
aws cp s3://pypi.inventanalytics.com/mapsdatabase/dacpacs/master.dacpac .
```

If you’re publishing for a new customer, you need to download latest.

```
aws s3 cp "s3://pypi.inventanalytics.com/mapsdatabase/dacpacs/Maps Database.dacpac" .
```

For the next step, we need `sqlpackage` tool to execute publish command. The tool can be obtained from [here](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/sql/tools/sqlpackage/sqlpackage-download?view=sql-server-ver16). After installation, modify and execute the command below to start publish process.

```
sqlpackage \
    /Action:Publish \
    /SourceFile:CustomerName.Maps.Database.dacpac\
    /TargetDatabaseName:CustomerDatabase \
    /TargetServerName:customer.db.inventanalytics.com,1433 \
    /TargetUser:inventuser \
    /TargetPassword:Hunter2 \
    /TargetTrustServerCertificate:True \
    /p:CreateNewDatabase=True \
    /p:ScriptDatabaseOptions=False
```

metadata.title: How to publish Maps Database with SqlPackage

content:
TrustServerCertificate:True \
    /p:CreateNewDatabase=True \
    /p:ScriptDatabaseOptions=False
```

> Note: If you see any errors about authorization/access problems, contact the Database Administrator to sort them out.

Example for a Windows User:

When you download the DacFramework.msi file and install it, it will create a folder inside`C:\Program Files\Microsoft SQL Server\160\DAC\bin`, you can move your `Maps Database.dacpac`file inside this folder and rename it as `MapsDatabase.dacpac`for easiness. Then create a terminal and paste the sqlpackage command. If your password contains special chars, make sure to put “. Make sure to get right permissions, especially for user dbo.

```
Error SQL72014: Framework Microsoft SqlClient Data Provider: Msg 15151, Level 16, State 1, Line 2 Cannot find the user 'dbo', because it does not exist or you do not have permission.
Error SQL72045: Script execution error.  The executed script:
CREATE SCHEMA [data]
    AUTHORIZATION [dbo];
```

metadata.title: How to publish Maps Database with SqlPackage

content:
045: Script execution error.  The executed script:

    AUTHORIZATION [dbo];
```

content:
## Overview

This document provides instructions for adding a User Acceptance Testing (UAT) branch to an existing Jenkins multibranch customer pipeline. UAT branches are long-running branches used for testing before production deployment, typically mirroring production configurations while deploying to a separate test environment.

noteNote that this configuration is only needed for Jenkins builds. If you are using GitHub actions, you ONLY need to create and push a UAT branch as described in Part 2. PLEASE DO NOT FOLLOW ANY OTHER PARTS. ONLY PART 2.

Note that this configuration is only needed for Jenkins builds. If you are using GitHub actions, you ONLY need to create and push a UAT branch as described in Part 2. PLEASE DO NOT FOLLOW ANY OTHER PARTS. ONLY PART 2.

## ⚠️ CRITICAL WARNING - Data Safety

BEFORE proceeding with UAT setup, you MUST configure separate storage buckets/containers for UAT to prevent accidental data loss or corruption of production data.

metadata.title: UAT Environment Setup Guide

content:
storage buckets/containers for UAT to prevent accidental data loss or corruption of production data.

UAT must have its own isolated storage:

- Input buckets/containers
- Output buckets/containers
- Datastore buckets/containers
- Database instances

Failing to configure separate storage can result in:

- Overwriting production data
- Data corruption
- Loss of critical business data
- Production service disruption

## Prerequisites

- Access to the Git repository
- Jenkins access with permissions to trigger builds
- Understanding of your customer's deployment architecture
- Familiarity with the existing branch structure (main, dev, feature branches)
- Separate storage buckets/containers created for UAT environment. For Azure, UAT containers are already provisioned for each customer during the onboarding phase. For AWS, please check with the Alpha or Nebula team if there are separate buckets or folders in use.

---

## Part 1: Understanding the Branch Configuration

### Typical Branch Structure

Most customer pipelines follow this pattern:

- main: Production environment
- dev: Development/testing environment
- feature branches: Short-lived feature development
- uat (to be added): User acceptance testing environment

### Environment Configuration Pattern

In the Jenkinsfile, branch configurations typically follow this structure:

groovy

```
switch(env.BRANCH_NAME) {
    case ~/^main$/:
        // Production settings
        env.IMAGE_ENV = "prod"
        env.CUSTOMER_SUBDOMAIN = "prod.domain"
        // ...
        break
    case ~/^dev$/:
        // Development settings
        env.IMAGE_ENV = "dev"
        env.CUSTOMER_SUBDOMAIN = "dev.domain"
        // ...
        break
    case ~/^uat$/:
        // UAT settings (to be added)
        break
}
```

Note: The specific environment variables will vary by customer, but common patterns include:

metadata.title: UAT Environment Setup Guide

content:
}
```

Note: The specific environment variables will vary by customer, but common patterns include:

- Kubernetes namespace configuration
- Environment identifiers (prod/dev)
- Cloud provider settings (AWS/Azure/GCP)
- Subdomain/URL configuration
- Cluster/resource group names

---

## Part 2: Creating the UAT Branch

### Step 1: Determine the Source Branch

Decide which branch to base UAT on:

- From main: If UAT should mirror production configuration
- From dev: If UAT should use the development configuration

Most commonly, UAT branches from the main since UAT environments typically mirror production settings. We will use the main branch for most cases.

### Step 2: Create and Push the Branch

bash

```
# Navigate to your repository
cd /path/to/repository

# Fetch latest changes
git fetch origin

# Create UAT branch from main (or dev)
git checkout -b uat origin/main

# Push the branch to remote
git push -u origin uat
```

---

## Part 3: Identifying the right accounts

metadata.title: UAT Environment Setup Guide

content:
Push the branch to remote
git push -u origin uat
```

---

## Part 3: Identifying the right accounts

### ⚠️ WARNING: Collect storage configuration BEFORE modifying Jenkinsfile

Before making any code changes, you must prepare UAT-specific storage to prevent data loss.

### Step 1: Identify All Storage Variables

Review the production and dev branch configurations to identify storage variables:

Common storage variables:

- INPUT_BUCKET_NAME / INPUT_CONTAINER_NAME
- OUTPUT_BUCKET_NAME / OUTPUT_CONTAINER_NAME
- DATASTORE_BUCKET_NAME / DATASTORE_CONTAINER_NAME
- STORAGE_ACCOUNT_NAME
- Database connection strings or secret IDs

Example from production:

```
env.INPUT_BUCKET_NAME = "invent-customer-input"
env.OUTPUT_BUCKET_NAME = "invent-customer-output"
env.DATASTORE_BUCKET_NAME = "invent-customer-datastore"
```

### Step 2: Identify UAT Storage Names

metadata.title: UAT Environment Setup Guide

content:
env.DATASTORE_BUCKET_NAME = "invent-customer-datastore"
```

### Step 2: Identify UAT Storage Names

For Azure, the container/bucket names follow a standard pattern i.e. `invent-customername-[input/output/datastore]-[dev/uat/ ]` The production account does not have the environment suffix at the end i.e. `invent-customername-datastore`.

For AWS, its not standard and you must get int touch with Nebula or Alpha team for identifying or creating the buckets if needed.

General patterns:

```
// Pattern 1: Add -uat suffix (recommended)
env.INPUT_BUCKET_NAME = "invent-customer-input-uat"
env.OUTPUT_BUCKET_NAME = "invent-customer-output-uat"
env.DATASTORE_BUCKET_NAME = "invent-customer-datastore-uat"

```

Verify:

- UAT names are clearly different from production
- Naming follows the customer's existing patterns
- All storage variables have UAT equivalents

## Part 4: Modifying the Jenkinsfile

### Required Changes

You'll need to modify the Jenkinsfile in the UAT branch. The key changes are:

#### 1. Add UAT Case to Branch Switch Statement

Locate the `switch(env.BRANCH_NAME)` block and add a UAT case:

> Note: Be careful while specifying datastore and source bucket names otherwise you might overwrite production data.

```
case ~/^uat$/:
    env.K8S_NAMESPACE = ("${CUSTOMER_NAME}-${env.BRANCH_NAME}").toLowerCase()
    env.IMAGE_ENV = "prod"  // Usually mirrors prod
    env.ROCKS_ENV = "prod"

    // ⚠️ CRITICAL: UAT MUST have separate buckets/storage from production
    env.INPUT_BUCKET_NAME = "invent-customer-input-uat"      // Separate UAT bucket
    env.OUTPUT_BUCKET_NAME = "invent-customer-output-uat"    // Separate UAT bucket
    env.DATASTORE_BUCKET_NAME = "invent-customer-datastore-uat"  // Separate UAT bucket

metadata.title: UAT Environment Setup Guide

content:
e UAT bucket
    env.DATASTORE_BUCKET_NAME = "invent-customer-datastore-uat"  // Separate UAT bucket

    env.CUSTOMER_SUBDOMAIN = "uat.domain"  // UAT-specific subdomain
    env.CUSTOMER_ENVIRONMENT = "prod-us"   // May vary
    env.K8S_CLUSTER = "${KB_CLUSTER_PROD}"
    env.K8S_CLUSTER_RG = "$CUSTOMER_ENVIRONMENT-rg"
    break
```

Customer-Specific Variations:

- Environment names may differ (prod-us, prod-eu, uat-specific)
- Subdomain patterns vary by customer
- Cloud provider settings (AWS vs Azure vs GCP)
- Cluster naming conventions
- Blob store container names will be different between environments and customers. AWS buckets have a different naming convention.

#### 2. Add UAT to Stage Conditions

Find all stages with `when` conditions and add UAT. Common stages include:

groovy

metadata.title: UAT Environment Setup Guide
UAT Environment Setup Guide

content:
may be commented out or should only run on certain branches.

#### 3. Fix Downstream Job References

If your pipeline calls other Jenkins jobs, ensure the branch parameter is dynamic. This is only needed for older pipelines. New Pipelines don’t need this.

Before (hardcoded):

groovy

```
build (job: '../CustomerAirflowScheduler/main',
    parameters: [
        string(name: 'BUILD_NUMBER', value: "${BUILD_NUMBER}"),
        string(name: 'BUILD_BRANCH_NAME', value: "${env.BRANCH_NAME}"),
    ])
```

After (dynamic):

groovy

```
build (job: "../CustomerAirflowScheduler/${env.BRANCH_NAME}",
    parameters: [
        string(name: 'BUILD_NUMBER', value: "${BUILD_NUMBER}"),
        string(name: 'BUILD_BRANCH_NAME', value: "${env.BRANCH_NAME}"),
    ])
```

#### 4. Fix Azure CLI MSAL Cache Issue (Azure Deployments Only)

If deploying to Azure, fix the MSAL cache error by setting the environment variable correctly:

Add to the stage environment block:

groovy

metadata.title: UAT Environment Setup Guide

content:
he error by setting the environment variable correctly:

Add to the stage environment block:

groovy

```
stage("Deploy Airflow Scheduler") {
    environment {
        AZURE_CORE_USE_MSAL_HTTP_CACHE = "false"  // Add this
        // ... other environment variables
    }
}
```

AND combine Azure commands in single shell:

groovy

```
sh """
    az login --service-principal --username ${AZURE_CLIENT_ID} --password ${AZURE_CLIENT_SECRET} --tenant ${AZURE_TENANT_ID}
    az account set --subscription ${AZURE_SUBSCRIPTION_ID}
    az aks get-credentials --subscription ${AZURE_SUBSCRIPTION_ID} --resource-group ${env.K8S_CLUSTER_RG} --name ${env.K8S_CLUSTER}-aks --admin
"""
```

Don't use (this doesn't work):

groovy

```
sh "export AZURE_CORE_USE_MSAL_HTTP_CACHE=false"  // Lost between commands
sh "az login ..."

### Step 1: Make Changes on UAT Branch

bash

```
# Ensure you're on UAT branch
git checkout uat

# Edit the Jenkinsfile
code .cicd/build/Jenkinsfile  # or your editor of choice

git diff
```

### Step 2: Commit and Push

bash

```
# Stage the changes
git add .cicd/build/Jenkinsfile

# Commit with descriptive message
git commit -m "Add UAT branch configuration to Jenkins pipeline

- Added UAT case to branch switch statement
- Added UAT to all deployment stage conditions
- Fixed downstream job branch parameter
- Fixed Azure MSAL cache issue
- Configured UAT to use prod settings with test subdomain"

# Push to remote
git push origin uat
```

```
## Part 6: Jenkins Configuration

### Step 1: Trigger Repository Scan

Jenkins needs to discover the new branch:

1. Navigate to your multibranch pipeline in Jenkins
2. Click "Scan Multibranch Pipeline Now" or "Scan Repository Now"
3. Wait for the scan to complete
4. You should see output like:

```
   Checking branch uat
     '.cicd/build/Jenkinsfile' found
   Met criteria
```

### Step 2: Verify Branch Detection

After scanning:

1. The UAT branch should appear in the branch list
2. Check that the branch shows as eligible for builds
3. Review any scan logs for errors

### Step 3: Trigger First Build

Option 1: Automatic Trigger

- If you have pollSCM configured, Jenkins will trigger automatically on the next poll when it detects the new commit
- Default polling: pollSCM("H/10  ") checks every 10 minutes

Option 2: Manual Trigger

metadata.title: UAT Environment Setup Guide

content:
he new commit
- Default polling: pollSCM("H/10  ") checks every 10 minutes

Option 2: Manual Trigger

1. Click on the UAT branch in Jenkins
2. Click "Build Now"
3. Monitor the build progress

### Step 4: Monitor the Build

Watch for these stages to execute:

1. Create Env Vars
2. DeployScripts
3. Build Airflow Scheduler Image
4. Deploy Airflow Scheduler
5. Any additional stages

---

## Part 7: Troubleshooting

### Issue: Branch Not Detected

Symptoms: UAT branch doesn't appear after scanning

Solutions:

1. Verify Jenkinsfile exists at correct path: .cicd/build/Jenkinsfile
2. Check branch protection rules in Git
3. Review Jenkins scan logs for errors
4. Verify Jenkins has Git credentials configured

### Issue: Build Not Triggered Automatically

Symptoms: Branch detected but no build runs

Causes:

- pollSCM only triggers on new commits
- Branch indexing discovers branches but doesn't trigger builds

Solutions:

metadata.title: UAT Environment Setup Guide

content:
triggers on new commits
- Branch indexing discovers branches but doesn't trigger builds

Solutions:

1. Push a new commit to UAT branch
2. Manually trigger with "Build Now"
3. Check if pollSCM is configured in Jenkinsfile

### Issue: Stages Skipped

Symptoms: Build runs but certain stages are skipped

Solutions:

1. Verify branch 'uat' is in all relevant when blocks
2. Check for typos in branch name
3. Add debug output:

groovy

```
   stage("Debug") {
       steps {
           echo "Branch Name: ${env.BRANCH_NAME}"
       }
   }
```

### Issue: Azure Login Fails with MSAL Error

Symptoms:

```
AttributeError: Can't get attribute 'NormalizedResponse'
```

Solution: Follow the Azure MSAL cache fix in Part 3, Section 4

### Issue: Downstream Job Not Found

Symptoms:

```
ERROR: No item named '../CustomerScheduler/uat' exists
```

Solutions:

1. Create UAT branch in downstream repository
2. Or configure UAT to use main scheduler (see Part 3, Section 3)
3. Verify job path is correct

metadata.title: UAT Environment Setup Guide

content:
tory
2. Or configure UAT to use main scheduler (see Part 3, Section 3)
3. Verify job path is correct

### Issue: Wrong Environment Variables

Symptoms: Deployment goes to wrong cluster/namespace

Solutions:

1. Verify switch statement configuration
2. Add debug stage to print all environment variables:

groovy

```
   stage("Debug Environment") {
       steps {
           sh """
               echo "K8S_NAMESPACE: ${env.K8S_NAMESPACE}"
               echo "IMAGE_ENV: ${env.IMAGE_ENV}"
               echo "CUSTOMER_ENVIRONMENT: ${env.CUSTOMER_ENVIRONMENT}"
           """
       }
   }

## Part 8: Verification Checklist

After completing the setup, verify:

- UAT branch exists in Git repository
- Jenkinsfile modified with UAT configuration
- All deployment stages include branch 'uat'
- Downstream job references are dynamic or handle UAT
- Azure MSAL cache fix applied (if using Azure)
- Jenkins scan detects UAT branch
- Build triggered successfully
- All stages execute as expected
- Deployment reaches correct environment
- Application accessible at UAT URL
- Slack/notification channels receive build status

---

## Part 9: Customer-Specific Considerations

### Configuration Variations by Customer

Different customers may have variations in:

Cloud Provider:

- AWS customers: S3 buckets, EKS clusters, IAM roles
- Azure customers: Storage accounts, AKS clusters, managed identities
- GCP customers: GCS buckets, GKE clusters, service accounts

Naming Conventions:

metadata.title: UAT Environment Setup Guide

content:
managed identities
- GCP customers: GCS buckets, GKE clusters, service accounts

Naming Conventions:

- Some use prod-us, prod-eu patterns
- Others use production, staging, uat patterns
- Namespace formats vary: customer-uat vs customer-uat-env

---

## Part 10: Maintenance

### Keeping UAT Updated

Periodic Merges from Main:

bash

```
git checkout uat
git fetch origin
git merge origin/main
git push origin uat
```

Or Rebase:

bash

```
git checkout uat
git fetch origin
git rebase origin/main
git push --force-with-lease origin uat
```

### Jenkinsfile Synchronization

When main Jenkinsfile changes:

1. Merge/cherry-pick changes to UAT
2. Verify UAT-specific configuration remains intact
3. Test UAT build after merge

---

## Summary

Adding a UAT branch involves:

metadata.title: UAT Environment Setup Guide

content:
uration remains intact
3. Test UAT build after merge

---

## Summary

Adding a UAT branch involves:

1. Creating the branch from main (typically)
2. Modifying the Jenkinsfile with UAT-specific configuration
3. Adding UAT to all relevant stage conditions
4. Fixing any hardcoded branch references
5. Pushing changes and triggering Jenkins scan
6. Monitoring and verifying the first build

The key is understanding your customer's existing patterns and applying them consistently to the UAT configuration.

---

## Quick Reference

### Common Commands

bash

```
# Create UAT branch
git checkout -b uat origin/main
git push -u origin uat

# Make changes and push
git checkout uat
git add .cicd/build/Jenkinsfile
git commit -m "Add UAT configuration"
git push origin uat

# Update UAT from main
git checkout uat
git merge origin/main
git push origin uat
```

### Key Jenkinsfile Sections to Modify

git merge origin/main
git push origin uat
```

### Key Jenkinsfile Sections to Modify

1. Switch statement: Add case ~/^uat$/:
2. Stage conditions: Add branch 'uat' to when blocks
3. Downstream jobs: Make branch parameter dynamic
4. Azure deployments: Set AZURE_CORE_USE_MSAL_HTTP_CACHE = "false"

## Postmortem summary

| Postmortem owner |  |
| --- | --- |
| Incident | Gratis Onboarding Delayed by – 5 weeks |
| Priority |  |
| Affected services | Gratis implementation |
| Team Members |  |

note
## Executive summary

On Tuesday, October 7th, 2025 the Nebula team was informed about the delay in onboarding Gratis for a new project. Gratis has been an existing customer of Invent for several years, and it was expected that this project would be executed quickly, as we already understand the customer’s data and have most of the business requirements. The existing implementation did not use the new Airflow DAGs and Databricks solution on Azure. The delivery team also factored in one to two weeks of additional onboarding time, but this time was extended to over 5 weeks. The extra time started affecting our delivery timelines, so it was escalated to the management.

metadata.title: Postmortem - Gratis Onboarding

content:
eks. The extra time started affecting our delivery timelines, so it was escalated to the management.

The delivery team expected the project to be completed by updating the datastore in about 2 weeks, with the rest of the work taking another week or so.

The existing implementation did not use the new Airflow DAGs and Databricks solution on Azure. The delivery team also factored in one to two weeks of additional onboarding time, but this time was extended to over 5 weeks. content: | Five whys root cause identificationRun a 5-whys analysis to understand the true causes of the incident. | Why did we miss the project deadlines/timelines/expectations?Creating the pre-etls took more than two weeks (12 business days)Why did it take more than two weeks for creating PRE ETLs?There were more than 20 pre-etls to build.Why did it take so long to create ETLs?Why are there 20+ PRE ETLs? → Data needs to be massaged to existing data feeds.For each update, there were Pokedex changes and testingUpdate datastore took a week - pokedex updates, takes time. This took about 1 and half weekThere were complex PRE ETLs i.e

metadata.title: Postmortem - Gratis Onboarding

content:
a week - pokedex updates, takes time. This took about 1 and half weekThere were complex PRE ETLs i.e. product, order_schedule, casepack_quantity, priceRequirements weren’t clear or documented clearly.Airflow Upgrade, Library changesWhy were the expectations so different from the reality?Every step is a discovery step?Why did we not re-align expectation based on the discovery and the discovered reality?We thought that the tasks will be distributed between the team?Other tasks came up for other team members.Lack of experiencePriorities not communicated very clearly. |
| Blameless root causeNote the final root cause and describe what needs to change without placing blame to prevent this class of incident from recurring. |  |

ind out if there was unplanned work that could've prevented the incident or reduced its impact. |  |

Expectations must be clearly drawn out before the start of the project and re-visted every day/week. Communication issue.Prioritization at the team level must be clear to everyone.The team should call out each other more often on timelines, priorities etc.The onboarding document and process need to be improved, and the new member should have a guided onboarding through the process with a mentor/guide/team. |

## Problem Statement

### Current Limitations

The `store_rpl_orders_controller` DAG currently processes store replenishment order files sequentially, one file at a time. This creates several issues:

1. Performance Bottleneck: When multiple CSV files are queued, they must wait for each previous file to complete processing, leading to:Increased total processing time (linear scaling)Underutilized Airflow worker resourcesDelayed order fulfillment for downstream systems
2. Scalability: As order volume increases, the sequential processing model becomes a significant constraint.
3. Resource Inefficiency: Airflow workers remain idle while waiting for downstream DAGs to complete, even when multiple files are ready for processing.

### Business Impact

metadata.title: Parallel Processing Architecture for Store Replenishment Orders Controller

content:
downstream DAGs to complete, even when multiple files are ready for processing.

### Business Impact

- Delayed Order Processing: Orders may not be processed in a timely manner during peak periods
- Reduced Throughput: System cannot handle sudden spikes in order volume efficiently
- Customer Experience: Potential delays in store replenishment order fulfillment
```

### Key Code Components

File Selection (`get_first_release()`):

```
# Returns only the earliest CSV file
earliest_csv = sorted(csv_files)[0]
return earliest_csv

```

Single Trigger (`trigger_run()`):

```
# Creates a single TriggerDagRunOperator
trigger = TriggerDagRunOperator(
    task_id="trigger",
    trigger_dag_id=self.trigger_dag_id,
    wait_for_completion=True  # Blocks until completion
)

```

### Limitations

metadata.title: Parallel Processing Architecture for Store Replenishment Orders Controller

content:
self.trigger_dag_id,
    wait_for_completion=True  # Blocks until completion
)

```

### Limitations

1. Single File Processing: get_first_release() only returns one file
2. Sequential Execution: Each file must complete before the next starts
3. Shared State Conflicts: Airflow Variables (output_file_status, released_store_rpl_orders_output_path) are global and could conflict in parallel execution
4. Manifest Generation: Designed for single output path

---

## Proposed Solution

### High-Level Approach

Implement parallel processing using Airflow Dynamic Task Mapping to process multiple CSV files concurrently, with configurable concurrency limits to prevent resource exhaustion.

### Benefits

metadata.title: Parallel Processing Architecture for Store Replenishment Orders Controller

content:
les concurrently, with configurable concurrency limits to prevent resource exhaustion.

### Benefits

- ✅ Improved Throughput: Process multiple files simultaneously
- ✅ Better Resource Utilization: Maximize Airflow worker usage
- ✅ Reduced Processing Time: Linear time complexity → logarithmic
- ✅ Scalability: Handle peak loads more efficiently
- ✅ Backward Compatible: Can fall back to sequential mode if needed

---
```

### Component Changes

#### 1. File Discovery Method

Current:

```
def get_first_release(self, run_queue_path: str):
    # Returns single file
    earliest_csv = sorted(csv_files)[0]
    return earliest_csv

```

Proposed:

```
@SelfTaskDecorator(task, trigger_rule=TriggerRule.NONE_FAILED_MIN_ONE_SUCCESS)
def get_all_releases(self, run_queue_path: str, max_files: int = None):
    """
    Get all CSV files under the latest run folder for parallel processing.

    :param run_queue_path: Path to queue folder
    :param max_files: Maximum number of files to process (None = all)
    :return: List of CSV file paths
    """
    storage_driver = self.get_storage_driver()
    try:
        last_run_folder = storage_driver.get_latest_prefix(prefix=run_queue_path)
        if not last_run_folder:
            return []

metadata.title: Parallel Processing Architecture for Store Replenishment Orders Controller

content:
river.get_latest_prefix(prefix=run_queue_path)
        if not last_run_folder:
            return []

        all_files = storage_driver.list_objects(last_run_folder)
        csv_files = sorted([f for f in all_files if f.endswith(".csv")])

        if max_files:
            csv_files = csv_files[:max_files]

        return csv_files
    except Exception as exc:
        LOG.exception("Failed to get CSV files: %s", exc)
        return []

```

def set_run_processed(self, dag):
    """Process multiple files in parallel"""

    @task
    def cleanup_single_file(release_path: str):
        """Cleanup a single file - mapped across all files"""
        with TaskGroup(group_id=f"cleanup_{hash(release_path)}") as cleanup_group:
            copy_task = PythonOperator(
                task_id="copy_to_processed",
                python_callable=self.copy_run_input_to_processed,
                op_kwargs={"last_run_in_queue_folder_path": release_path},
                dag=dag,
            )

            delete_task = PythonOperator(
                task_id="delete_from_queue",
                python_callable=self.get_storage_driver().delete_files,
                op_kwargs={"prefix": release_path},
                dag=dag,
            )

            copy_task >> delete_task

        return cleanup_group

```
## Implementation Details

### Configuration

Add configuration options to `fabbrica.yaml`:

```
store_rpl_orders_controller:
  application_settings:
    # ... existing settings ...
    parallel_processing:
      enabled: true
      max_concurrent_files: 5  # Maximum files to process in parallel
      batch_size: 10  # Maximum files to fetch per run

```

### Airflow Variables Management

Problem: Global Airflow Variables will conflict when multiple files process simultaneously.

Solution: Use file-specific variable naming or XCom-based state management.

Option 1: File-Specific Variables

metadata.title: Parallel Processing Architecture for Store Replenishment Orders Controller

content:
Use file-specific variable naming or XCom-based state management.

Option 1: File-Specific Variables

```
def _pick_manifest_branch_file_specific(group_id: str, release_path: str, _):
    """Check manifest status for specific file"""
    file_hash = hashlib.md5(release_path.encode()).hexdigest()[:8]
    status = Variable.get(f"output_file_status_{file_hash}", default_var="")
    return (
        f"{group_id}.generate_manifest"
        if status != "empty"
        else f"{group_id}.skip_manifest"
    )

```

Option 2: XCom-Based State (Preferred)

```
# Store file-specific state in XCom instead of Variables
# Each mapped task has its own XCom namespace

```

### Manifest Generation Strategy

Current: Single manifest for single output path

Proposed Options:

metadata.title: Parallel Processing Architecture for Store Replenishment Orders Controller

content:
### Manifest Generation Strategy

Current: Single manifest for single output path

Proposed Options:

1. Per-File Manifests: Generate a manifest for each output filePros: Simple, no conflictsCons: Multiple manifest files
2. Aggregated Manifest: Collect all outputs, generate one combined manifestPros: Single manifest fileCons: Requires aggregation step, more complex
3. No Per-Run Manifest: Generate manifest only at end of all processingPros: Cleanest approachCons: Requires final aggregation task

Recommendation: Option 1 (Per-File Manifests) for initial implementation, with option to aggregate later.

### Concurrency ControlUse Airflow's built-in concurrency controls:

```
# In DAG definition
dag = DAG(
    dag_id="store_rpl_orders_controller",
    max_active_tasks=10,  # Limit total concurrent tasks
    max_active_runs=1,    # Only one DAG run at a time
    # ...
)

```

Or use task-level concurrency:

metadata.title: Parallel Processing Architecture for Store Replenishment Orders Controller

content:
max_active_runs=1,    # Only one DAG run at a time
    # ...
)

```

Or use task-level concurrency:

```
@task(
    max_active_tis_per_dag=5  # Limit concurrent instances of this task
)
def process_single_file(...):
    ...

```

---

## Issues and Challenges

### 1. Airflow Variables Conflict ⚠️

Issue: Global Variables (`output_file_status`, `released_store_rpl_orders_output_path`) will be overwritten by parallel tasks.

Impact: High - Could cause incorrect manifest generation or lost output paths.

Solution:

- Use file-specific variable names (with file hash)
- Or migrate to XCom-based state management
- Or use a shared state table/database

Priority: Critical

---

### 2. Manifest Generation Logic 🔄

Issue: Current manifest generation expects a single output path from a single Variable.

Impact: Medium - Manifest may not be generated correctly for parallel outputs.

Solution:

metadata.title: Parallel Processing Architecture for Store Replenishment Orders Controller

content:
Variable.

Impact: Medium - Manifest may not be generated correctly for parallel outputs.

Solution:

- Generate per-file manifests
- Or implement aggregation step to combine outputs
- Update manifest generation to handle multiple paths

Priority: High

---

### 3. File Cleanup Race Conditions 🏁

Issue: Multiple tasks trying to move/delete the same file could cause conflicts.

Impact: Medium - Could cause file processing errors or duplicate processing.

Solution:

- Use atomic file operations
- Implement file locking mechanism
- Track processed files in a database/state store
- Use idempotent operations

Priority: High

---

### 4. Downstream DAG Concurrency 📊

Issue: Multiple instances of `store_rpl_orders_send_output` DAG running simultaneously may have resource constraints.

Impact: Medium - Could overwhelm downstream systems or databases.

Solution:

- Configure downstream DAG concurrency limits
- Monitor resource usage
- Implement backpressure mechanisms

Priority: Medium

---

metadata.title: Parallel Processing Architecture for Store Replenishment Orders Controller

content:
ncurrency limits
- Monitor resource usage
- Implement backpressure mechanisms

Priority: Medium

---

### 5. Error Handling and Partial Failures ❌

Issue: If one file fails, should others continue? How to handle partial success?

Impact: Medium - Need clear failure handling strategy.

Solution:

- Use TriggerRule.NONE_FAILED_MIN_ONE_SUCCESS for aggregation tasks
- Implement retry logic per file
- Track success/failure per file
- Provide clear error reporting

Priority: Medium

---

### 6. Backward Compatibility 🔙

Issue: Existing workflows and monitoring may depend on sequential behavior.

Impact: Low - Should maintain compatibility.

Solution:

- Add feature flag to enable/disable parallel processing
- Support both modes (sequential and parallel)
- Gradual rollout with monitoring

Priority: Low

---

### 7. Testing Complexity 🧪

Issue: Testing parallel execution and edge cases is more complex than sequential.

Impact: Medium - Requires comprehensive test coverage.

Solution:

metadata.title: Parallel Processing Architecture for Store Replenishment Orders Controller

content:
is more complex than sequential.

Impact: Medium - Requires comprehensive test coverage.

Solution:

- Unit tests for individual components
- Integration tests with mock parallel execution
- End-to-end tests with multiple files
- Load testing with various file counts

Priority: Medium

## Testing Strategy

### 1. Unit Tests

Scope: Individual methods and functions

Test Cases:

- get_all_releases() returns correct list of files
- get_all_releases() respects max_files parameter
- get_all_releases() handles empty folder gracefully
- File-specific variable naming works correctly
- Manifest branch logic with file-specific variables

Tools: `pytest`, `unittest.mock`

---

### 2. Integration Tests

Scope: Task groups and DAG structure

Test Cases:

- Dynamic task mapping creates correct number of tasks
- XCom data flows correctly between tasks
- Task dependencies are correct
- File cleanup operations are atomic

Tools: Airflow test utilities, `pytest-airflow`

---

- File cleanup operations are atomic

Tools: Airflow test utilities, `pytest-airflow`

### 3. End-to-End Tests

Scope: Full DAG execution with multiple files

Test Scenarios:

1. Happy Path: 5 files, all process successfullyVerify all files processedVerify all manifests generatedVerify all files moved to processed folderVerify queue folder is empty
2. Partial Failure: 5 files, 1 failsVerify successful files are processedVerify failed file remains in queueVerify error reporting
3. Empty Queue: No files availableVerify DAG completes gracefullyVerify no errors
4. Large Batch: 20 files (test concurrency limits)Verify all files eventually processedVerify no resource exhaustionVerify processing time improvement

Tools: Airflow test DAG runs, test Azure Blob Storage

---

Scope: Throughput and resource usage

### 4. Performance Tests

Scope: Throughput and resource usage

Metrics:

- Total processing time vs. sequential
- Throughput (files per hour)
- Resource utilization (CPU, memory)
- Airflow worker utilization

Test Cases:

- Baseline: Sequential processing of 10 files
- Parallel: Parallel processing of 10 files (various concurrency levels)
- Compare processing times

Expected Results:

- 5x parallel processing should reduce total time by ~60-70% (accounting for overhead)
- Resource usage should increase proportionally

### 5. Load Tests

Scope: System behavior under high load

Test Scenarios:

- 50 files in queue
- 100 files in queue
- Continuous file arrival (simulate production)

Metrics:

- System stability
- Error rates
- Resource exhaustion points
- Optimal concurrency level

Scope: Ensure existing functionality still works

Test Cases:

## Rollout Plan

### Phase 1: Development and Testing (Week 1)

- [ ] Implement code changes
- [ ] Unit tests
- [ ] Integration tests
- [ ] Code review

### Phase 2: Staging Environment (Week 2)

- [ ] Deploy to staging
- [ ] End-to-end testing
- [ ] Performance testing
- [ ] Fix issues

### Phase 3: Production Pilot (Week 3)

- [ ] Deploy with feature flag disabled
- [ ] Enable for low-traffic period
- [ ] Monitor closely
- [ ] Collect metrics

### Phase 4: Gradual Rollout (Week 4-6)

- [ ] Increase concurrency gradually (1 → 3 → 5)
- [ ] Monitor at each step
- [ ] Adjust based on metrics

### Phase 5: Full Rollout (Week 7)

- [ ] Enable for all traffic
- [ ] Remove feature flag
- [ ] Update documentation
- [ ] Post-mortem review

Create Airflow/Grafana dashboards showing:

- ✅ Most processing to be complete in 1-5 minutes.
- ✅ No increase in error rates

### Reliability

---

## Alternative Approaches

Several alternative approaches were considered before selecting the parallel processing solution. This section outlines the alternatives and why they were evaluated or rejected.

### Alternative 1: Faster Polling (Detection Speed Improvement)

Approach: Reduce the sensor polling interval from 60 seconds to 10 seconds or less to detect files faster.

Implementation:

- Change poke_interval=60 to poke_interval=10 in the prefix sensor
- Minimal code change (single line modification)

Pros:

metadata.title: Parallel Processing Architecture for Store Replenishment Orders Controller

content:
=60 to poke_interval=10 in the prefix sensor
- Minimal code change (single line modification)

Pros:

- ✅ Very simple implementation (1-line change)
- ✅ Immediate improvement in detection latency (60s → 10s)
- ✅ No architectural changes required
- ✅ Low risk, easy to rollback

Cons:

- ❌ Does not address the core bottleneck (sequential processing)
- ❌ Still processes files one at a time
- ❌ Increased API calls (6x more frequent polling)
- ❌ Only improves detection speed, not processing throughput

Verdict: Complementary, not a replacement - This can be implemented alongside parallel processing for maximum benefit. Recommended as a quick win while planning the parallel processing implementation.

Current Status: `manual_orders_controller.py` already uses `poke_interval=5`, demonstrating this approach is viable.

---

### Alternative 2: Event-Driven Triggers (Real-Time Detection)

metadata.title: Parallel Processing Architecture for Store Replenishment Orders Controller

content:
rating this approach is viable.

---

### Alternative 2: Event-Driven Triggers (Real-Time Detection)

Approach: Use Azure Blob Storage Events + Event Grid to trigger DAGs immediately when files are uploaded, eliminating polling entirely.

Architecture:

```
Web UI Upload → Azure Blob Storage → Event Grid → Webhook → Airflow REST API → DAG Trigger

```

Implementation:

- Configure Azure Event Grid subscription for blob creation events
- Create webhook endpoint to receive events
- Trigger Airflow DAG via REST API when files are detected

Pros:

- ✅ Near-instant detection (<1 second latency)
- ✅ No polling overhead (zero API calls when idle)
- ✅ Most efficient resource usage
- ✅ Scales automatically with file volume
- ✅ Best user experience

Cons:

metadata.title: Parallel Processing Architecture for Store Replenishment Orders Controller

content:
t efficient resource usage
- ✅ Scales automatically with file volume
- ✅ Best user experience

Cons:

- ❌ Requires Event Grid infrastructure setup
- ❌ Requires secure webhook endpoint (security considerations)
- ❌ More complex architecture
- ❌ Additional failure points (Event Grid, webhook)
- ❌ Still doesn't solve sequential processing bottleneck

Verdict: Excellent for detection speed, but doesn't solve throughput - Best combined with parallel processing. Recommended as a future enhancement after parallel processing is implemented.

---

### Alternative 3: Batch Processing (Process All Files in One Run)

Approach: Instead of processing files one-by-one in a loop, collect all available files and process them in a single DAG run.

Implementation:

- Modify get_first_release() to return all files
- Process all files in sequence within one DAG run
- No dynamic task mapping needed

Pros:

metadata.title: Parallel Processing Architecture for Store Replenishment Orders Controller

content:
all files
- Process all files in sequence within one DAG run
- No dynamic task mapping needed

Pros:

- ✅ Simpler than dynamic task mapping
- ✅ Single DAG run for all files
- ✅ Easier to monitor and debug
- ✅ No need for self-triggering loop

Cons:

- ❌ Still sequential processing (no parallelism)
- ❌ Long-running DAG runs (if many files)
- ❌ All-or-nothing: if one file fails, may affect others
- ❌ Doesn't utilize Airflow's parallel execution capabilities

Verdict: Does not solve the core problem - This approach still processes files sequentially, just in a different structure. Rejected in favor of true parallel processing.

---

### Alternative 4: Separate DAG Per File (Multiple DAG Runs)

Approach: Trigger a separate DAG run for each file immediately upon detection, rather than processing in a single controller DAG.

Architecture:

- Event-driven or fast polling detects files
- Each file triggers its own store_rpl_orders_send_output DAG run
- No controller DAG needed

Pros:

metadata.title: Parallel Processing Architecture for Store Replenishment Orders Controller

content:
- Each file triggers its own store_rpl_orders_send_output DAG run
- No controller DAG needed

Pros:

- ✅ True parallelism (multiple DAG runs execute concurrently)
- ✅ Isolation: one file failure doesn't affect others
- ✅ Simpler controller logic (just trigger, no orchestration)

Cons:

- ❌ No centralized coordination
- ❌ Difficult to manage concurrency limits
- ❌ Harder to track overall progress
- ❌ Manifest generation becomes complex (multiple outputs)
- ❌ File cleanup coordination challenges

Verdict: Viable but less controlled - This approach works but loses the orchestration benefits of a controller DAG. The proposed parallel processing solution provides better control and observability.

---

### Alternative 5: External Queue System (Message Queue)

Approach: Use an external message queue (Azure Service Bus, RabbitMQ, etc.) to manage file processing, with Airflow workers consuming from the queue.

Architecture:

metadata.title: Parallel Processing Architecture for Store Replenishment Orders Controller

content:
itMQ, etc.) to manage file processing, with Airflow workers consuming from the queue.

Architecture:

```
Web UI → Azure Blob → Event Grid → Service Bus Queue → Airflow Workers (parallel consumers)

```

Pros:

- ✅ Industry-standard pattern for parallel processing
- ✅ Built-in concurrency control (queue depth)
- ✅ Automatic retry and dead-letter queue handling
- ✅ Scales independently of Airflow

Cons:

- ❌ Requires additional infrastructure (message queue)
- ❌ More complex architecture
- ❌ Additional operational overhead
- ❌ Overkill for current use case
- ❌ Migration effort from current system

Verdict: Over-engineered for current needs - While this is a robust pattern, it adds significant complexity and infrastructure requirements. The proposed Airflow-native solution is sufficient and simpler to maintain.

---

### Alternative 6: Hybrid Sequential-Parallel (Adaptive)

metadata.title: Parallel Processing Architecture for Store Replenishment Orders Controller

content:
s sufficient and simpler to maintain.

---

### Alternative 6: Hybrid Sequential-Parallel (Adaptive)

Approach: Process files sequentially during low-traffic periods, switch to parallel processing during peak periods.

Implementation:

- Monitor queue depth
- If queue has >N files, enable parallel processing
- If queue has ≤N files, use sequential processing

Pros:

- ✅ Optimizes resource usage based on load
- ✅ Reduces overhead during quiet periods
- ✅ Automatic scaling based on demand

Cons:

- ❌ More complex logic (queue monitoring, mode switching)
- ❌ Potential for mode switching issues
- ❌ Harder to predict behavior
- ❌ May delay processing during mode transitions

Verdict: Interesting but adds complexity - The proposed solution with configurable concurrency limits achieves similar benefits with simpler implementation. Can be considered as a future optimization.

---

### Comparison Matrix

metadata.title: Parallel Processing Architecture for Store Replenishment Orders Controller

content:
with simpler implementation. Can be considered as a future optimization.

---

### Comparison Matrix

| Approach | Throughput Improvement | Detection Speed | Complexity | Infrastructure | Recommendation |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Current (Sequential) | Baseline | 0-60s | Low | None | Status quo |
| Faster Polling | None | 0-10s | Low | None | ✅ Quick win |
| Event-Driven | None | <1s | Medium | Event Grid | ✅ Future enhancement |
| Batch Processing | None | 0-60s | Low | None | ❌ Doesn't help |
| Separate DAG Runs | High | Variable | Medium | None | ⚠️ Less control |
| Message Queue | High | <1s | High | Queue system | ❌ Over-engineered |
| Hybrid Adaptive | High | Variable | High | None | ⚠️ Future optimization |
| Parallel Processing (Proposed) | High | 0-60s | Medium | None | ✅ Selected |

---

### Recommended Approach: Combination Strategy

The optimal solution combines multiple approaches:

metadata.title: Parallel Processing Architecture for Store Replenishment Orders Controller

content:
### Recommended Approach: Combination Strategy

The optimal solution combines multiple approaches:

1. Immediate: Implement faster polling (poke_interval=10)Quick win with minimal riskImproves detection latency immediately
2. Short-term (Week 1): Implement parallel processing (this proposal)Solves the core throughput bottleneckUtilizes Airflow's native capabilities
3. Long-term (Needs to be planned): Add event-driven triggersEliminates polling overheadProvides near-instant detectionComplements parallel processing

Combined Benefits:

- ✅ Fast detection (event-driven)
- ✅ High throughput (parallel processing)
- ✅ Efficient resource usage (no polling)
- ✅ Scalable architecture

---

- Airflow 2.3+ (for Dynamic Task Mapping)
- Python 3.8+
- Existing storage driver and provider infrastructure

content: As our delivery teams operate across multiple customer implementations with varying complexities, ensuring consistency in development practices is essential to maintaining quality, reducing risks, and achieving predictable delivery timelines. This Standard Operating Procedure (SOP) defines a structured, repeatable process for software testing, versioning, and release management. It covers critical areas including Git workflow management, code promotion strategies, version control, release trains and cadence, environment synchronization, and data cloning, etc., with particular emphasis on our three-environment model (Development, UAT, and Production) linked to long-running branches.

metadata.title: (DRAFT) RFC-NEB-02: Release management, Software Testing and Versioning guidelines for Customer Projects

content:
s on our three-environment model (Development, UAT, and Production) linked to long-running branches.

This SOP builds upon and provides the frameworks, best practices, and procedural guidance necessary to onboard new customer projects, introduce new solutions and features for existing customers, resolve merge conflicts, and plan release schedules effectively while minimizing issues caused by each release. By following these guidelines, teams can reduce technical debt, prevent branch divergence, maintain parity across environments, and deliver high-quality solutions consistently. It builds upon prior internal documentation and pilot implementations. It is intended as a living document that will evolve with our processes and tooling, with feedback from delivery teams actively encouraged.

metadata.title: (DRAFT) RFC-NEB-02: Release management, Software Testing and Versioning guidelines for Customer Projects

content:
t will evolve with our processes and tooling, with feedback from delivery teams actively encouraged.

> Info: This RFC is intended only for external customer-facing projects and excludes internal product teams such as Noob, Rocket, and the UI. Product and infrastructure teams follow their own, well-documented internal processes and should not be confused with external customer-related processes.

metadata.title: (DRAFT) RFC-NEB-02: Release management, Software Testing and Versioning guidelines for Customer Projects

content:
- Pipeline Repository: Git repository named customer-pipeline-* per client.
- Branch: Git branch corresponding to an environment (dev, uat, main).
- Release Cadence: Scheduled frequency of production releases agreed with the customer.
- Release Train: Scheduled, predictable cadence for bundling and deploying multiple software changes or features together to production.
- Feature Branch: Short-lived branch used to develop individual features or fixes. Generally prefixed with feature-{jira-ticket-number}
- RACI Roles: Responsible (executes the task), Accountable (owns final decision), Consulted (provides input), Informed (kept up-to-date).
- Product teams: Internal teams responsible for developing and maintaining Invent AI products like Noob, Rocket, MAPS, the UI etc.
- Shallow clone: A shallow clone is a clone that does not copy the data files to the clone target. The table metadata is equivalent to the source.

metadata.title: (DRAFT) RFC-NEB-02: Release management, Software Testing and Versioning guidelines for Customer Projects

content:
at does not copy the data files to the clone target. The table metadata is equivalent to the source.
- Deep clone: A deep clone is a clone that copies the source table data to the clone target in addition to the metadata of the existing table.

content: Historically, we deployed features and upgrades with limited structured planning, prioritizing speed over other factors. This ad hoc process is not scalable and has been a source of stability and governance issues in the past.As we transition into an enterprise software vendor, our practices should evolve to support our scale-up and the transition to that role. Doing things at scale requires a significantly different mindset, and to some, this may appear like more red tape that slows us down. This is understandable, but we must also keep in mind that we are no longer a small vendor anymore. Our software powers some of the largest retailers in the world - an incident or disruption can potentially cause significant financial losses, reputational damage, or compliance fines for our customers. These procedures are what differentiate a small company from a large enterprise software organisation

metadata.title: (DRAFT) RFC-NEB-02: Release management, Software Testing and Versioning guidelines for Customer Projects

content:
hese procedures are what differentiate a small company from a large enterprise software organisation. As we scale, we must be prepared to sacrifice the agility of deploying to production at any time for stability and to mitigate risks for our customers.

Most of our customers have stringent IT governance processes that not only require us to maintain multiple environments for developing, testing, integrating, and verifying our software before going to production, but also to follow strict release, change, and risk management procedures. We need to ramp up our practices not only to meet our customers' requirements but also to stay a step ahead.

This document is intended to guide our delivery teams with a set of recommendations and guidelines that align with the processes and practices our customers expect from us. The document establishes Standard Operating Procedures and recommends tools to help manage these processes.

### 2.1 The Rationale for Change

metadata.title: (DRAFT) RFC-NEB-02: Release management, Software Testing and Versioning guidelines for Customer Projects

content:
ng Procedures and recommends tools to help manage these processes.

### 2.1 The Rationale for Change

Delivery teams should adopt formal Release Management (RM) because:

metadata.title: (DRAFT) RFC-NEB-02: Release management, Software Testing and Versioning guidelines for Customer Projects

content:
## 2.1 The Rationale for Change

Delivery teams should adopt formal Release Management (RM) because:

- Enterprise Expectation: Our large enterprise customers value predictability, rigorous QA, and clear audit trails (governance). Ad-hoc deployments can be viewed as unprofessional and introduce unnecessary risk to their complex IT systems.
- Risk Mitigation: Formal planning, proper versioning, and environment-specific testing help to significantly reduce the risk of deployment failures and costly service interruptions.
- Scalability & Alignment: Adopting a defined release cadence and proactively versioning our customer pipeline features is the most effective way to efficiently handle multiple concurrent development streams while maintaining alignment with the core engineering team's existing cadence.
- Compliance: Enterprise governance frameworks such as ISO 27001, SOC 2, etc., mandate specific procedures, and we must adopt them for some of our customers.

## 3. Purpose

metadata.title: (DRAFT) RFC-NEB-02: Release management, Software Testing and Versioning guidelines for Customer Projects

content:
etc., mandate specific procedures, and we must adopt them for some of our customers.

## 3. Purpose

The purpose of this SOP is to provide delivery teams, Nebula, product, and CX IT with a standardized, repeatable process for software development, testing, versioning, and release management across customer projects. By following this SOP, teams can ensure high-quality releases, maintain consistency across Development, UAT, and Production environments, reduce technical debt, and prevent branch divergence, data integrity issues, and code quality issues. It also establishes clear responsibilities for environmental ownership, code promotion,  release approvals, and ownership for each branch and step of the release process.

metadata.title: (DRAFT) RFC-NEB-02: Release management, Software Testing and Versioning guidelines for Customer Projects

content:
, code promotion,  release approvals, and ownership for each branch and step of the release process.

noteWhile Release Management is a field in its own right that spans the entire lifecycle of customer delivery, this document explicitly focuses on short-term tactical processes for delivering features, bug fixes, etc., to customers who are already live and using our systems in production. The document focuses on making the operational process more transparent and visible, providing better operational metrics and visibility to delivery teams across all stages - from development, to UAT, and deployment to production.

metadata.title: (DRAFT) RFC-NEB-02: Release management, Software Testing and Versioning guidelines for Customer Projects

content:
bility to delivery teams across all stages - from development, to UAT, and deployment to production.

While Release Management is a field in its own right that spans the entire lifecycle of customer delivery, this document explicitly focuses on short-term tactical processes for delivering features, bug fixes, etc., to customers who are already live and using our systems in production. The document focuses on making the operational process more transparent and visible, providing better operational metrics and visibility to delivery teams across all stages - from development, to UAT, and deployment to production.

## 4. Scope

This SOP applies to all activities related to software development, testing, version control, and release deployment for customer pipelines. It covers:

metadata.title: (DRAFT) RFC-NEB-02: Release management, Software Testing and Versioning guidelines for Customer Projects

content:
are development, testing, version control, and release deployment for customer pipelines. It covers:

- Development of new features and bug fixes.
- Promotion of code across Development, UAT, and Production environments.
- Git workflow management, including long-running branches and feature branches.
- Versioning, tagging, and dependency management.
- Release cadence planning and customer communication.
- While data backup, updates, cloning, and rollbacks are part of the testing and release process, the specific procedures, scripts, etc., have been categorically excluded from the scope of this document.

It is intended for all delivery teams, product teams, CX-IT personnel, Nebula team, solution architects, and production release approvers involved in customer projects.

> Note: Demo environments, PoC environments, and other environments for customers that have not signed an SoW or are not in live are excluded from this RFC.

metadata.title: (DRAFT) RFC-NEB-02: Release management, Software Testing and Versioning guidelines for Customer Projects

content:
nvironments for customers that have not signed an SoW or are not in live are excluded from this RFC.

## 4. Introduction: Continuous Release Management & Release Planning

noteContinuous release management is closely aligned with continuous delivery (CD) and continuous deployment. While CD ensures that every code change is built, tested, and ready to release at any time, continuous deployment automatically releases changes that pass all checks. Continuous release management plays a crucial role in this context by overseeing the readiness, quality, and safe rollout of releases, even without a fixed schedule. Its focus shifts from planning dates to managing the flow of changes, minimizing risk, and ensuring that every releasable change can be deployed reliably.

metadata.title: (DRAFT) RFC-NEB-02: Release management, Software Testing and Versioning guidelines for Customer Projects

content:
low of changes, minimizing risk, and ensuring that every releasable change can be deployed reliably.

Continuous release management is closely aligned with continuous delivery (CD) and continuous deployment. While CD ensures that every code change is built, tested, and ready to release at any time, continuous deployment automatically releases changes that pass all checks. Continuous release management plays a crucial role in this context by overseeing the readiness, quality, and safe rollout of releases, even without a fixed schedule. Its focus shifts from planning dates to managing the flow of changes, minimizing risk, and ensuring that every releasable change can be deployed reliably.

metadata.title: (DRAFT) RFC-NEB-02: Release management, Software Testing and Versioning guidelines for Customer Projects

content:
low of changes, minimizing risk, and ensuring that every releasable change can be deployed reliably.

Release management is the end-to-end process of planning, building, testing, and deploying software releases. It bridges development work with production deployment, ensuring quality and stability. At its core, release management creates a single source of truth that brings together all the moving pieces of a software delivery into one cohesive, *trackable entity - the planned version or release.* For delivery managers, this means you can answer the critical question "What's the status of Release 2.5?" by viewing a single, unified view rather than chasing information across multiple systems, spreadsheets, and conversations. Release management unifies several aspects of feature and software delivery in one plan:

- Intended delivery date
- Planned features and scope
- Code & branch status
- Review Status
- Deployment status
- Test status

metadata.title: (DRAFT) RFC-NEB-02: Release management, Software Testing and Versioning guidelines for Customer Projects

content:
Planned features and scope
- Code & branch status
- Review Status
- Deployment status
- Test status

Release management, when properly implemented, avoids ambiguity and makes communication and delivery of features much clearer and straightforward by providing Invent delivery teams with:

- Visibility: One view shows the complete status - what’s done, what’s in progress, and what’s blocked.
- Predictability: Clear timelines with measurable progress towards the delivery date
- Control: Ability to manage scope, assess risks, and make informed decisions
- Communication: Single source for status updates to stakeholders
- Accountability: Clear ownership of each component and its status.

Delivery teams can think of a versioned release as a container that holds everything needed to deliver value to the customer:

metadata.title: (DRAFT) RFC-NEB-02: Release management, Software Testing and Versioning guidelines for Customer Projects

content:
of a versioned release as a container that holds everything needed to deliver value to the customer:

```markdown
Release v2.5.0 (Target: Dec 15, 2025)
│
├── Features (4 stories)
│   ├── [DONE] CUSTOMER-001 Ad-hoc order release DAG
│   ├── [IN UAT] CUSTOMER-002 Pokedex updates for extended product
│   ├── [IN REVIEW] PRE ETL for Extended Store
│   └── [IN PROGRESS] Raw Data Control Email Notifications
│
├── Code Status
│   ├── CUSTOMER-001: feature/CUSTOMER-001 (merged to main)
│   ├── CUSTOMER-002: feature/CUSTOMER-001 (merged to uat)
│   ├── Build Status: ✓ Passing
│   └── Code Reviews: 25% complete (1/4)
│
├── Testing Status
│   ├── Unit Tests: ✓ 92% coverage
│   ├── Integration Tests: ✓ Passing
│   ├── UAT: 60% complete (18/30 test cases)
│   └── Regression: Scheduled for Dec 10
│
└── Deployment Status
    ├── DEV: ✓ Deployed (Nov 1)
    ├── UAT: ✓ Deployed (Nov 23)
    └── PRODUCTION: Planned for Dec 15
```

metadata.title: (DRAFT) RFC-NEB-02: Release management, Software Testing and Versioning guidelines for Customer Projects

content:
DEV: ✓ Deployed (Nov 1)
    ├── UAT: ✓ Deployed (Nov 23)
    └── PRODUCTION: Planned for Dec 15
```

Note that we do not talk about a single feature or a single Jira ticket. We consider this entire set as a versioned container. This container moves through your delivery pipeline as a cohesive unit. When you look at the release, you immediately see:

- Are we on track for the delivery date?
- What percentage of features are complete?
- Which environments have this code?
- What testing remains?
- What's blocking progress?

metadata.title: (DRAFT) RFC-NEB-02: Release management, Software Testing and Versioning guidelines for Customer Projects

content:
e complete?
- Which environments have this code?
- What testing remains?
- What's blocking progress?

> Info: It is essential to understand the role of the delivery plan and your release plan - the delivery plan is your overall plan that defines overall timelines and deliverables. The release plan actually delivers the planned milestones: minor incremental deployments of code, configuration, tests, and other assets, week after week. Each such deployment, with everything taken together, is essentially a “release”.  Technically, it is possible to view (and plan) the entire solution delivery as a release plan, but that’s beyond the scope of this document.

### 4.2 Release Planning and Cadence

metadata.title: (DRAFT) RFC-NEB-02: Release management, Software Testing and Versioning guidelines for Customer Projects

content:
a release plan, but that’s beyond the scope of this document.

### 4.2 Release Planning and Cadence

Release planning transforms development work into deliverable releases. It involves selecting features, managing scope, and coordinating the activities needed to ship. While release management provides the framework and container, release planning is the active process of filling that container with the right content, at the right time, with the right level of quality. For delivery managers, effective release planning means you can confidently answer these questions at any point in time:

metadata.title: (DRAFT) RFC-NEB-02: Release management, Software Testing and Versioning guidelines for Customer Projects

content:
s, effective release planning means you can confidently answer these questions at any point in time:

- What are we releasing? - Specific features, bug fixes, and technical improvements
- When will it be ready? - Realistic dates based on capacity and dependencies
- Who is working on what? - Clear assignment and accountability
- What are the risks? - Known blockers, dependencies, and mitigation plans
- Are we on track? - Progress metrics showing green/yellow/red status
- What's the quality level? - Test coverage, review completion, and technical debt status

content: - Strategic (2-3 months): This is essentially your overall delivery plan, providing a high-level view of the solutions or features that need to be delivered in 3 months. A good example is a high-level goal to go live with a replenishment or allocation solution with the customer in 6 months. For well-established products such as replenishment or forecasting, this can be aligned and defined via CoE work items in Jira. For new products or for highly customized implementations, this could be created directly by the delivery teams. This is the domain of CoE and delivery teams and is best managed by them.

metadata.title: (DRAFT) RFC-NEB-02: Release management, Software Testing and Versioning guidelines for Customer Projects

content:
tly by the delivery teams. This is the domain of CoE and delivery teams and is best managed by them.
- Operational (Current release): As you develop features, bug fixes, etc., you would like to release them to production to deliver value to customers ASAP. However, suppose the customer is already live and using the system in production. In that case, it can be tricky to track, manage, and deploy multiple interrelated features while ensuring no live features are impaired. This is where continuous release management and release planning come into play.

### 4.3 Weekly Workflow/Checklist for continuous delivery

noteWhile we recommend a weekly or a once-in-two-weeks (biweekly) cadence, teams are free to choose their own cadence as they deem fit for their implementations. Additionally, refer to the release cadence section later in the document.

metadata.title: (DRAFT) RFC-NEB-02: Release management, Software Testing and Versioning guidelines for Customer Projects

content:
for their implementations. Additionally, refer to the release cadence section later in the document.

While we recommend a weekly or a once-in-two-weeks (biweekly) cadence, teams are free to choose their own cadence as they deem fit for their implementations. Additionally, refer to the release cadence section later in the document.

Delivery managers are encouraged to perform these release-planning activities on a weekly or biweekly cadence, depending on the release frequency and team size. Regular check-ins help ensure progress is tracked, risks are managed, and releases remain predictable, coordinated, and high-quality. Even minor updates or incremental releases benefit from this structured review.

Below is a recommended list of tasks suitable for most projects. It is recommended to track these tasks for each release as a “Release Plan” in Jira.

content:
- Select and confirm features for release – Identify completed and tested features, fixes, and enhancements ready to ship; proactively decide which items will be included in the current release.
- Create release version and tag branch – In Jira, create a release/fix version to track included items; in Git, tag the relevant branch (UAT or prod) to mark the release point for traceability.
- Verify deployment to the correct environment – Confirm that each feature or fix is deployed to the intended environment (Dev, UAT, Production) and accessible for testing or release.
- Review feature and bug-fix status – Track the progress of each item to ensure nothing is overlooked and that issues are addressed before release.
- Identify and resolve blockers or dependencies – Detect obstacles early, coordinate solutions, and prevent delays from cascading into the release.

metadata.title: (DRAFT) RFC-NEB-02: Release management, Software Testing and Versioning guidelines for Customer Projects

content:
– Detect obstacles early, coordinate solutions, and prevent delays from cascading into the release.
- Validate test coverage and quality gates – Ensure that all features and fixes meet testing and quality standards before deployment.
- Update the deployment runbook – confirm deployment steps, rollback procedures, and environment readiness to ensure releases execute smoothly.
- Draft release notes – Keep release notes up to date with features, bug fixes, and known issues, proactively documenting the value delivered.
- Update assignments and release schedule – Ensure clarity on team responsibilities and adjust timelines to keep the release on track.
- Communicate status to stakeholders – Provide proactive visibility into progress, risks, and readiness to maintain alignment and confidence.
- Assess risks (optional) – Identify and track potential blockers or dependencies, and put mitigation plans in place before they impact the release.

metadata.title: (DRAFT) RFC-NEB-02: Release management, Software Testing and Versioning guidelines for Customer Projects

content:
otential blockers or dependencies, and put mitigation plans in place before they impact the release.
- Rebase branches (dev → UAT) – Regularly synchronize branches to prevent integration issues and reduce last-minute conflicts.
- Prepare UAT test environment – Refresh, clone, and update data to ensure testing reflects real scenarios and supports quality assurance.

### 4.4 Metrics to track

- Planned vs. actual delivery date (on-time %)
- Scope creep (features added/removed)
- Defect escape rate (bugs found in production)
- Deployment success rate
- Team velocity trends
- Time spent in each phase (i.e., base implementation)

## 5. Delivery Managers as the Release Managers with Product Mindset

## 5. Delivery Managers as the Release Managers with Product Mindset

The old model, where engineers or data scientists unilaterally ran deployments, did not scale and caused issues because it lacked a dedicated governance layer to bridge technical changes with client business expectations and formal change management processes. In addition, as we transition to mature software engineering practices across multiple environments (Test, UAT, Production) and concurrently develop numerous features and solutions for the customer, we urgently need a single point of ownership to tie together this complex process.
```
