content: Our customer project pipelines must not be viewed as standalone products we throw over the production fence to the customer, but as long-term, strategic products that we build together with the customer. This has been proven again and again: our customers come back for more. With a product mindset, we must change from being people managers to product managers with an incorporated release management function. The Delivery Manager is the best person to do this as they possess the necessary holistic view of scope, schedule, and stakeholder dependencies, enabling them to act as the integrity guardian of the production system. They ensure that project management tasks (such as scope negotiation and client communication) are directly tied to mandatory technical governance, including enforcing the Go/No-Go Checklist, validating UAT sign-offs, and managing risks associated with the deployment pipeline

metadata.title: (DRAFT) RFC-NEB-02: Release management, Software Testing and Versioning guidelines for Customer Projects

content:
o-Go Checklist, validating UAT sign-offs, and managing risks associated with the deployment pipeline. By taking on the RM function, the Delivery Manager ensures that delivery speed never compromises the predictability and quality demanded by enterprise customers, bridging the gap between business expectations and technical execution.

### Key Mandates of the RM Role:

1. Product Ownership: The client implementation is a long-lived software product, not a temporary project.
2. Process Guardianship: The RM is accountable for enforcing the release cadence, quality gates, and communication protocols.
3. Delivery Hygiene: The RM ensures formal version numbers are assigned, defects are managed as production bugs (requiring patches/hotfixes), and client expectations are mapped to a release roadmap.

### RM vs. Change Management (CM)

metadata.title: (DRAFT) RFC-NEB-02: Release management, Software Testing and Versioning guidelines for Customer Projects

content:
tfixes), and client expectations are mapped to a release roadmap.

### RM vs. Change Management (CM)

- Release Management (RM): Focuses on the technical process of planning, scheduling, and controlling the build, test, and deployment of software increments (the what and how of technical transfer).
- Change Management (CM): Focuses on preparing people, processes, and systems for the change (the who and when of adoption). CM is external-facing and essential for enterprise clients to manage risk and communicate operational impact.

To help the delivery managers in their additional role as the release managers and give them a head start, we outline the key components and tools of our release management strategy below, and how they work together to provide a complete release management solution to the delivery team.

## 6. Foundational Components: Jira Releases, Environments, and Git Branches

metadata.title: (DRAFT) RFC-NEB-02: Release management, Software Testing and Versioning guidelines for Customer Projects

content:
to the delivery team.

## 6. Foundational Components: Jira Releases, Environments, and Git Branches

This section provides an overview of the components needed for the new release management process and how they work together to provide a unified, complete control and reporting of our delivery processes. Three components enable the continuous release management process:

- Multi-Environment Setup: Provides delivery teams with dev, UAT, and production environments for testing and verifying features before releasing to production.
- Git & GitHub Actions: Enables multiple environments linked to long-running branches. Also provides code tagging and versioning functionality. With GitHub actions, our releases are automated.
- Jira Release Management: Ties everything together into a versioned release and provides easy tracking and management across all stages of the release process.

Each of these is described in more detail below.

Release Management in Jira with Multiple Environments

metadata.title: (DRAFT) RFC-NEB-02: Release management, Software Testing and Versioning guidelines for Customer Projects

content:
h of these is described in more detail below.

Release Management in Jira with Multiple Environments

### 6.1. Multi-Environment Setup: Dev, UAT, and Production environments

As previously proposed in the [(DRAFT) RFC-NEB-01: Environment Branching, Provisioning, and Data Sync Strategy for customer implementations]  and [finally merged into the GitHub Actions](https://github.com/inventanalytics/actions-workflow-templates/pull/16) repository, each *new* customer environment now comes pre-configured with the following three environments. Each environment is provisioned with its own input, output, and datastore buckets/containers, as well as its own Airflow and Data Bricks environment. Default configurations, including environment variables and dependency versions, are applied during provisioning.

It is recommended and expected that all delivery teams start using all three environments instead of just one. The recommended flow for development is as follows:

Note that the above is only a recommendation that should fit well for most cases.

metadata.title: (DRAFT) RFC-NEB-02: Release management, Software Testing and Versioning guidelines for Customer Projects

Note that the above is only a recommendation that should fit well for most cases.

> Note: Note that the dev, uat, and main branches might diverge quickly if you do not merge and rebase often. This will be almost impossible to solve if you don’t address it from the start. Merge and rebase every day, or at the start of your workday. Do not leave this until the end of the release process, as you will surely run into issues if you do.

Below is a summary of the process you should typically follow from a developer/data scientist perspective:

1. Develop in feature branches.
2. Merge feature branches back into Dev for internal testing.
3. Promote Dev → UAT → tag as vX.Y.Z-rcN. (rcN denotes Release CaNdidate)
4. Customer approves UAT release.
5. Promote UAT → main → tag as vX.Y.Z.
6. Cherry-pick urgent fixes if needed.
7. Deploy according to the release train cadence. More about release candences later in this page.

### 6.2. Git, GitHub Actions, Tagging, and Versioning

### 6.2. Git, GitHub Actions, Tagging, and Versioning

> Warning: The current GitHub action pipeline deploys code to the production environment whenever code is pushed to the main branch. Any merges or going to the main branch outside of scheduled releases and hotfixes are highly discouraged.

metadata.title: (DRAFT) RFC-NEB-02: Release management, Software Testing and Versioning guidelines for Customer Projects

content:
erges or going to the main branch outside of scheduled releases and hotfixes are highly discouraged.

GitHub and GitHub actions provide much of the functionality needed to version and deploy code into customer environments. While Git provides a versioned repository of code artifacts, GitHub Actions provides automated pipelines that can deploy code and configuration to customer environments in a predictable, repeatable manner. All customer repositories include GitHub Actions out of the box that automate deployment to dev, UAT, and production environments. Note that currently, any code pushed to the main branch is immediately deployed to the customer’s production environment; as such, going to the main branch outside scheduled releases and hotfixes is highly discouraged.

metadata.title: (DRAFT) RFC-NEB-02: Release management, Software Testing and Versioning guidelines for Customer Projects

content:
nt; as such, going to the main branch outside scheduled releases and hotfixes is highly discouraged.

- Main and UAT branches must be locked with no direct code push allowed.
- Code can only be merged in the UAT and main branches after two approving reviews. We also recommend using Co-Pilot for automated code reviews, but it should not be used as a replacement for manual reviews.
- Each feature branch, PR, and commit message must use the appropriate Jira Ticket number. This automatically links the commits, pull requests, code reviews, etc., to the work item in Jira Release Management.
- Each release in UAT and main must be tagged as explained in the previous section.
- Additionally, the Forge team can investigate if the following makes sense:Releasing code to production on new tag pushes only.For manual deployments, GitHub forms (with restricted permissions) can be used.

### 6.3. Jira Release Management

### 6.3. Jira Release Management

Jira Release Management is available to all delivery teams, but has not been used so far. We highly recommend using Jira Releases over custom spreadsheets or Google Docs, as it integrates automatically with Jira work items and GitHub to track pull requests, review status, and deployment status across different environments and branches. Above all, it provides a centralized tracking and reporting view which ties everything together in one place and gives a birds eye view of each release and its features.

#### 6.1.1 Release Planning and Versioning in Jira

The very first step in this journey is to create a release version in Jira

6.1.1.1 Creating the Release (Version): The delivery managers must create the release in the Releases section in their customer project, using the semantic versioning naming convention (e.g., `ClientName-v2.1.0`) and setting the target dates.

metadata.title: (DRAFT) RFC-NEB-02: Release management, Software Testing and Versioning guidelines for Customer Projects

content:
the semantic versioning naming convention (e.g., `ClientName-v2.1.0`) and setting the target dates.

Click on Create version and supply the details of the release according to your project:

6.1.1.2 Linking Work Items: All work items (Stories, Tasks, Bugs) planned for the release must have their Fix Version field updated to select the target release. This provides the single source of truth for the release scope. Alternatively, from the release page, simply add the relevant work items to your release as shown below:

#### 6.1.1.3 Tracking Feature Build, Review, and Merge Status

To allow Jira Release management to automatically track the status of the feature/work item across environments, we must use the Jira/GitHub Plugin for automatic status updates:

metadata.title: (DRAFT) RFC-NEB-02: Release management, Software Testing and Versioning guidelines for Customer Projects

content:
ture/work item across environments, we must use the Jira/GitHub Plugin for automatic status updates:

1. Developer/Data Scientist Action: Developers must reference the Jira issue key (e.g., [CLIENT-123]) in every commit and Pull Request (PR) title.
2. Jira Tracking: When the code is reviewed, merged (e.g., from feature/ to dev or uat or main), and passes the CI/CD build, Jira automatically updates the issue, showing the linked branches and PR status (Merged).

In the release view, delivery managers can view who is working on the feature, the latest build, and the merge status:

#### 6.1.1.4 Tracking Deployment to UAT and Production Environments

The automated deployment tracking ensures the delivery managers have real-time status.

metadata.title: (DRAFT) RFC-NEB-02: Release management, Software Testing and Versioning guidelines for Customer Projects

content:
Environments

The automated deployment tracking ensures the delivery managers have real-time status.

1. UAT Deployment: When the pipeline pushes code to the UAT environment (linked to the release branch), Jira shows “Deployment to UAT: SUCCESS.” This officially marks the start of the client UAT period.
2. Production Deployment: After the Go/No-Go Checklist is approved and the code is merged to the main branch, the deployment to Production will show: Deployment to Prod: SUCCESS.

Clicking on the merge icon, the delivery managers can view the complete history of the feature in Git, including commits, build status, deployments, pull requests, review status etc.

#### 6.1.1.5 Marking Releases as Complete

Once the release is deployed and validated in production, the delivery manager must navigate to the Releases section in Jira and click Release (or Mark as Released) for the completed version. This formally documents its delivery completion.

metadata.title: (DRAFT) RFC-NEB-02: Release management, Software Testing and Versioning guidelines for Customer Projects

content:
se (or Mark as Released) for the completed version. This formally documents its delivery completion.

#### 6.1.1.6 Release Metrics and Continuous Improvement

The delivery manager must track and report on these metrics to ensure continuous process improvement and communicate delivery stability to stakeholders:

| Metric | Definition | Improvement Goal |
| --- | --- | --- |
| Deployment Frequency | How often a team successfully deploys to Production. | Increase predictability and regularity (align with internal cadence). |
| Lead Time for Change | The time from code commit to code running successfully in Production. | Decrease this time for faster response. |
| Change Failure Rate | The percentage of releases that result in a production incident or immediate rollback. | Keep this rate as close to 0% as possible. |
| MTTR (Mean Time To Recovery) | The average time it takes to restore service after a release-related failure. | Decrease MTTR via tested rollback plans. |

metadata.title: (DRAFT) RFC-NEB-02: Release management, Software Testing and Versioning guidelines for Customer Projects

content:
kes to restore service after a release-related failure. | Decrease MTTR via tested rollback plans. |

#### 6.1.1.7 Emergency Hotfix Procedure

The Emergency Hotfix procedure is reserved only for critical production defects (P0/P1 severity) that severely impact client operations.

1. Isolation: The fix must be developed on a dedicated hotfix branch, isolating it from active development.
2. Minimal Scope: The fix must contain only the code required to resolve the immediate issue.
3. Expedited Testing: Focused regression testing must be performed in a UAT environment.
4. Delivery Manager Authorization: The RM (or delegate) provides immediate authorization based on a successful hotfix-specific Go/No-Go check.
5. Post-Mortem: After resolution, a formal review must be conducted to understand why the bug was missed.

## 7.0 Release Cadence

A common question across almost all delivery teams is how often to release changes and features to the customers. Many teams follow an agile approach and release to customer production environments multiple times a week. However, this approach is not sustainable and contradicts the governance practices of large customers, which seek more predictable release schedules.

Also, for new customer onboarding where there is no live data and the Invent feeds are not integrated into the customer’s environments, it does not make sense to follow an overly complicated process that delays development. Therefore, we propose two separate processes depending on the customer's implementation stage.

### 7.1 What needs to be released and managed

metadata.title: (DRAFT) RFC-NEB-02: Release management, Software Testing and Versioning guidelines for Customer Projects

content:
ses depending on the customer's implementation stage.

### 7.1 What needs to be released and managed

> Note: The majority of this document focuses on managing versions and releases of the artifacts described below. Environment versioning as a whole is out of scope of this document.

In each environment, we run a specific combination of software to provide a particular functionality to the customer at a given point in time. This combination of software includes:

metadata.title: (DRAFT) RFC-NEB-02: Release management, Software Testing and Versioning guidelines for Customer Projects

content:
cular functionality to the customer at a given point in time. This combination of software includes:

- Pipeline Projects: Customer-specific DAGs, ETL scripts, extensions, and pipelines, i.e., whatever is contained in the customer-pipeline-* repositories. Note that any ad-hoc scripts to be run in UAT and production should also be version-controlled and must be included in your versioned deployment package.
- Product Libraries: Rocket, Noob, etc., product libraries used across pipelines.
- Product and Pipeline configs: Pokedex metadata/schemas
- UI Components: Front-end and corresponding components interacting with pipelines.
- UI Config: Feature flags, parameter configurations, and other configurations not managed in code.
- Customer Parameters: Optimization parameters configured and controlled by the customer. This is usually maintained within the UI itself and is excluded from this discussion.

metadata.title: (DRAFT) RFC-NEB-02: Release management, Software Testing and Versioning guidelines for Customer Projects

content:
the customer. This is usually maintained within the UI itself and is excluded from this discussion.

> Info: Note that the UI is currently NOT included in the standard UAT environment provisioning. For now, externally accessible UI must be separately requested from the UI team.

All the above components are owned by various product teams and follow their own development, testing, and release processes, as well as their own release cadence, except for the customer-pipeline project. The following section proposes how the components above can be released on a known, communicated cadence, thereby reducing administrative and communication overhead.

### 7.2 New Customers, Not handed over to CX IT

For new customers, there is no need to follow any release cadence, and all development can go straight to the main branch until the base implementation is completed and the customer is handed over to CX IT. When the customer is handed over to CX IT, it is essential to ensure that:

metadata.title: (DRAFT) RFC-NEB-02: Release management, Software Testing and Versioning guidelines for Customer Projects

content:
is handed over to CX IT. When the customer is handed over to CX IT, it is essential to ensure that:

- UAT and Dev environments exist
- UAT and Dev daily feeds are also set up
- UI is configured and functional in UAT
- main branch is locked, approvers and release owners identified.
- Version v1.0.0of the customer pipeline is created and released to the production environment.
- Corresponding GitHub Release created with appropriate release notes.

However, until the base implementation is complete, development can continue on the main branch; no other processes are required.

### 7.3 Existing customers, under CX IT and live

metadata.title: (DRAFT) RFC-NEB-02: Release management, Software Testing and Versioning guidelines for Customer Projects

content:
the main branch; no other processes are required.

### 7.3 Existing customers, under CX IT and live

Once a customer has been handed over to CX IT and is in production, we need to follow the formal release processes and agree on a release cadence/schedule. At this point, the main branch will be locked, and no one will be allowed to release changes directly to production. However, given the components that make up Invent.ai solutions, it is a bit tricky to develop a schedule for all the elements. At the same time, we do not want to overwhelm the customer with multiple schedules for different components. For the customer, invent.ai solutions are a single solution, so it makes incredible sense to follow a unified release cadence for all our components.

metadata.title: (DRAFT) RFC-NEB-02: Release management, Software Testing and Versioning guidelines for Customer Projects

content:
e solution, so it makes incredible sense to follow a unified release cadence for all our components.

Of all the teams identified above, only the UI team has a [well-defined release process](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1tJ_XRke7tgyVhG0MF03h1SIjzI6Y6JHUyz1urwA3BFY/edit?gid=1482673103#gid=1482673103)  with a 2-week cadence; i.e., it releases changes to customer-facing UAT and production environments every 2 weeks. The fact that the UI is multi-tenanted makes it much easier to coordinate releases across multiple customers simultaneously. All other teams, including delivery and product, do not follow a schedule and release changes as and when needed. This has created issues in the past, and we highly recommend moving away from such practices.

metadata.title: (DRAFT) RFC-NEB-02: Release management, Software Testing and Versioning guidelines for Customer Projects

content:
eeded. This has created issues in the past, and we highly recommend moving away from such practices.

What we propose is aligning all customer releases with the existing UI team's two-week release cadence to ensure our artifacts are released, managed, and supported in synchrony, and to avoid potential disruptions to the customer. This *does not mean* that all customer teams, product teams, etc. must release their artifacts every two weeks. Each team can still pick its own release schedule (e.g., every 4 weeks, 8 weeks, 10 weeks, etc.), but must align with UI's release dates; i.e., it must be a common release with all components updated in that release.

metadata.title: (DRAFT) RFC-NEB-02: Release management, Software Testing and Versioning guidelines for Customer Projects

content:
h UI's release dates; i.e., it must be a common release with all components updated in that release.

This approach also does not mean that all customers must be upgraded on the same day; each delivery team can pick and schedule their updates for their customers when they deem it fitting. The only requirement is that they must align with the UI team’s release train. Even an ad hoc release without fixed/recurring schedules can be planned and aligned to this cadence.

metadata.title: (DRAFT) RFC-NEB-02: Release management, Software Testing and Versioning guidelines for Customer Projects

content:
Even an ad hoc release without fixed/recurring schedules can be planned and aligned to this cadence.

| Component | Recommended Cadence | Notes / Alignment with the UI team | Recommended Minimum UAT time | Ownership |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Customer Pipelines | Per release train (aligned with UI) | Merge Dev → UAT → Prod in sync with UI release | 1 Week | Delivery manager |
| Product Libraries (Noob, Rocket, OPAL, etc) | Release per train or patch | Versioned alongside UI and pipeline releases | 1 Week | Product Teams |
| UI Code | Release train schedule | Acts as the primary cadence driver | 1 Week | Cheetah UI team |
|  |  |  |  |  |

The following diagram shows how various components can be aligned on the release train. Notice how each team follows its own cadence while some are aligned to the UI team’s cadence:

In summary,

metadata.title: (DRAFT) RFC-NEB-02: Release management, Software Testing and Versioning guidelines for Customer Projects

content:
how each team follows its own cadence while some are aligned to the UI team’s cadence:

In summary,

- All component releases should be coordinated to avoid mismatched versions.
- Minor updates outside the release train must be thoroughly tested in UAT and approved by Production Release Approvers.
- Release notes should clearly indicate component versions, dependencies, and owners.

## 5. Roles & Responsibilities (RACI Overview)

The following roles are used for assigning responsibilities and accountability for various stages of the release process:

metadata.title: (DRAFT) RFC-NEB-02: Release management, Software Testing and Versioning guidelines for Customer Projects

content:
re used for assigning responsibilities and accountability for various stages of the release process:

- Nebula: Oversees technical standards, code review until handing over to CX IT, and complex environment setups.
- CX-IT / CX Lead: Owns customer environment approvals and production release control after CX IT handover.
- Delivery Team: Writes, tests, and promotes code; ensures adherence to SOP.
- Delivery Team/Solution Architects: Validates data schema, models, and data integrity in all environments.
- Customer Stakeholders: Review and approve UAT releases.
- Production Release Approvers: Authorize deployment to Production. This will typically be the CX IT lead, the Delivery Manager, and the Solution Architect.
- Product Teams: Owns product version upgrades, patches, testing, and releases in customer environments.
- Foundry Team: Owns infrastructure components such as Kubernetes clusters, Airflow packages, Azure environments, GitHub Actions pipelines, etc.

content:
This document explains how environment variables are configured, deployed, and made available to Airflow DAGs and Databricks tasks in our pipeline infrastructure.

---

## Overview

Environment variables flow through four stages before reaching your Databricks tasks:

```
┌─────────────────────┐     ┌─────────────────────┐     ┌─────────────────────┐     ┌─────────────────────┐
│  branch-config.yml  │ ──► │      .env.tpl       │ ──► │  Kubernetes         │ ──► │  Databricks         │
│  (Define values)    │     │  (Template file)    │     │  ConfigMap          │     │  spark_env_vars     │
└─────────────────────┘     └─────────────────────┘     └─────────────────────┘     └─────────────────────┘

```

---

## Stage 1: Define Variable Values in branch-config.yml

The `branch-config.yml` file in your customer pipeline repository defines environment-specific variable values.

Location: `customer-pipeline-<customer>/branch-config.yml`

Example:

metadata.title: Environment Variables Flow: From CI/CD to Databricks Tasks

content:
ment-specific variable values.

Location: `customer-pipeline-<customer>/branch-config.yml`

Example:

```
branches:
  main:
    input_bucket_name: "invent-{{ customer_name }}-input"
    output_bucket_name: "invent-{{ customer_name }}-output"
    filestore_bucket_name: "invent-{{ customer_name }}-filestore"

  uat:
    input_bucket_name: "invent-{{ customer_name }}-input-uat"
    output_bucket_name: "invent-{{ customer_name }}-output-uat"
    filestore_bucket_name: "invent-{{ customer_name }}-filestore-uat"

default:
  input_bucket_name: "invent-{{ customer_name }}-input-dev"
  output_bucket_name: "invent-{{ customer_name }}-output-dev"
  filestore_bucket_name: "invent-{{ customer_name }}-filestore-dev"

```

Key Points:

- Use Jinja2 templating ({{ customer_name }}, {{ branch_name }}) for dynamic values
- Branch-specific configurations override the default block
- Variable names are lowercase with underscores (they get uppercased automatically)

---

metadata.title: Environment Variables Flow: From CI/CD to Databricks Tasks

content:
fault block
- Variable names are lowercase with underscores (they get uppercased automatically)

---

## Stage 2: Create Variable Placeholders in .env.tpl

The `.env.tpl` file is a template that maps environment variables to their runtime values.

Location: `customer-pipeline-<customer>/.env.tpl`

Example:

```
INPUT_BUCKET_NAME=${INPUT_BUCKET_NAME}
OUTPUT_BUCKET_NAME=${OUTPUT_BUCKET_NAME}
DATASTORE_BUCKET_NAME=${DATASTORE_BUCKET_NAME}
FILESTORE_BUCKET_NAME=${FILESTORE_BUCKET_NAME}
ROCKS_ENV=${ROCKS_ENV}
POKEDEX_ENVIRONMENT=${POKEDEX_ENVIRONMENT}

```

Key Points:

- Variable names must be UPPERCASE
- Format is VAR_NAME=${VAR_NAME} (the right side references the shell environment variable)
- The envsubst command expands these placeholders during CI/CD

---

## Stage 3: CI/CD Pipeline Processing

During the GitHub Actions workflow, the following happens:

### 3.1 Process Configuration

The `process-config` composite action:

metadata.title: Environment Variables Flow: From CI/CD to Databricks Tasks

content:
kflow, the following happens:

### 3.1 Process Configuration

The `process-config` composite action:

1. Reads branch-config.yml
2. Renders Jinja2 templates with context (customer_name, branch_name, etc.)
3. Converts keys to UPPERCASE
4. Exports all variables to GITHUB_ENV

### 3.2 Generate .env File

```
cat .env.tpl | envsubst > .env

```

This substitutes all `${VAR_NAME}` placeholders with actual values.

### 3.3 Create Kubernetes ConfigMap

```
kubectl create configmap env-vars --from-env-file=.env -n <namespace>

```

This creates/updates a ConfigMap named `env-vars` containing all variables.

Note: Airflow pods must be restarted to pick up ConfigMap changes. The deployment workflow handles this automatically.

---

## Stage 4: Pass Variables to Databricks Tasks

Variables in the ConfigMap are available in the Airflow container, but not automatically in Databricks. You must explicitly pass them via `spark_env_vars`.

metadata.title: Environment Variables Flow: From CI/CD to Databricks Tasks

content:
container, but not automatically in Databricks. You must explicitly pass them via `spark_env_vars`.

Location: `customer-pipeline-<customer>/dags/config/main.yaml`

Example:

```
providers:
  azure:
    runtimes:
      spark3:
        resources:
          DatabricksJobCluster:
            new_cluster:
              spark_env_vars:
                INPUT_BUCKET_NAME: ${oc.env:INPUT_BUCKET_NAME}
                OUTPUT_BUCKET_NAME: ${oc.env:OUTPUT_BUCKET_NAME}
                DATASTORE_BUCKET_NAME: ${oc.env:DATASTORE_BUCKET_NAME}
                FILESTORE_BUCKET_NAME: ${oc.env:FILESTORE_BUCKET_NAME}  # Add new vars here
                ROCKS_ENV: ${oc.env:ROCKS_ENV}

```

Key Points:

- ${oc.env:VAR_NAME} reads from the Airflow container's environment (OmegaConf syntax)
- You can provide defaults: ${oc.env:VAR_NAME, default_value}
- Add the variable to ALL cluster configurations:DatabricksJobClusterDatabricksExistingJobClusterDatabricksMultiTaskJobCluster (including all job_clusters)

metadata.title: Environment Variables Flow: From CI/CD to Databricks Tasks

content:
icksJobClusterDatabricksExistingJobClusterDatabricksMultiTaskJobCluster (including all job_clusters)

---

## Adding a New Environment Variable: Checklist

When adding a new variable (e.g., `FILESTORE_BUCKET_NAME`), update these files:

| File | Action | Example |
| --- | --- | --- |
| branch-config.yml | Add variable with value | filestore_bucket_name: "my-bucket" |
| .env.tpl | Add placeholder | FILESTORE_BUCKET_NAME=${FILESTORE_BUCKET_NAME} |
| dags/config/main.yaml | Add to all spark_env_vars blocks | FILESTORE_BUCKET_NAME: ${oc.env:FILESTORE_BUCKET_NAME} |

---

## Accessing Variables in Code

### In Airflow DAGs (Python)

```
import os

bucket_name = os.environ.get('FILESTORE_BUCKET_NAME')
# or
bucket_name = os.environ['FILESTORE_BUCKET_NAME']

```

### In Databricks Tasks (PySpark)

```
import os

# Available because it's in spark_env_vars
bucket_name = os.environ.get('FILESTORE_BUCKET_NAME')

```

### In DAG Configuration (YAML with OmegaConf)

metadata.title: Environment Variables Flow: From CI/CD to Databricks Tasks

content:
_name = os.environ.get('FILESTORE_BUCKET_NAME')

```

### In DAG Configuration (YAML with OmegaConf)

```
global_settings:
  filestore_bucket: ${oc.env:FILESTORE_BUCKET_NAME}

```

---

## Troubleshooting

### Variable not available in Airflow

1. Check GitHub Actions logs for "Process Branch Configuration" step
2. Verify the variable appears in GITHUB_ENV output
3. Check "Setup .env" step - does cat .env show the variable?
4. Verify ConfigMap was updated: kubectl get configmap env-vars -n <namespace> -o yaml
5. Restart Airflow pods if ConfigMap was updated after pod creation

### Variable not available in Databricks

1. Confirm variable is in Airflow environment first (see above)
2. Check dags/config/main.yaml - is the variable in spark_env_vars?
3. Verify you added it to all cluster configurations being used
4. Check for typos in variable names (case-sensitive)

### Variable has wrong value

metadata.title: Environment Variables Flow: From CI/CD to Databricks Tasks

content:
tions being used
4. Check for typos in variable names (case-sensitive)

### Variable has wrong value

1. Check which branch configuration is being used (see workflow logs)
2. Verify the correct branch block exists in branch-config.yml
3. If using default block unintentionally, add your branch explicitly

---

content:
This guide explains how to configure long-running UAT and Dev environments for your customer pipeline using the GitHub Actions CI/CD workflow.

---

## Overview

The CI/CD pipeline supports multiple environments through branch-based configuration. Each branch can have its own:

- Kubernetes namespace
- Storage buckets (input, output, datastore)
- Pokedex environment (metadata store)
- Logging and monitoring tags
- Cluster configurations

---

## Quick Start: Adding a UAT Environment

### Step 1: Add UAT Configuration to branch-config.yml

Add a `uat` block to your `branch-config.yml` file:

```
branches:
  # ... existing branches ...

  uat:
    # Storage buckets - use separate buckets or suffixed buckets for isolation
    input_bucket_name: "invent-{{ customer_name }}-input-uat"
    output_bucket_name: "invent-{{ customer_name }}-output-uat"
    datastore_bucket_name: "invent-{{ customer_name }}-datastore-uat"

metadata.title: Setting Up UAT and Dev Environments

content:
{ customer_name }}-output-uat"
    datastore_bucket_name: "invent-{{ customer_name }}-datastore-uat"

    # Environment identifiers
    rocks_env: "uat"
    pokedex_environment: "uat"  # or "prod" if sharing metadata with production

    # Kubernetes namespace - separate namespace for UAT
    k8s_namespace: "{{ customer_name }}-uat"

    # Image environment tag
    image_env: "uat"

    # Logging
    log_level: "INFO"

    # Kubernetes cluster (use same cluster, different namespace)
    k8s_cluster: prod-eu
    k8s_cluster_rg: prod-eu-rg

    # Cloud provider
    cloud_provider: azure
    customer_environment: prod-eu

    # Customer subdomain for Airflow UI access
    customer_subdomain: "uat"

    # Optional: Maps database secret (if using Maps)
    maps_database_secret_id: "invent-{{ customer_name }}-maps-uat"

```

### Step 2: Add Variables to .env.tpl

Ensure all environment-specific variables are in your `.env.tpl`:

metadata.title: Setting Up UAT and Dev Environments
Setting Up UAT and Dev Environments

content:
IRONMENT}
                # ... other variables ...

```

### Step 4: Create and Push the UAT Branch

```
git checkout main
git pull origin main
git checkout -b uat
git push -u origin uat

```

The CI/CD pipeline will automatically:

1. Detect the uat branch
2. Apply the uat configuration from branch-config.yml
3. Deploy to a separate {{ customer_name }}-uat namespace

---

## Adding a Dev Environment

Follow the same steps as UAT, but with dev-specific settings:

```
branches:
  dev:
    input_bucket_name: "invent-{{ customer_name }}-input-dev"
    output_bucket_name: "invent-{{ customer_name }}-output-dev"
    datastore_bucket_name: "invent-{{ customer_name }}-datastore-dev"

    rocks_env: "dev"
    pokedex_environment: "dev"

    k8s_namespace: "{{ customer_name }}-dev"
    image_env: "dev"

    # More verbose logging for development
    log_level: "DEBUG"

metadata.title: Setting Up UAT and Dev Environments

content:
name }}-dev"
    image_env: "dev"

    # More verbose logging for development
    log_level: "DEBUG"

    k8s_cluster: prod-eu
    k8s_cluster_rg: prod-eu-rg
    cloud_provider: azure
    customer_environment: prod-eu
    customer_subdomain: "dev"

    maps_database_secret_id: "{{ customer_name }}-dev-app"

```

---

## Environment Configuration Reference

### Key Variables Explained

metadata.title: Setting Up UAT and Dev Environments

content:
omer_name }}-dev-app"

```

---

## Environment Configuration Reference

### Key Variables Explained

| Variable | Description | Example Values |
| --- | --- | --- |
| rocks_env | Runtime environment identifier. Used for logging, metrics, MLflow, and path isolation. | prod, uat, dev, feature-xyz |
| pokedex_environment | Metadata service environment. Controls which Pokedex instance to use. | prod, uat, dev, wba |
| k8s_namespace | Kubernetes namespace for Airflow deployment. Must be unique per environment. | customer-prod, customer-uat |
| image_env | Tag used for Docker images. | prod, uat, dev |
| customer_subdomain | Subdomain for Airflow UI access. | prod, uat, dev |
| log_level | Logging verbosity. | INFO, DEBUG, WARNING |

### ROCKS_ENV Impact

Setting `ROCKS_ENV` affects:

metadata.title: Setting Up UAT and Dev Environments

content:
el | Logging verbosity. | INFO, DEBUG, WARNING |

### ROCKS_ENV Impact

Setting `ROCKS_ENV` affects:

| Feature | prod | uat/dev/other |
| --- | --- | --- |
| MLflow Experiment | /Shared/prod | /Shared/playground |
| Log Tags | environment:prod | environment:uat |
| Config Path | .../src/prod/... | .../src/uat/... |
| DataDog Metrics | Tagged with prod | Tagged with uat |

### POKEDEX_ENVIRONMENT Considerations

- Shared Metadata: Set pokedex_environment: "prod" to share metadata (products, stores, etc.) with production
- Isolated Metadata: Set pokedex_environment: "uat" for completely isolated metadata (requires UAT Pokedex setup)

Recommendation: For most UAT environments, use `pokedex_environment: "prod"` to share master data with production while keeping runtime data separate.

---

## Feature Branch Environments

For temporary feature branches, use the `default` configuration or create specific entries:

metadata.title: Setting Up UAT and Dev Environments

content:
onments

For temporary feature branches, use the `default` configuration or create specific entries:

```
branches:
  feature-ml-experiment:
    input_bucket_name: "invent-{{ customer_name }}-input-dev"
    output_bucket_name: "invent-{{ customer_name }}-output-dev"
    datastore_bucket_name: "invent-{{ customer_name }}-datastore-dev"

    rocks_env: "{{ branch_name }}"  # Uses branch name as environment
    pokedex_environment: "dev"

    k8s_namespace: "{{ customer_name }}-{{ branch_name }}"
    image_env: "dev"
    log_level: "DEBUG"

    # ... other settings ...

# Fallback for unlisted feature branches
default:
  input_bucket_name: "invent-{{ customer_name }}-input-dev"
  output_bucket_name: "invent-{{ customer_name }}-output-dev"
  datastore_bucket_name: "invent-{{ customer_name }}-datastore-dev"

  rocks_env: "{{ branch_name }}"
  pokedex_environment: "dev"

  k8s_namespace: "{{ customer_name }}-{{ branch_name }}"
  image_env: "dev"
  log_level: "DEBUG"

metadata.title: Setting Up UAT and Dev Environments

content:
v"

  k8s_namespace: "{{ customer_name }}-{{ branch_name }}"
  image_env: "dev"
  log_level: "DEBUG"

  # ... other settings ...

```

---

    input_bucket_name: "invent-{{ customer_name }}-input"

## Deployment Workflow

```

---

## Deployment Workflow

```
┌─────────────────┐     ┌─────────────────┐     ┌─────────────────┐
│   Push to uat   │ ──► │  CI/CD Pipeline │ ──► │  K8s Namespace  │
│     branch      │     │  reads config   │     │  customer-uat   │
└─────────────────┘     └─────────────────┘     └─────────────────┘
                               │
                               ▼
                        ┌─────────────────┐
                        │ Applies UAT     │
                        │ configuration:  │
                        │ - buckets       │
                        │ - ROCKS_ENV     │
                        │ - namespace     │
                        └─────────────────┘

```

---

## Accessing Your Environments

After deployment, access Airflow UI at:

metadata.title: Setting Up UAT and Dev Environments

content:
────────────────┘

```

---

## Accessing Your Environments

After deployment, access Airflow UI at:

- Production: https://{{ customer_subdomain }}.airflow.inventanalytics.com
- UAT: https://{{ customer_subdomain }}-uat.airflow.inventanalytics.com
- Dev: https://{{ customer_subdomain }}-dev.airflow.inventanalytics.com

(Exact URLs depend on your ingress configuration)

---

## Checklist: New Environment Setup

- [ ] Add branch configuration to branch-config.yml
- [ ] Verify all required variables are in .env.tpl
- [ ] Ensure spark_env_vars in main.yaml includes new variables (if any)
- [ ] Create storage buckets (input, output, datastore) if using separate buckets
- [ ] Create the branch and push to trigger deployment
- [ ] Verify deployment in GitHub Actions logs
- [ ] Verify Airflow pods are running: kubectl get pods -n {{ namespace }}
- [ ] Access Airflow UI and verify configuration

---

## Troubleshooting

### Environment variables not appearing in Databricks

metadata.title: Setting Up UAT and Dev Environments

content:
verify configuration

---

## Troubleshooting

### Environment variables not appearing in Databricks

1. Check that the variable is in branch-config.yml
2. Check that the variable is in .env.tpl
3. Check that spark_env_vars in main.yaml includes the variable
4. Restart Airflow pods after ConfigMap updates

### Wrong configuration being applied

1. Check GitHub Actions logs for "Process Branch Configuration" step
2. Verify your branch name matches exactly in branch-config.yml
3. If no match, the default block is used

### Namespace already exists errors

This is normal for updates. The pipeline handles existing namespaces gracefully.

# config.yml
---
# 1. STORAGE & INPUT PATHS
storage:
  provider: azure
  account: invent-tecovas-shared
  container: invent-tecovas-input
  base_path: history/

file_format: csv

suffix: ""     # resolved at runtime via run_date

# 2. TABLES TO VALIDATE
tables_to_validate:
  - product
  - store
  - warehouse

# 3. VALIDATION RULES (Overrides Pokedex defaults or Add new Rules)
validation_rules:
  product:
    key: product_feed
    not_nullable_cols:
      - product_code
      - option_code
    not_negative_cols:
      - price_without_tax
      - tax_rate
      - cogs
    change_threshold: 0.15
    history_offsets: [1, 7]
    check_history:
      "*":
        - function: count
          alias: row_count
      product_code:
        - function: countDistinct
          alias: distinct_products
    cross_check:
      dest_table: store
      source_columns: [destination_code]
      dest_columns: [store_code]

I'll be updating this page as I progress through the onboarding process for the Indomaret project. Please note, this is an internal Nebula team page and not an official customer project page.

---

Project kickoff meeting.

Quicks Notes:

- First daily data is expected at 9 PM (UTC+03:00).
- Input folder is created by Invent as empty, and filled by the customer from multiple sources.

---

The input folder is expected to contain four manifest files: `manifest_1`, `manifest_2`, `manifest_3`, and `manifest_4`. As a result, the `customer_input_sensor` has been updated to look for these four specific manifest files, rather than a single `manifest` file, in order to proceed to the next task in the `daily_runner` DAG. Find the [commit](https://github.com/inventanalytics/customer-pipeline-indomaret/commit/b87fc00badcd976e396a35f1380721fc00fe50de) here.

    def _customer_input_sensor_func(self, input_key_prefix: str = None, kwargs):
        """
        Checks if the customer input is available.
        """

        dag_run = kwargs["dag_run"]

        _check_parallel_sensors(
            "between_batches_timeout_sensor",
            "end_of_day_timeout_sensor", dag_run=dag_run,
        )

        try:
            LOG.info(f"Poking for: {input_key_prefix}")
            prefixes = self.storage_driver.get_prefix_list(input_key_prefix)
        except ValueError:
            LOG.warning(f"No folder is found with input_key_prefix: {input_key_prefix}. "
                        "Continue searching...")
            return False

content:
This document explains the configuration and execution logic used for ingesting and processing historical tables with custom/default PreETL extensions and DataFeed pipelines.
It supports customer-specific classes (e.g. `CitiTrendsRetailPrice`) and can dynamically detect and run them.

---

## 🧠 Purpose

This script allows you to:

- Dynamically load the appropriate PreETL class (custom or base),
- Read and combine all historical .csv files for a table,
- Execute custom PreETL logic (transformations, aggregations, column mappings, etc.),
- Write processed data to the feed folder, and
- Automatically trigger the DataFeed process to push results to the operation layer.

It is especially useful for one-time historical backfills where multiple CSVs must be ingested together.

---

## 🧩 Step-by-Step Explanation

### 1. Import and Environment Setup

metadata.title: 🕓 Historical Data Ingestion Guide

content:
must be ingested together.

---

## 🧩 Step-by-Step Explanation

### 1. Import and Environment Setup

```
from rocks.core.pipeline import load_pipeline_step_class
from rocks.opal.pre_etl import PreETL
from rocks.opal.data_feed_new import DataFeedNew

```

The script imports base Rocks classes and utilities for dynamically loading pipeline steps.
A local Rocks extension path is added to `sys.path` to allow imports of customer-specific modules:

```
rocks_extension_path = "/dbfs/FileStore/src/dev"
if rocks_extension_path not in sys.path:
    sys.path.insert(0, rocks_extension_path)

```

---

### 2. Define Runtime Parameters

```
customer_prefix = "CitiTrends"
table_name = "retail_price"
csv_delimiter = "|"
run_date = datetime.now().strftime("%Y-%m-%d")
history_base_path = "/mnt/invent-cititrends-input-dev/mfp_files"
history_table_wildcard_pattern = ".csv"
wildcard_path = f"{history_base_path}/{table_name}{history_table_wildcard_pattern}"

```

metadata.title: 🕓 Historical Data Ingestion Guide

content:
rn = ".csv"
wildcard_path = f"{history_base_path}/{table_name}{history_table_wildcard_pattern}"

```

| Parameter | Description |
| --- | --- |
| customer_prefix | Used to construct the custom class name (e.g. CitiTrendsRetailPrice) |
| table_name | Table to process (e.g. retail_price, goods_in_transit) |
| history_base_path | Input directory containing historical CSVs |
| history_table_wildcard_pattern | Pattern used to read multiple files at once |
| run_date | Logical date for processing |
| csv_delimiter | Field delimiter used in source files |

* `wildcard_path` is a file path pattern that uses wildcards (like `*` or `?`) to match multiple files or folders dynamically instead of specifying each path explicitly.

---

### 3. Dynamic Class Detection

The helper function determines which PreETL class to use:

metadata.title: 🕓 Historical Data Ingestion Guide

content:
tly.

---

### 3. Dynamic Class Detection

The helper function determines which PreETL class to use:

```
def get_pre_etl_class(table_name, customer_prefix="CitiTrends", custom_classes_map=None):
    """
    Dynamically load PreETL class - tries custom first, falls back to base.
    """

```

It tries to load:

1. A custom class from rocks_extension.opal.pre_etl.<table_name>→ e.g. rocks_extension.opal.pre_etl.retail_price.CitiTrendsRetailPrice
2. If not found, falls back to the base PreETL class from rocks.opal.pre_etl.

This logic ensures that any customer-specific preprocessing logic runs automatically when defined.

```
PreETLClass = get_pre_etl_class(table_name, customer_prefix)
print(f"✅ Successfully imported {PreETLClass.__name__}")

```

---

### 4. Read and Combine Historical Files

The script reads and merges all historical CSVs for the target table:

```
combined_df = spark.read.csv(
    wildcard_path,
    header=True,
    sep=csv_delimiter,
    inferSchema=False
)
```

metadata.title: 🕓 Historical Data Ingestion Guide

content:
ark.read.csv(
    wildcard_path,
    header=True,
    sep=csv_delimiter,
    inferSchema=False
)
```

* The `wildcard_path` points to the main directory containing all parts of the same CSV (for example, daily or partitioned slices of a table). The script reads every matching file and combines them into a single DataFrame.

---

### 5. Optional Raw Data Transformations

This is the place to apply any pre-processing or cleanup logic on the raw historical DataFrame before running PreETL.

```
# Run any transformations on raw dataframe here.
combined_df = combined_df.withColumn(
    "product_agg_level_code",
    F.regexp_replace("product_agg_level_code", r'^[0]*', "")
)

```

#### 💡 Explanation:

metadata.title: 🕓 Historical Data Ingestion Guide

content:
evel_code",
    F.regexp_replace("product_agg_level_code", r'^[0]*', "")
)

```

#### 💡 Explanation:

- The above example removes leading zeros from the product_agg_level_code column.
- You can perform any kind of transformation here depending on the structure of your raw CSVs, such as:Renaming columnsCasting data typesHandling null valuesNormalizing codesAdding or dropping columnsFiltering invalid records

> 🧩 This section acts as a sandbox for one-time data fixes before the PreETL step runs.Use it carefully to align historical CSV structures with expected Pokedex schemas.

---

### 6. Run Pre-ETL

A unique `run_id` is generated, and the detected class executes its transformation logic:

metadata.title: 🕓 Historical Data Ingestion Guide

content:
n Pre-ETL

A unique `run_id` is generated, and the detected class executes its transformation logic:

```
run_id = f"{run_date}-{table_name}-{datetime.now().strftime('%Y%m%d_%H%M%S')}"
pre_etl = PreETLClass(
    config_section=f"pre_etl_{table_name}",
    raw_data_path=history_base_path + "/",
    run_date=run_date,
    run_id=run_id,
    csv_delimiter=csv_delimiter
)
input_data = {'raw': combined_df}
result = pre_etl.main(input_data=input_data)
pre_etl.write(result)

```

✅ Outcome:
Transformed data is written to the feed layer (e.g.
`/mnt/invent-cititrends-datastore-dev/feed/<table_name>/run_id=<run_id>`).

---

### 7. Run DataFeed

After PreETL completes, the DataFeedNew step pushes the data into the operation layer:

```
data_feed = DataFeedNew(
    config_section=f"data_feed_{table_name}",
    run_id=run_id,
    run_date=run_date,
)
data_feed.run()

```

✅ Outcome:
Operation table updated at
`/mnt/invent-cititrends-datastore-dev/operation/<table_name>`

---

metadata.title: 🕓 Historical Data Ingestion Guide

content:
tcome:
Operation table updated at
`/mnt/invent-cititrends-datastore-dev/operation/<table_name>`

---

### 8. Logging and Error Handling

The script logs:

- The loaded PreETL class name
- Total rows processed
- Run IDs for traceabilityIf any error occurs, the stack trace is printed for debugging.

---

## 💡 Tips & Customization

- To process a different table, just update:table_name = "cost"
- To use a specific transformation logic, define a custom class under:rocks_extension/opal/pre_etl/cost.py
with a matching name pattern:class CitiTrendsCost(PreETL):
    def main(self, input_data):
        ...
- You can pass a custom mapping (custom_classes_map) to manually control which module/class to load.

| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| 1 | Read all historical CSVs | Spark | Combined raw DataFrame |
| 2 | Transform with PreETL | Custom or base PreETL | Feed Delta Table |
| 3 | Feed to operation layer | DataFeedNew | Operation Delta Table |

Key Assets and Configuration for Customer PipelinesMain assets(artifacts) to know while starting:

- Customer Pipelines
- Internal Libraries that are used in the Customer Pipelines
- The Environment such as cloud resources(AWS, Azure, Airflow, Jenkins, Github)

Customer Pipelines

Purpose:

- clean and organize the customer input files for the Invent’s various products
- Create necessary stage files for the models process
- Create final output files as results to be shared with the customer

Very high level: Get the data => Enrich => Output

2. Fabbrica: where the dags are managed Fabbrica Reference

content:
### Beymen Data Lineage Overview

The data follows a path from raw customer inputs to optimized replenishment decisions and final reporting.

#### 1. Data Ingestion (Raw Sources)

The lineage begins with raw CSV files uploaded by Beymen to Azure Blob Storage.

- Source Path: wasbs://${INPUT_BUCKET_NAME}@.../

- Key Entities: product.csv, store.csv, inventory.csv, transactional_sales.csv, purchase_order.csv, open_orders.csv, and price.csv.

- Configuration: Defined in scripts/opal/config.yaml.

#### 2. Pre-ETL (Custom Transformations)

Beymen-specific business logic is applied during the `pre_etl` phase to clean and standardize the raw data.

- Extensions: Custom logic is implemented in rocks_extension/opal/pre_etl/.

- Warehouse/Store/Product: BeymenWarehouse, BeymenStore, BeymenProduct.

- Inventory/Sales: BeymenInventory, BeymenTransactionalSales.

- Result: Standardized Parquet files stored in the "feed" layer of the Datastore.

#### 3. Data Integration (The Data Catalog)

metadata.title: Sample Data Lineage of a Customer Project

content:
quet files stored in the "feed" layer of the Datastore.

#### 3. Data Integration (The Data Catalog)

The `update_datastore` phase integrates the "feed" data into the Rocks Data Catalog.

- Process: Internal IDs are assigned to products, stores, and warehouses.

- Lineage Point: This is where data becomes "ready for optimization." It links external codes to internal Invent Analytics identifiers.

#### 4. Demand Forecasting (Noob)

The Noob sub-pipeline generates demand forecasts.

- Customization: BeymenProductAggLevelGenerator (in rocks_extension/noob/) defines how Beymen's product hierarchy (Attributes, Categories) is used to aggregate sales for forecasting.

- Flow: noob_etl → noob_daily → noob_forecast_selection → noob_reporting.

#### 5. Optimization & Replenishment (Rocket & Enigma)

This stage generates the recommended orders.

- Engine: rocket_pandas orchestrates the optimization.

- Models: Optimization models are run using enigma logic (integrated via Docker images).

metadata.title: Sample Data Lineage of a Customer Project

content:
imization.

- Models: Optimization models are run using enigma logic (integrated via Docker images).

- StoreReplenishmentModel: Generates orders for stores.

- DCReplenishmentModel: Generates orders for DCs.

- AdhocAllocationModel: Handles manual or one-time allocation requests.

- Inputs: Data Catalog (Inventory/Orders) + Noob Forecasts.

#### 6. User Interface & Review (Omega UI)

Data is prepared for Beymen planners to review and edit in the Omega UI.

- Modules: prep_cost_units, prep_price_units, store_inventory, store_rpl_orders.

- Extensions: BeymenProductMasterIntegration and BeymenStoreMasterIntegration ensure the UI displays the correct product and store metadata.

#### 7. Data Sinks (Final Outputs)

The final step is exporting the decisions back to Beymen's systems or for reporting.

- Customer Outputs: BeymenAllocationOutput (in rocks_extension/opal/allocation_send_output.py) formats and writes the final allocation results to the output bucket.

metadata.title: Sample Data Lineage of a Customer Project

content:
pal/allocation_send_output.py) formats and writes the final allocation results to the output bucket.

- Reporting: BeymenStoreProductHistoricReport generates historical SKU-level reports by joining Inventory, Sales, and Open Orders.

- Output Path: wasbs://${OUTPUT_BUCKET_NAME}@.../ad-hoc-allocation-customer-results/

content:
| Raw Column (Beymen) | Type | Transformation Logic (BeymenTransactionalSales) |
| --- | --- | --- |
| sales_id | string | Used as the invoice/receipt ID. For E-commerce rows, this is mapped from order_code. |
| store_code | string | Physical store ID. For E-commerce rows, this is forced to '2009'. |
| product_code | string | SKU code. Mapped directly. |
| sales_date | date | Filtered to only include data from yesterday (run_date - 1) and the same day last week (run_date - 7). |
| sales_quantity | float | Sales quantity. Mapped directly. |
| sales_revenue | float | Revenue excluding tax. Mapped directly. |
| sales_type | string | Normalized: "POS SATIŞ" $\rightarrow$ "regular", "POS İADE" $\rightarrow$ "return". |
| sales_channel | string | "Internet" rows are filtered out from the raw CSV because they are unified later from ecom_order.csv. |
| is_tourist | string | Converted: 'E' (Yes) $\rightarrow$ 1, 'H' (No) $\rightarrow$ 0. |

metadata.title: Column Level Lineage - transactional_sales.csv

content:
der.csv. |
| is_tourist | string | Converted: 'E' (Yes) $\rightarrow$ 1, 'H' (No) $\rightarrow$ 0. |
| is_bulk_sales | string | Converted: 'E' (Yes) $\rightarrow$ 1, 'H' (No) $\rightarrow$ 0. |

### 2. Processing Logic (rocks_extension)

In `rocks_extension/opal/pre_etl/transactional_sales.py`, the following steps occur:

- E-commerce Integration: It reads ecom_order.csv, sets the store to '2009', channel to 'Internet', and currency to 'TRY', then performs a union with the physical sales data.
- Unique ID Generation: A system-wide unique transaction_id is created by joining a row number with the sales_id (e.g., 1_invoice123).
- Date Filtering: It strictly limits the data to the specific dates required for the incremental run to ensure processing speed.

### 3. Data Catalog (Feed Layer: transactional_sales_feed)

The processed data is saved as a Delta table in the Datastore with this finalized schema:

metadata.title: Column Level Lineage - transactional_sales.csv

content:
les_feed)

The processed data is saved as a Delta table in the Datastore with this finalized schema:

| Final Column | Description |
| --- | --- |
| transaction_id | Unique row-level identifier. |
| sales_id | Original receipt/order number. |
| sales_date | Date of sale. |
| store_code | Store identifier (2009 for Web). |
| product_code | Product SKU identifier. |
| sales_quantity | Number of units sold. |
| sales_revenue | Revenue (Net of tax). |
| sales_type | Classification (regular/return/promo). |
| sales_channel | Channel (Retail or Internet). |
| is_bulk_sales | Boolean (0/1) flag for bulk orders. |

### 4. Downstream Usage

- Noob (Forecasting): Aggregates these sales into daily_data to calculate demand trends.
- Omega UI: Displays these historical sales in the Alerts Review and Forecast Review screens.
- Enigma (Optimization): Uses the sales history to calculate stock-out risks and replenishment needs.

metadata.title: Column Level Lineage - transactional_sales.csv

content:
The daily_runner DAG controls the customer input workflow that runs before the main daily DAG. Its responsibilities include waiting for customer input using a sensor, validating the input by checking the manifest against the delivered files, moving the input folder to backup and history locations, and finally triggering the daily DAG.

notee2c2e50e8436In some cases, customers may want to deliver their data in a non-standard way. When this happens, the daily_runner DAG requires additional customization to support those requirements.

In some cases, customers may want to deliver their data in a non-standard way. When this happens, the daily_runner DAG requires additional customization to support those requirements.

This document demonstrates such a customization using a real-life example from the Indomaret project, to make the daily_runner behavior easier to understand.

### Preparing the Daily Runner for Customization

ke the daily_runner behavior easier to understand.

### Preparing the Daily Runner for Customization

Before implementing any customization in the `daily_runner` workflow, a project-specific daily runner must be set up.

First, ensure that a `daily_runner.py` file exists under the `/dags` directory for the customer. Within this file, define a customer-specific class following the naming convention `<CustomerName>DailyRunner`. For this project, the class is named `IndomaretDailyRunner`.

This class must inherit from the base `DailyRunnerDAG` class provided by the `fabbrica_plugin_invent.opal.dags.daily_runner` library. This inheritance allows the project to reuse the default daily runner behavior while selectively overriding specific parts of the workflow.

metadata.title: Customizing daily_runner DAG With An Example

content:
reuse the default daily runner behavior while selectively overriding specific parts of the workflow.

To customize a particular behavior, identify the method in the default `DailyRunnerDAG` that needs to be modified. Copy this method into the customer-specific class and apply the required changes there. The copied method will override the default implementation, allowing the customized logic to be executed for this customer while leaving the base daily runner unchanged for others.

```
from fabbrica_plugin_invent.opal.dags.daily_runner import DailyRunnerDAG

class IndomaretDailyRunner(DailyRunnerDAG):
    """
    IndomaretDailyRunner
    """

        pass

with IndomaretDailyRunner(config_path="/etc/airflow/dags/config").dag() as daily_dag:
    pass
```

### Indomaret Project Overview

In the Indomaret project, the customer delivers files from four different sources. Each source sends its own data files along with its own manifest file.

By default, the input sensor in daily_runner waits for a single file named `manifest` to appear in the expected input directory. Once the manifest is detected, the workflow proceeds to the next steps.

metadata.title: Customizing daily_runner DAG With An Example

content:
he expected input directory. Once the manifest is detected, the workflow proceeds to the next steps.

However, for the Indomaret project, the customer delivers four separate manifest files (`manifest_1` through `manifest_4`). These manifests are sent independently, at different times, and by different sources. As a result, the input sensor must be modified to wait until all four manifest files are present in the input folder before continuing the process.

For each manifest:

- A unique task ID is generated (check_manifest_1, check_manifest_2, etc.).
- A task configuration is created using the appropriate validation command.
- The task is registered with the current DAG.
- Each generated task is appended to manifest_tasks, allowing the method to return all validation tasks as a group.

```
    return manifest_tasks
```

The function returns a list of tasks rather than a single operator, reflecting the need to validate multiple manifests.

```
manifest_tasks = [
    dag.get_task(f'check_manifest_{i}')
    for i in range(1, 5)
]
```

Here, the DAG retrieves each dynamically created manifest validation task by name.
This makes it easy to treat all four checks as a logical group without manually referencing each one.

```
check_manifest = EmptyOperator(
    task_id='check_manifest',
    dag=dag,
)

metadata.title: Customizing daily_runner DAG With An Example

content:
erencing each one.

```
check_manifest = EmptyOperator(
    task_id='check_manifest',
    dag=dag,
)

after_check_manifest = EmptyOperator(
    task_id='after_check_manifest',
    dag=dag,
)
```

Two `EmptyOperator`s are used to:

- check_manifest: act as a logical entry point before any manifest validation begins.
- after_check_manifest: act as a synchronization point after all manifest checks complete.

These operators don’t perform work themselves but help structure dependencies and improve DAG readability.

```
check_manifest >> manifest_tasks >> after_check_manifest
```

This dependency chain ensures:

1. The DAG reaches the check_manifest checkpoint.
2. All four manifest validation tasks run (in parallel).
3. The workflow only proceeds once every manifest has been successfully validated.

#### Handling Extra Files Check

> Info: By default, the check_manifest checks for extra files that are present in the folder but not listed in the manifest as well as it checks for missing files listed in the manifest.

In the Indomaret scenario, each manifest only lists the files for its respective source. This means that files from other sources would incorrectly be flagged as “extra” when validating a single manifest. To handle this correctly, the extra file validation must be disabled, while still ensuring that all required files listed in each manifest are present.

I added the `--ignore-unexpected-files` flag to address extra file validation.

I added the `--ignore-unexpected-files` flag to address extra file validation.

```
command = [
    "python3",
    "manifest/check_manifest.py",
    "--cloud-provider",
    self.global_settings.cloud_provider,
    "--bucket-name",
    self.global_settings.manifest.input_bucket,
    "--folder-path",
    "{{ti.xcom_pull(task_ids='customer_input_sensor', key='input_folder_paths')[0]}}",
    "--file-name",
    manifest_name,
    "--ignore-unexpected-files"
]
```
